{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2015}} {{Infobox film |name = Fritz the Cat |image = Fritz the Cat (film).jpg |image_size = 220px |border = yes |alt = The film poster shows a blonde, pale-orange female cat wearing boots and a blue-striped shirt with a suggestive look sitting next to a grey male cat wearing a red-striped shirt on a green couch, with drugs and matches scattered on the floor. The background is a dark blue with the film's tagline spelled in big white letters on the top and the film's title on the bottom. |caption = Theatrical release poster by [[John Alvin]] |director = [[Ralph Bakshi]] |producer = [[Steve Krantz]] |screenplay = Ralph Bakshi |based on = {{Based on|''[[Fritz the Cat]]''|[[Robert Crumb]]}} |starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Skip Hinnant]] * [[Rosetta LeNoire]] * John McCurry * Judy Engles * [[Phil Seuling]]}} |music = {{Plainlist| * [[Ed Bogas]] * [[Ray Shanklin]]}} |cinematography = {{Plainlist| * Ted Bemiller * Gene Borghi}} |editing = Renn Reynolds |studio = {{Plainlist| * Aurica Finance Company * Black Ink * Fritz Productions * [[Steve Krantz|Steve Krantz Productions]]}} |distributor = [[Cinemation Industries]] |released = {{Film date|1972|04|12}} |runtime = 80 minutes<!--Theatrical runtime: 80:36--><ref>{{cite web|title=''Fritz the Cat'' (X)|url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/fritz-cat-1970|work=[[British Board of Film Classification]]|date=June 2, 1972|accessdate=March 12, 2013}}</ref> |country = United States |language = [[English language|English]], [[Yiddish]] |rating = X |budget = $700,000 |gross = $90 million }} '''''Fritz the Cat''''' is a 1972 American [[adult animated]] [[comedy film]] written and directed by [[Ralph Bakshi]]. It was Bakshi's feature film debut and is loosely based on the [[Fritz the Cat]] comic strips by [[Robert Crumb]]. It was the first animated feature film to receive an [[X rating]] in the United States.
The film stars Fritz (voiced by [[Skip Hinnant]]), an [[Anthropomorphism|anthropomorphic]] cat in mid-1960s New York City who explores the ideals of [[hedonism]] and sociopolitical consciousness. The film is a [[satire]] focusing on American college life of the era, race relations, the [[free love]] movement, and [[left-wing|left-]] and [[right-wing politics]].
The film had a troubled production history and controversial release. Crumb had disagreements with the filmmakers over the film's political content.<ref name="Maremaa"/><ref name="Barrier-3"/><ref name="Barrier-5"/> ''Fritz the Cat'' was controversial for its rating and content, which many viewers at the time found to be offensive. It was produced on a budget of $700,000<ref name="cohen">Cohen, Karl F. (1997). ''Forbidden Animation: Censored Cartoons and Blacklisted Animators in America''. Jefferson, North Carolina: McFarland & Company, Inc., Publishers, pgs 82-83, {{ISBN|978-0786420322}}.</ref> and grossed over $90 million worldwide. Its success led to a slew of other X-rated animated films and a sequel, ''[[The Nine Lives of Fritz the Cat]]'' (1974), made without Crumb's or Bakshi's involvement.
==Plot== In a [[New York City]] park, [[hippie]]s have gathered with guitars to sing [[protest song]]s. Fritz and his buddies show up in an attempt to meet girls. When a trio of attractive females walk by, Fritz and his friends exhaust themselves trying to get their attention, but find that the girls are more interested in the [[crow]] standing a few feet away. The girls attempt to flirt with the crow, making unintentionally condescending remarks about [[black (people)|black]]s, while Fritz looks on in annoyance. Suddenly, the crow rebukes the girls with a snide remark, indicates that he is [[gay]] and walks away. Fritz invites the girls to "seek the truth", bringing them up to his friend's apartment, where a wild party is taking place. Since the other rooms are crowded, Fritz drags the girls into the bathroom and the four of them have [[group sex]] in the bathtub.
Meanwhile, the [[police]] (portrayed as [[pig]]s) arrive to raid the party. As the two officers walk up the stairs, one of the party-goers finds Fritz and the girls in the bath tub. Several others jump in, pushing Fritz to the side where he takes solace in [[marijuana]]. The two officers break into the apartment, but find that it is empty because everyone has moved into the bathroom. Fritz takes refuge in the toilet when one of the pigs enters the bathroom and begins to beat up the partygoers. As the pig becomes exhausted, a very stoned Fritz jumps out, grabs the pig's gun, and shoots the toilet, causing the water main to break and flooding everybody out of the apartment. The pigs chase Fritz down the street into a [[synagogue]]. Fritz manages to escape when the congregation gets up to celebrate the United States' decision to send more weapons into [[Israel]].
Fritz makes it back to his dormitory, where his roommates ignore him. He decides to ditch his bore of a life and sets all of his notes and books on fire. The fire spreads throughout the dorm, finally setting the entire building ablaze. In a bar in [[Harlem]], Fritz meets Duke the Crow at a billiard table. After narrowly avoiding getting into a fight with the bartender, Duke invites Fritz to "bug out", and they steal a car, which Fritz drives off a bridge, leading Duke to save his life by grabbing onto a railing. The two arrive at the apartment of a drug dealer named Bertha, whose [[Joint (cannabis)|cannabis joints]] increase Fritz's libido. While having sex with Bertha, he comes to a realization that he "must tell the people about the revolution!" He runs off into the city street and incites a riot, during which Duke is shot and killed.
Fritz hides in an alley where his older fox girlfriend, Winston Schwartz, finds him and drags him on a road trip to San Francisco. When the car runs out of gas in the middle of the desert, he decides to abandon her. He later meets up with Blue, a [[heroin]]-addicted [[Nazi]] rabbit biker. Along with Blue's horse girlfriend, Harriet, they take a ride to an underground hide-out, where several other revolutionaries tell Fritz of their plan to blow up a power station.
When Harriet tries to get Blue to leave with her to go to a Chinese restaurant, he hits her several times and ties her down with a chain. When Fritz objects to their treatment of her, he is hit in the face with a candle by a member of the group. Blue and the other revolutionaries then gang-rape her. After setting the dynamite at the power plant, Fritz suddenly has a change of heart, and unsuccessfully attempts to remove it before being caught in the explosion. At a [[Los Angeles]] hospital, Harriet (disguised as a nun) and the girls from the New York park come to comfort him in what they believe to be his last moments. Fritz, after reciting the speech he used to pick up the girls from New York, becomes revitalized and has sex with the trio of girls while Harriet watches in astonishment.
==Cast== * [[Skip Hinnant]] as [[Fritz the Cat]] * [[Rosetta LeNoire]] as Big Bertha / Additional voices * [[John McCurry]] as Blue / John * [[Judy Engles]] as Winston Schwartz / Lizard Leader * [[Phil Seuling]] as Pig Cop #2 / Additional voices * [[Ralph Bakshi]] (''uncredited'') as Pig Cop #1 / Narrator * [[Mary Dean]] (''uncredited'') as Girl #1 / Girl #2 / Girl #3 / Harriet * [[Charles Spidar]] (''uncredited'') as Bar Patron / Duke the Crow
==Background== [[Robert Crumb]] (b. 1943) was still a teenager when he created the character [[Fritz the Cat]] for self-published comics magazines he made with his older brother [[Charles Crumb|Charles]]. The character first appeared to a wider public in [[Harvey Kurtzman]]'s humor magazine ''[[Help! (magazine)|Help!]]'' in 1965.{{sfn|Creekmur|2010|p=228}} <!-- no need to go overboard on the detail on how this progressively developed -->The strips place anthropomorphic characters—normally associated with children's comics—in stories with drugs, sex, and other adult-oriented content.{{sfn|Creekmur|2010|p=229}} Crumb left his wife in 1967 and moved to San Francisco, where he took part in the [[Counterculture of the 1960s|counterculture]] and indulged in drugs such as [[LSD]]. He had countercultural strips published in underground periodicals{{sfn|Harvey|1996|p=193}} and in 1968 published the first issue of ''[[Zap Comix]]''. Crumb's cartoons became progressively more transgressive, sexually explicit, and violent,{{sfn|Harvey|1996|pp=195–196}} and Crumb became the center of the burgeoning [[underground comix]] movement.{{sfn|Harvey|1996|p=214}} Fritz became one of Crumb's best-known creations, particularly outside the counterculture.{{sfn|Harvey|1996|p=218}}
{{quote box|width=30%|align=right|quote=[The idea of] grown men sitting in cubicles drawing butterflies floating over a field of flowers, while American planes are dropping bombs in Vietnam and kids are marching in the streets, is ludicrous.|source= —Ralph Bakshi<ref name="Barrier-1"/>}}
[[Ralph Bakshi]] majored in cartooning at the [[High School of Art and Design]]. He learned his trade at the [[Terrytoons]] studio in New York City, where he spent ten years animating characters such as [[Mighty Mouse]], [[Heckle and Jeckle]], and [[Deputy Dawg]]. At the age of 29, Bakshi was hired to head the [[Famous Studios|animation division]] of [[Paramount Pictures]] as both writer and director, where he produced four experimental short films before the studio closed in 1967.<ref name="Cohen-81">{{cite book |last=Cohen |first=Karl F |title=Forbidden Animation: Censored Cartoons and Blacklisted Animators in America |year=1997 |publisher=McFarland & Company, Inc. |location=North Carolina |ISBN=0-7864-0395-0 |chapter=Ralph Bakshi's ''Fritz the Cat'' and ''Heavy Traffic'' |pages=81–84 }}</ref> With producer [[Steve Krantz]], Bakshi founded his own studio, Bakshi Productions. In 1969, Ralph's Spot was founded as a division of Bakshi Productions to produce commercials for [[Coca-Cola]] and ''[[Max, the 2000-Year-Old Mouse]]'', a series of educational shorts paid for by [[Encyclopædia Britannica]].<ref name="Gibson-McDonnell-58">{{cite book |last1=Gibson |first1=Jon M. |last2=McDonnell |first2=Chris |title=Unfiltered: The Complete Ralph Bakshi |year=2008 |publisher=Universe Publishing |isbn=0-7893-1684-6 |page=58|chapter=''Fritz the Cat'' }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Television/radio Age |year=1969 |publisher=Television Editorial Corp |page=13 }}</ref> However, Bakshi was uninterested in the kind of animation he was producing, and wanted to produce something personal. In a 1971 article for the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' Bakshi said that the idea of "grown men sitting in cubicles drawing butterflies floating over a field of flowers, while American planes are dropping bombs in Vietnam and kids are marching in the streets, is ludicrous."<ref name="Barrier-1">{{cite journal |url=http://www.michaelbarrier.com/Funnyworld/FritzPartOne/FritzOne.htm |title=The Filming of ''Fritz the Cat'': Bucking the Tide |accessdate=March 2, 2007 |author=Barrier, Michael |authorlink=Michael Barrier (historian) |date=Spring 1972 |work=Funnyworld | issue=14 |pages= |language= |quote= }}</ref> Bakshi soon developed ''[[Heavy Traffic]]'', a tale of inner-city street life. However, Krantz told Bakshi that studio executives would be unwilling to fund the film because of its content and Bakshi's lack of film experience.<ref name="Gibson-McDonnell-58"/>
While browsing the East Side Book Store on [[St. Mark's Place (Manhattan)|St. Mark's Place]], Bakshi came across a copy of ''R. Crumb's Fritz the Cat'' (1969). Impressed by Crumb's sharp satire, Bakshi purchased the book and suggested to Krantz that it would work as a film.<ref name="Gibson-McDonnell-60">{{cite book |last1=Gibson |first1=Jon M. |last2=McDonnell |first2=Chris |title=Unfiltered: The Complete Ralph Bakshi |year=2008 |publisher=Universe Publishing |isbn=0-7893-1684-6 |page=60|chapter=''Fritz the Cat'' }}</ref> Bakshi was interested in directing the film because he felt that Crumb's work was the closest to his own.<ref name="BakshiOn-1">{{cite web |url=http://www.ralphbakshi.com/gallery/displayimage.php?album=38&pos=0 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071027075512/http://www.ralphbakshi.com/gallery/displayimage.php?album=38&pos=0 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=October 27, 2007 |title=Bakshi on ... Fritz |accessdate=October 6, 2007 |work= |publisher=The official Ralph Bakshi website |pages= |language= |doi= |quote= }}</ref> Krantz arranged a meeting with Crumb, during which Bakshi showed Crumb drawings that had been created as the result of Bakshi attempting to learn Crumb's style to prove that he could translate the look of Crumb's artwork to animation.<ref name="Gibson-McDonnell-58"/> Impressed by Bakshi's tenacity, Crumb lent him one of his sketchbooks as a reference.<ref name="Gibson-McDonnell-60"/>
As Krantz began to prepare the paperwork, preparation began on a pitch presentation for potential studios, including a poster-sized painted [[cel]] setup featuring the strip's cast against a traced photo background, as Bakshi intended the film to appear.<ref name="Gibson-McDonnell-60"/> In spite of Crumb's enthusiasm, he was unsure about the film's production, and refused to sign the contract.<ref name="Gibson-McDonnell-60"/> Cartoonist [[Vaughn Bodé]] warned Bakshi against working with Crumb, describing him as "slick".<ref name="Gibson-McDonnell-60"/> Bakshi later agreed with Bodé's assessment, calling Crumb "one of the slickest hustlers you'll ever see in your life".<ref name="Gibson-McDonnell-60"/> Krantz sent Bakshi to San Francisco, where Bakshi stayed with Crumb and his wife Dana in an attempt to persuade Crumb to sign the contract. After a week, Crumb left, leaving the film's production status uncertain,<ref name="Gibson-McDonnell-62">{{cite book |last1=Gibson |first1=Jon M. |last2=McDonnell |first2=Chris |title=Unfiltered: The Complete Ralph Bakshi |year=2008 |publisher=Universe Publishing |isbn=0-7893-1684-6 |pages=62–63|chapter=''Fritz the Cat'' }}</ref> but Dana had power of attorney and signed the contract. Crumb received US$50,000, which was delivered throughout different phases of the production, in addition to ten percent of Krantz's take.<ref name="Gibson-McDonnell-62"/>
==Production==
===Funding and distribution=== With the rights to the character, Krantz and Bakshi set out to find a distributor. "When I say that every major distributor turned it down, this is not an exaggeration",<ref name="Barrier-3">{{cite journal |url=http://www.michaelbarrier.com/Funnyworld/FritzPartOne/FritzThree.htm |title=The Filming of ''Fritz the Cat'': Crumb, His Cat, and the Dotted Line |accessdate=March 2, 2007 |author=Barrier, Michael |authorlink=Michael Barrier (historian) |date=Spring 1972 |work=Funnyworld | issue=14 |pages= |language= |quote= }}</ref> remembers Krantz. "There has never been a project that was received with less enthusiasm. Animation is essentially a dirty word for distributors, who think that only [[Walt Disney|Disney]] can paint a tree, and in addition to that, ''Fritz'' was so far out that there was a failure to understand that we were onto something very important."<ref name="Barrier-1"/>
In the spring of 1970, [[Warner Bros.]] agreed to fund and distribute the film.<ref name="Cohen-81"/><ref name="NYT">{{cite web |url=http://movies2.nytimes.com/mem/movies/review.html?title1=COOL%20WORLD%20(MOVIE)&title2=&reviewer=JAMIE%20DIAMOND&pdate=&v_id= |title=Animation's Bad Boy Returns, Unrepentant |accessdate=March 21, 2007 |author=Diamond, Jamie |date=July 5, 1992 |work=New York Times |pages= |language= |quote= }}</ref> The Harlem sequences were the first to be completed. Krantz intended to release these scenes as a 15-minute short if the film's funding was pulled; Bakshi was nevertheless determined to complete the film as a feature.<ref name="Gibson-McDonnell-62"/> Late in November, Bakshi and Krantz screened a presentation reel for the studio with this sequence, pencil tests, and shots of Bakshi's storyboards.<ref name="Barrier-4">{{cite journal |url=http://www.michaelbarrier.com/Funnyworld/FritzPartTwo/FritzFour.htm |title=The Filming of ''Fritz the Cat'': Coast to Coast Animation |accessdate=March 2, 2007 |author=Barrier, Michael |authorlink=Michael Barrier (historian) |date=Fall 1973 |work=Funnyworld | issue=15 |pages= |language= |quote= }}</ref> Bakshi stated, "You should have seen their faces in the screening room when I first screened a bit of ''Fritz''. I'll remember their faces until I die. One of them left the room. Holy hell, you should have seen his face. 'Shut ''up'', Frank! This is not the movie you're allowed to make!' And I said, Bullshit, I just made it."<ref name="BlackBook">{{cite web |url=http://www.blackbookmag.com/article/ralph-bakshi-on-the-fritz |title=Ralph Bakshi on the 'Fritz' |accessdate=April 4, 2008 |last=Haramis |first=Nick |date=March 16, 2008 |publisher=BlackBook}}</ref>
The film's budget is disputed. In 1972, ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' stated that ''Fritz the Cat'' recouped its costs in four months following its release. A year later the magazine reported that the film grossed $30 million worldwide and was produced on a budget of $1.3 million. In 1993, director Ralph Bakshi said "''Fritz the Cat'', to me, was an enormous budget -- at $850,000 -- compared to my [[Terrytoons|Terrytoon]] budgets ..." In an intereview published in 1980, Bakshi stated "We made the film for $700,000. Complete".<ref name="cohen"/>
Warner executives wanted the sexual content toned down, and to cast big names for the voices. Bakshi refused, and Warner pulled their funding from the film, leading Krantz to seek funds elsewhere. This led to a deal with Jerry Gross, the owner of [[Cinemation Industries]], a distributor specializing in [[exploitation film]]s. Although Bakshi did not have enough time to pitch the film, Gross agreed to fund its production and distribute it, believing that it would fit in with his [[grindhouse]] slate.<ref name="Gibson-McDonnell-62"/> Further financing came from [[Saul Zaentz]], who agreed to distribute the [[Fritz the Cat (soundtrack)|soundtrack album]] on his [[Fantasy Records]] label.<ref name="Gibson-McDonnell-62"/>
===Direction=== [[File:RalphBakshiJan09.jpg|thumb|alt=Head and shoulders of a bearded older man in glasses. Smiling, with eyes nearly closed, he is wearing a plain sweater and holding a microphone.|The film was the feature debut of writer and director Ralph Bakshi.]] Bakshi was initially reluctant to direct ''Fritz the Cat'' because he had spent years working on animated productions featuring animal characters and wanted to make films focusing on human characters.<ref name="DirectorsSeries">{{cite web|url=http://video.google.com/videoplay?docid=8744784132440773336&hl=en |title=The Directors Series: Interview with Ralph Bakshi |accessdate=March 16, 2007 |author=Gallagher, John A. |year=1983 |work= |publisher= |pages= |language= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090124050714/http://video.google.com/videoplay?docid=8744784132440773336&hl=en |archivedate=January 24, 2009 |quote= |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> He became interested in working on the film because he loved Crumb's work and considered him a "total genius".<ref name="Cohen-81"/> During the development of the film, Bakshi says that he "started to get giddy" when he "suddenly was able to get a pig that was a cop, and this particular other pig was [[Jewish]], and I thought, 'Oh my God—a Jewish pig?' These were major steps forward, because in the initial ''[[Heckle and Jeckle]]'' for Terrytoons, they were two black guys running around. Which was hysterically funny and, I think, great—like [[Uncle Remus]] stuff. But they didn't play down south, and they had to change two black crows to two Englishmen. And I always told him that the black crows were funnier. So it was a slow awakening."<ref name="IGN">{{cite web|url=http://filmforce.ign.com/articles/518/518805p1.html |title=An Interview with Ralph Bakshi |accessdate=April 27, 2007 |first=Ken |last=P. |date=May 25, 2004 |work= |publisher=IGN |pages= |language= |quote= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060218211315/http://filmforce.ign.com/articles/518/518805p1.html |archivedate=February 18, 2006 |df= }}</ref>
In his notes to animator Cosmo Anzilotti, Bakshi is precise, and even specifies that the crows smoked marijuana rather than tobacco. Bakshi states that "The weed had to read on screen. It's an important character detail."<ref name="Gibson-McDonnell-66">{{cite book |last1=Gibson |first1=Jon M. |last2=McDonnell |first2=Chris |title=Unfiltered: The Complete Ralph Bakshi |year=2008 |publisher=Universe Publishing |isbn=0-7893-1684-6 |pages=66–67|chapter=''Fritz the Cat'' }}</ref> The film's opening sequence sets the satirical tone of the film. The setting of the story's period is not only established by a title, but also by a voiceover by Bakshi playing a character giving his account of the 1960s: "happy times, heavy times". The film's opening dialogue, by three construction workers on their lunch break, establishes many of the themes discussed in the film, including drug use, promiscuity, and the social and political climate of the era. When one of the workers urinates off of the scaffold, the film's credits play over a shot of the liquid falling against a black screen. When the credits end, it is shown that the construction worker has urinated on a long-haired hippie with a guitar. Karl F. Cohen writes that the film "is a product of the radical politics of the period. Bakshi's depiction of Fritz's life is colorful, funny, sexist, raw, violent, and outrageous."<ref name="Cohen-81"/>
Of his direction of the film, Bakshi stated, "My approach to animation as a director is live action. I don't approach it in the traditional animation ways. None of our characters get up and sing, because that's not the type of picture I'm trying to do. I want people to believe my characters are real, and it's hard to believe they're real if they start walking down the street singing."<ref name="Barrier-1"/> Bakshi wanted the film to be the [[antithesis]] of any animated film produced by [[the Walt Disney Company]].<ref name="Cohen-81"/> Accordingly, ''Fritz the Cat'' includes two satirical references to Disney. In one scene, silhouettes of [[Mickey Mouse]], [[Daisy Duck]], and [[Donald Duck]] are shown cheering on the [[United States Air Force]] as it drops [[napalm]] on a black neighborhood during a riot. Another scene features a reference to the "[[Pink Elephants on Parade]]" sequence from ''[[Dumbo]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cinepassion.org/Reviews/f/FritzCat.html |title=Cinepassion: Review of ''Fritz the Cat'' (1972) |accessdate=April 6, 2007 |work= }}</ref> A sequence of the camera panning across a garbage heap in an abandoned lot in Harlem sets up a visual device which recurs in ''[[Hey Good Lookin' (film)|Hey Good Lookin']]''.<ref name="Miller"/>
===Writing=== The original screenplay consisted mostly of dialog and featured only a few changes from Crumb's stories. The script and storyboards went largely unused in favor of more experimental storytelling techniques.<ref name="Barrier-5">{{cite journal |url=http://www.michaelbarrier.com/Funnyworld/FritzPartTwo/FritzFive.htm |title=The Filming of ''Fritz the Cat'': A Strange Breed of Cat |accessdate=March 2, 2007 |author=Barrier, Michael |authorlink=Michael Barrier (historian) |date=Fall 1973 |work=Funnyworld | issue=15 |pages= |language= |quote= }}</ref><ref name="Barrier-4"/> Bakshi said, "I don't like to jump ahead on my films. The way you feel about a film on Day One, you may not feel the same way forty weeks down the road. Characters grow, so I wanted to have the option to change things, and strengthen my characters  ... It was sort of a stream of consciousness, and a learning process for myself."<ref name="Barrier-4"/> Bakshi wrote the characters without feral animal behavior to lend the material greater realism.<ref name=Arrow>{{cite video | people = Ralph Bakshi | date = 2006 | title = Interview | url = | medium = ''The Fritz the Cat Collection'' DVD set, disc 3| publisher = Arrow Films}}</ref>
The first part of the film's plot was adapted from a self-titled story published in a 1968 issue of ''R. Crumb's Head Comix'',<ref name="Barrier-5"/><ref>{{cite book |last=Crumb |first=Robert |title=Fritz the Cat |year=1968 |publisher=R. Crumb's Head Comix |location= |isbn= }}</ref> while the second part is derived from "Fritz Bugs Out", which was serialized in the February to October 1968 issues of ''[[Cavalier (magazine)|Cavalier]]'',<ref name="Barrier-5"/><ref>{{cite book |last=Crumb |first=Robert |title=Fritz Bugs Out |date=February–October 1968 |work=Cavalier |location= |isbn= }}</ref> and the final part of the story contains elements of "Fritz the No-Good", first published in the September/October 1968 issue of ''Cavalier''.<ref>{{cite book |last=Crumb |first=Robert |title=Fritz the No-Good |date=September–October 1968 |work=Cavalier |location= |isbn= }}</ref> The last half of the film makes a major departure from Crumb's work. Animation historian [[Michael Barrier (historian)|Michael Barrier]] describes this section of the film as being "much grimmer than Crumb's stories past that point, and far more violent."<ref name="Barrier-5"/> Bakshi stated that he deviated from the comics because he felt that the strips lacked depth:
<blockquote>It was cute, it was sweet, but there was nowhere to put it. That's why Crumb hates the picture, because I slipped a couple of things in there that he despises, like the rabbis—the pure Jewish stuff. Fritz can't hold that kind of commentary. Winston is 'just a typical Jewish broad from Brooklyn'.  ... [The strip] was cute and well-done, but there was nothing that had that much depth.<ref>{{cite web |last=Heater |first=Brian |title=Interview: Ralph Bakshi Pt. 2 |url=http://thedailycrosshatch.com/2008/06/30/interview-ralph-bakshi-pt-2/ |date=June 30, 2008 |work=The Daily Cross Hatch |accessdate=June 19, 2009}}</ref></blockquote>
Bakshi's unwillingness to use anthropomorphic characters that behaved like feral animals led him to rewrite a scene in "Fritz Bugs Out" where Duke saves Fritz's life by flying while holding Fritz; in the film, Duke grabs a railing before the car crashes into the river, a solution that Bakshi wasn't entirely satisfied with, but prevented him from having to use any feral animal behavior in that scene.<ref name=Arrow/>
In the film, there are two characters named "Winston" – one appears at the beginning and end of the film, the other is Fritz's girlfriend Winston Schwartz. Michael Barrier notes that Winston Schwartz (who appears prominently in "Fritz Bugs Out" and "Fritz the No-Good") never has a proper introduction in Bakshi's film, and interprets the naming of a separate character as Bakshi's attempt to reconcile this; however, the two characters look and sound nothing alike.<ref name="Barrier-5"/> Bakshi intended to end the film with Fritz's death, but Krantz objected to this ending, and Bakshi eventually changed it to the final ending.<ref name=Arrow/>
===Casting=== The film's voice cast includes [[Skip Hinnant]], [[Rosetta LeNoire]], John McCurry, Judy Engles, and comic book distributor/convention organizer [[Phil Seuling]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/1971/film/reviews/fritz-the-cat-1200422802/ |title=Review of ''Fritz the Cat'' |accessdate=April 5, 2007 |date=January 1, 1972 |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |pages= |quote= }}</ref> Hinnant, who would become known as a featured performer on ''[[The Electric Company]]'', was cast because he "had such a naturally phony voice", according to Bakshi.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ralphbakshi.com/gallery/displayimage.php?album=38&pos=1 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071027074537/http://www.ralphbakshi.com/gallery/displayimage.php?album=38&pos=1 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=October 27, 2007 |title=Bakshi on ... Fritz |accessdate=October 6, 2007 |work= |publisher=The official Ralph Bakshi website |pages= |doi= |quote= }}</ref> Bakshi and Seuling improvised their dialogue as comically inept pig officers; Bakshi enjoyed working as a voice actor and later went on to provide voice roles for some of his other films.<ref name=Arrow/> Bakshi re-created the voice he did in this film for the part of a storm trooper in his 1977 animated [[science fiction]] film ''[[Wizards (film)|Wizards]]''.<ref name="WizardsCommentary">Bakshi, Ralph. ''Wizards'' [[DVD]], 20th Century Fox Home Entertainment, 2004, [[audio commentary]]. ASIN: B0001NBMIK</ref>
===Audio design=== Some scenes used documentary recordings which were made by Bakshi and edited to fit the scene;<ref name="A.V. Club">{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/content/node/22810 |title=Interview with Ralph Bakshi |accessdate=April 27, 2007 |first=Tasha |last=Robinson |date=January 31, 2003 |work= |publisher=The Onion A.V. Club |pages= |language= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012173749/http://www.avclub.com/content/node/22810 |archivedate=October 12, 2007 |quote= |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> these were used because Bakshi wanted the film to "feel real".<ref name="Miller">{{cite journal |last1=Miller |first1=Morgan |date=April 2010 |title=Ralph Bakshi |journal=[[BOMB (magazine)|BOMB]] |url=http://bombsite.com/issues/999/articles/3491 |accessdate=April 30, 2010}}</ref> According to Bakshi, "I made tons and tons of tapes.  ... When I went to have the film mixed, the sound engineers gave me all kinds of crap about the tracks not being professionally recorded; they didn't even want to mix the noise of bottles breaking in the background, street noise, tape hiss, all kinds of shit. They said it was unprofessional, but I didn't care." Although the sound designers insisted that Bakshi needed to re-record the dialogue in the studio, Bakshi persisted on their inclusion.<ref name="Miller"/>
Almost all of the film's dialogue, except for that of a few of the main characters, was recorded entirely on the streets of New York City.<ref name="Bio">{{cite web|url=http://www.ralphbakshi.com/bio.php |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040824000136/http://www.ralphbakshi.com/bio.php |dead-url=yes |archive-date=August 24, 2004 |title=Biography |accessdate=March 2, 2007 |work= |publisher=Ralph Bakshi.com |pages= |language= |quote= |df= }}</ref> For the film's opening sequence, Bakshi paid two construction workers US$50 each, and drank [[Scotch whisky|Scotch]] with them, recording the conversation.<ref name="Miller"/> In the Washington Square Park sequence, only Skip Hinnant was a professional actor; Fritz's friends were voiced by young males Bakshi found in the park.<ref name="Miller"/> One of the sequences that was not based upon Crumb's comics involved a comic chase through a [[synagogue]] full of praying [[rabbi]]s. For the voices of the rabbis, Bakshi used a documentary recording of his father and uncles. This scene continued to have a personal significance on Bakshi after his father and uncle died. Bakshi states, "Thank God I have their voices. I have my dad and family praying. It's so nice to hear now."<ref name="Gibson-McDonnell-66"/> Bakshi also went to a [[Harlem]] bar with a tape recorder and spent hours talking to black patrons, getting drunk with them as he asked them questions.<ref name="Barrier-4"/>
===Music===
{{Main|Fritz the Cat (soundtrack)}}
The film's score was composed by [[Ed Bogas]] and [[Ray Shanklin]]. The soundtrack was released by [[Fantasy Records]] and Ampex Tapes, along with the single, "You're the Only Girl" b/w "Winston". The film also featured songs by [[Charles Earland]], [[Cal Tjader]], [[Bo Diddley]], and [[Billie Holiday]]. Bakshi bought the rights to use Holiday's performance of the song "Yesterdays" for $35.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fulvuedrive-in.com/interview/1032/RALPH+BAKSHI+INTERVIEW |title=Ralph Bakshi on the recent DVD release of ''Wizards'' |accessdate=March 6, 2007 |author=Simmons, Stephanie |authorlink= |author2=Simmons, Areya |work= |publisher=Fulvue Drive-In |pages= |language= |quote= }}</ref>
===Animation=== [[Image:A Soul Tormented.jpg|alt=Four cartoon figures of cats dressed in human clothes, walking single file.|thumb|220px|Fritz trying to [[Pickup artist|pick up]] a trio of young females at [[Washington Square Park]]. The background is a watercolor painting based on a tracing from a photograph, giving the film a stylized realism virtually unprecedented in animation.<ref name="Gibson-McDonnell-58"/>]] Many of the animators who worked on the film were professionals that Bakshi had previously worked with at Terrytoons, including Jim Tyer, John Gentilella, Nick Tafuri, [[Martin Taras]], Larry Riley, and Cliff Augustine.<ref name="Beck">{{cite book |last=Beck |first=Jerry |title=The Animated Movie Guide |year=2005 |publisher=Chicago Review Press |location= |pages=88–89 |isbn=978-1-55652-591-9 }}</ref> According to Bakshi, it took quite a long time to assemble the right staff. Those who entered with a smirk, "wanting to be very dirty and draw filthy pictures", did not stay very long, and neither did those with a low tolerance for vulgarity. One cartoonist refused to draw a [[African-American|black]] crow shooting a pig policeman. Two female animators quit; one because she could not bring herself to tell her children what she did for a living, the other because she refused to draw exposed breasts.<ref name="Kanfer">{{cite book |last=Kanfer |first=Stefan |title=Serious Business: The Art and Commerce of Animation in America from Betty Boop to Toy Story |year=2001 |publisher=Da Capo |location= |isbn=978-0-306-80918-7|page=204 }}</ref>
In order to save money by eliminating the need for model sheets, Bakshi let animator John Sparey draw some of the first sequences of Fritz. Bakshi states that he knew that "Sparey would execute them beautifully." Poses from his sequences were photocopied and handed out to the rest of the crew.<ref name="Gibson-McDonnell-58"/> The film was produced almost entirely without [[Pencil test (animation)|pencil tests]]. According to Bakshi, "We pencil tested I'd say a thousand feet [of footage], tops. ... We do a major feature without pencil tests—that's tough. The timing falls off. I can always tell an animator to draw it better, and I know if the attitude of the characters is right, but the timing you really can't see." Bakshi had to judge the timing of the animation simply by flipping an animator's drawings in his hand, until he could see the completed animation on the screen.<ref name="Barrier-1"/> Veteran Warner Bros. animator Ted Bonnicksen was incredibly dedicated to his work on the film, to the point where he completed his animation for the synagogue sequence while suffering from leukemia, and would take the scenes home at night to work on them.<ref name="Gibson-McDonnell-66"/>
In May 1971, Bakshi moved his studio to Los Angeles to hire additional animators there. Some animators, including [[Rod Scribner]], [[Dick Lundy (animator)|Dick Lundy]], [[Virgil Walter Ross]], [[Norman McCabe]], and [[John Sparey]], welcomed Bakshi's presence, and felt that ''Fritz the Cat'' would bring diversity to the animation industry.<ref name="Gibson-McDonnell-72"/> Other animators disliked Bakshi's presence, and placed an advertisement in ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'', stating that Bakshi's "filth" was unwelcome in California.<ref name="Gibson-McDonnell-72">{{cite book |last1=Gibson |first1=Jon M. |last2=McDonnell |first2=Chris |title=Unfiltered: The Complete Ralph Bakshi |year=2008 |publisher=Universe Publishing |isbn=0-7893-1684-6 |page=72|chapter=''Fritz the Cat'' }}</ref> According to Bakshi, "I didn't know who these guys were because I was from New York, so I threw the ad away."<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.awn.com/mag/issue4.04/4.04pages/bakshidrawing.php3 |title=Draw What You Want To Draw |accessdate=April 27, 2007 |last=Bakshi |first=Ralph |date=July 1999 |work=Animation World | issue=4.4 |pages= |language= |quote= }}</ref> However, Bakshi found the negative reaction to the film from his peers to be disheartening.<ref name="Gibson-McDonnell-72"/>
===Cinematography=== Because it was cheaper for Ira Turek to trace photographs to create the backgrounds, Bakshi and Johnnie Vita walked around the streets of the [[Lower East Side]], [[Washington Square Park, New York|Washington Square Park]], [[Chinatown, Manhattan|Chinatown]] and [[Harlem]] to take moody snapshots. Turek inked the outlines of these photographs onto cels with a [[Rotring|Rapidograph]], the [[technical pen]] preferred by Crumb, giving the film's backgrounds stylized realism that had never been portrayed in animation before.<ref name="Gibson-McDonnell-58"/> After Turek completed a background drawing in ink on an animation cel, the drawing would be photocopied onto watercolor paper for Vita and onto animation paper for use in matching the characters to the backgrounds. When Vita finished his painting, Turek's original drawing, on the cel, would be placed over the watercolor, obscuring the photocopy lines on the painting.<ref name="Barrier-4"/> However, not every background was taken from live-action sources.<ref name="Funnyworld-2">{{cite journal |url=http://www.michaelbarrier.com/Funnyworld/FritzPartTwo/FritzFour.htm |title=The Filming of ''Fritz the Cat'', Part Two |accessdate=March 2, 2007 |author=Barrier, Michael |authorlink=Michael Barrier (historian) |date=Fall 1973 |work=Funnyworld | issue=15 |pages= |language= |quote= }}</ref> The tones of the watercolor backgrounds were influenced by the "[[Ashcan School|Ash Can style]]" of painters, which includes [[George Luks]] and [[John French Sloan]].<ref name="Gibson-McDonnell-77">{{cite book |last1=Gibson |first1=Jon M. |last2=McDonnell |first2=Chris |title=Unfiltered: The Complete Ralph Bakshi |year=2008 |publisher=Universe Publishing |isbn=0-7893-1684-6 |pages=77–78|chapter=''Fritz the Cat'' }}</ref> The film also used bent and [[Fisheye lens|fisheye]] camera perspectives in order to replicate the way the film's hippies and hoodlums viewed the city.<ref name="Gibson-McDonnell-77"/>
==Rating== By the time production finished, Cinemation had released [[Melvin Van Peebles]]' ''[[Sweet Sweetback's Baadasssss Song]]'' to considerable success, and the distributor hoped that ''Fritz the Cat'' would be even more profitable.{{clarify|reason=Why?|date=June 2016}} ''Fritz'' received an [[X-rated|X rating]] from the [[Motion Picture Association of America]], the first animated film to receive such rating.<ref name="Gibson-McDonnell-80">{{cite book |last1=Gibson |first1=Jon M. |last2=McDonnell |first2=Chris |title=Unfiltered: The Complete Ralph Bakshi |year=2008 |publisher=Universe Publishing |isbn=0-7893-1684-6 |pages=80–81|chapter=''Fritz the Cat'' }}</ref> Producer Krantz stated that the film lost playdates due to the rating, and 30 American newspapers rejected display advertisements for it or refused to give it editorial publicity.<ref name="Cohen-81"/> The film's limited screenings led Cinemation to exploit the film's content in its promotion of the film, advertising it as containing "90 minutes of violence, excitement, and SEX  ... he's X-rated and animated!"<ref name="Gibson-McDonnell-80"/> According to Ralph Bakshi, "We almost didn't deliver the picture, because of the exploitation of it."<ref name="Barrier-1"/>
Cinemation's advertising style and the film's rating led many to believe that ''Fritz the Cat'' was a [[pornographic film]]. When it was introduced as such at a showing at the [[University of Southern California]], Bakshi stated firmly, "''Fritz the Cat'' is not pornographic."<ref name="Barrier-1"/> In May 1972, ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' reported that Krantz had appealed the X rating, saying "Animals having sex isn't pornography." The MPAA refused to hear the appeal.<ref name="Cohen-81"/> The misconceptions about the film's content were eventually cleared up when it received praise from ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' and ''[[The New York Times]]'', and the film was accepted into the [[1972 Cannes Film Festival]].<ref name="Gibson-McDonnell-80"/> Bakshi later stated, "Now they do as much on ''[[The Simpsons]]'' as I got an X rating for ''Fritz the Cat''."<ref name="UGO">{{cite web|url=http://www.ugo.com/channels/filmtv/features/ralphbakshi/interview.asp |title=Ralph Bakshi Interview |accessdate=April 27, 2007 |first=Daniel Robert |last=Epstein |work= |publisher=UGO.com Film/TV |pages= |language= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060605131239/http://www.ugo.com/channels/filmtv/features/ralphbakshi/interview.asp |archivedate=June 5, 2006 |quote= |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref>
Before the film's release, American distributors attempted to cash in on the publicity garnered from the rating by rushing out dubbed versions of two other [[adult animation|adult animated]] films from Japan, both of which featured an X rating in their advertising material: ''Senya ichiya monogatari'' and ''Kureopatora'', re-titled ''[[One Thousand and One Arabian Nights (film)|One Thousand and One Arabian Nights]]'' and ''[[Cleopatra (1970 film)|Cleopatra: Queen of Sex]]''. However, neither film was actually submitted to the MPAA, and it is not likely that either feature would have received an X rating.<ref name="Barrier-1"/> The film ''[[Down and Dirty Duck]]'' was promoted with an X rating, but had not been submitted to the MPAA.<ref>{{cite book |last=Cohen |first=Karl F |title=Forbidden Animation: Censored Cartoons and Blacklisted Animators in America |year=1997 |publisher=McFarland & Company, Inc. |location=North Carolina |isbn=0-7864-0395-0 |chapter=Charles Swenson's ''Dirty Duck'' |pages=89–90 }}</ref> The French-Belgian animated film ''[[Tarzoon: Shame of the Jungle]]'' was initially released with an X rating in a subtitled version, but a dubbed version released in 1979 received an R rating.<ref>{{cite book |last=Cohen |first=Karl F |title=Forbidden Animation: Censored Cartoons and Blacklisted Animators in America |year=1997 |publisher=McFarland & Company, Inc. |location=North Carolina |isbn=0-7864-0395-0 |chapter=Importing foreign productions |page=91 }}</ref>
For the DVD release, MGM Home Entertainment has surrendered the X rating for an unrated video release, although the tagline "He's X-Rated and Animated!" is still used on the cover. Also, the MPAA "This film has been rated X" screen is seen just before the MGM logo at the end of the film on the DVD.
==Reception== ''Fritz the Cat'' opened on April 12, 1972, in Hollywood and Washington, D.C.<ref name="Barrier-3"/> Although the film only had a limited release, it went on to become a worldwide hit.<ref name=Arrow/> Against its $700,000 budget, it grossed $25 million in the United States and over $90 million worldwide,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Robinson|first1=Tasha|title=Ralph Bakshi - Interview|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/ralph-bakshi-13690|publisher=A.V. Club|accessdate=September 6, 2014|date=December 6, 2000|quote=And Fritz was a $700,000 picture that made $90 million worldwide, and is still playing.}}</ref><ref name=choron>{{cite book |first1=Sandra |last1=Choron |first2=Harry |last2=Choron |first3=Arden |last3=Moore |title=Planet Cat: A Cat-Alog |year=2007 |publisher=[[Houghton Mifflin Harcourt]] |isbn=9780618812592 |page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=shAHJQwXslYC&pg=PA96 96]}}</ref> and was the most successful independent animated feature of all time.<ref name="Gibson-McDonnell-58"/> The film earned $4.7 million in video rentals in North America.<ref>"All-time Film Rental Champs", ''Variety'', January 7, 1976 p. 48.</ref>
In Michael Barrier's 1972 article on its production, Bakshi gives accounts of two screenings of the film. Of the reactions to the film by audiences at a preview screening in Los Angeles, Bakshi stated, "They forget it's animation. They treat it like a film.  ... This is the real thing, to get people to take animation seriously." Bakshi was also present at a showing of the film at the [[Museum of Modern Art]] and remembers, "Some guy asked me why I was against the revolution. The point is, animation was making people get up off their asses and get mad."<ref name="Barrier-1"/>
The film also sparked negative reactions because of its content. "A lot of people got freaked out", says Bakshi. "The people in charge of the power structure, the people in charge of magazines and the people going to work in the morning who loved Disney and [[Norman Rockwell]], thought I was a pornographer, and they made things very difficult for me. The younger people, the people who could take new ideas, were the people I was addressing. I wasn't addressing the whole world. To those people who loved it, it was a huge hit, and everyone else wanted to kill me."<ref name="Guardian">{{cite news |url=http://film.guardian.co.uk/features/featurepages/0,,1841791,00.html |title=Who flamed Roger Rabbit? |accessdate=March 2, 2007 |date=August 11, 2006 |work=The Guardian |pages= |language= |quote= | location=London | first=Steve | last=Rose}}</ref>
===Critical reception=== Critical reaction was mixed, but generally positive. [[Vincent Canby]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' wrote that the film is "constantly funny  ... [There's] something to offend just about everyone."<ref name="Cohen-81"/> ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' magazine film critic [[Judith Crist]] reviewed the film as "a gloriously funny, brilliantly pointed, and superbly executed entertainment  ... [whose] target is  ... the muddle-headed radical chicks and slicks of the sixties", and that it "should change the face of the animated cartoon forever".{{sfn|Crist|1972|p=80}} Paul Sargent Clark in ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' called the film "powerful and audacious",<ref name="Cohen-81"/> while ''[[Newsweek]]'' called it "a harmless, mindless, pro-youth saga calculated to shake up only the box office".<ref name="Cohen-81"/> ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' and ''Cue'' both gave the film mixed reviews.<ref name="Cohen-81"/> Thomas Albright of ''[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]'' wrote an enthusiastic preview in the December 9, 1971 issue based on seeing thirty minutes of the film, declaring that it was "sure to mark the most important breakthrough in animation since ''[[Yellow Submarine (1968 film)|Yellow Submarine]]''".<ref name="RS #97">{{cite journal |last1=Albright |first1=Thomas |last2= |first2= |date=December 9, 1971 |title=Crumb's Cat Fritz Comes To Screen |journal=[[Rolling Stone]] |publisher=Straight Arrow Publishers, Inc. |volume= |issue=97 |page=14 |url= |doi= }}</ref> But in a review published after its release, Albright recanted his earlier statement and wrote that the visuals were not enough to save the finished product from being a "qualified disaster" due to a "leaden plot" and a "juvenile" script that relied too heavily on tired gags and tasteless ethnic humor.<ref name="RS #109">{{cite journal |last1=Albright |first1=Thomas |last2= |first2= |date=May 25, 1972 |title=Fritz the Cat |journal=[[Rolling Stone]] |publisher=Straight Arrow Publishers, Inc. |volume= |issue=109 |page=74 |url= |doi= }}</ref> On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film has a score of 58%, based on 19 critic reviews, with an average rating of 5.5/10.<ref>{{cite web|title=Fritz the Cat (1972) - Rotten Tomatoes|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/fritz_the_cat/|website=Rotten Tomatoes.com|publisher=Rotten Tomatoes|accessdate=14 June 2016}}</ref>
Film critic Andrew Osmond wrote that the epilogue hurt the film's integrity for "giving Fritz cartoon powers of survival that the film had rejected until then".{{sfn|Osmond|2010|p=77}}
Patricia Evans found scenes with Jewish stereotypes "vicious and offensive", and stated, "Only the jaundiced eye of director Ralph Bakshi, which denigrates all of the characters, the hero included, makes one reflect on the nature of the attack."{{sfn|Erens|1984|p=365}}
===Crumb's response=== Crumb first saw the film in February 1972, during a visit to Los Angeles with fellow underground cartoonists [[Spain Rodriguez]], [[S. Clay Wilson]], [[Robert Williams (artist)|Robert Williams]], and [[Rick Griffin]]. According to Bakshi, Crumb was dissatisfied with the film.<!-- according to virtually every source, not just Bakshi—got to do something about this --><ref name=Arrow/> Among his criticisms, he said that he felt that Skip Hinnant was wrong for the voice of Fritz, and said that Bakshi should have voiced the character instead.<ref name=Arrow/> Crumb later said in an interview that he felt that the film was "really a reflection of Ralph Bakshi's confusion, you know. There's something real repressed about it. In a way, it's more twisted than my stuff. It's really twisted in some kind of weird, unfunny way.  ... I didn't like that sex attitude in it very much. It's like real repressed horniness; he's kind of letting it out compulsively."<ref name="Barrier-5"/> Crumb also criticized the film's condemnation of the radical [[left-wing|left]],<ref name="Barrier-3"/> denouncing Fritz's dialogue in the final sequences of the film, which includes a quote from [[The Beatles]] song "[[The End (The Beatles song)|The End]]", as "red-neck and fascistic"<ref name="Maremaa">{{cite book |last1=Maremaa |first1=Thomas |authorlink1= |last2= |first2= |editor1-first=D. K. |editor1-last=Holm |editor1-link= |others= |title=R. Crumb: Conversations |year=2004 |origyear=1972 |publisher=Univ. Press of Mississippi |isbn=1-57806-637-9 |page=28 |chapter=Who Is This Crumb?|laysummary= |laydate= |separator= |postscript= |lastauthoramp=}}</ref> and stated, "They put words into his mouth that I never would have had him say."<ref name="Maremaa"/>
Reportedly, Crumb filed a lawsuit to have his name removed from the film's credits.<ref name="Umphlett">{{cite book |last=Umphlett |first=Wiley Lee |title=From Television to the Internet: Postmodern Visions of American Media Culture in the Twentieth Century |year=2006 |publisher=Fairleigh Dickinson University Press |location= |isbn=978-0-8386-4080-7|page=134 }}</ref> San Francisco copyright attorney Albert L. Morse said that no suit was filed, but an agreement was reached to remove Crumb's name from the credits.<ref name="Funnyworld-Crumb">{{cite journal |url=http://www.michaelbarrier.com/Funnyworld/FritzPartTwo/Crumb.htm |title=The Filming of ''Fritz the Cat'': Feedback from R. Crumb |accessdate=March 2, 2007 |author=Barrier, Michael |authorlink=Michael Barrier (historian) |date=Fall 1973 |work=Funnyworld | issue=15 |pages= |language= |quote= }}</ref> However, Crumb's name has remained in the final film since its original theatrical release.<ref name="Cohen-81"/> In response to his distaste for the film, Crumb had "Fritz the Cat—Superstar" published in ''People's Comics'' later in 1972, in which a jealous girlfriend kills Fritz with an icepick;{{sfn|Harvey|1996|p=218}} he has refused to use the character again,{{sfn|Creekmur|2010|p=228}} and wrote the filmmakers a letter saying not to use his characters in their films.<ref name="Barrier-3"/> Crumb later cited the film as "one of those experiences I sort of block out. The last time I saw it was when I was making an appearance at a German art school in the mid-1980s, and I was forced to watch it with the students. It was an excruciating ordeal, a humiliating embarrassment. I recall [[Victor Moscoso]] was the only one who warned me, 'if you don't stop this film from being made, you are going to regret it for the rest of your life'—and he was right."<ref name="Crumbhandbook">{{cite book | title = The R. Crumb Handbook | first = Robert | last = Crumb|author2=Poplaski, Peter | publisher = M Q Publications | isbn = 978-1-84072-716-6}}</ref>
In a 2008 interview, Bakshi referred to Crumb as a "hustler" and stated, "He goes in so many directions that he's hard to pin down. I spoke to him on the phone. We both had the same deal, five percent. They finally sent Crumb the money and not me. Crumb always gets what he wants, including that château of his in France.  ... I have no respect for Crumb. Is he a good artist? Yes, if you want to do the same thing over and over. He should have been my best friend for what I did with ''Fritz the Cat''. I drew a good picture, and we both made out fine."<ref name="BlackBook"/> Bakshi also stated that Crumb threatened to disassociate himself from any cartoonist that worked with Bakshi, which would have hurt their chances at getting work published.<ref>{{cite web |last=Heater |first=Brian |title=Interview: Ralph Bakshi Pt. 4 |url=http://thedailycrosshatch.com/2008/07/15/interview-ralph-bakshi-pt-4-of-4/ |date=July 15, 2008 |work=The Daily Cross Hatch |accessdate=June 19, 2009}}</ref>
==Legacy== In addition to other animated films aimed at adult audiences, the film's success led to the production of a [[sequel]], ''[[The Nine Lives of Fritz the Cat]]''. Although producer Krantz and voice actor Hinnant returned for the follow-up, Bakshi did not. Instead, ''Nine Lives'' was directed by animator Robert Taylor, who co-wrote the film with Fred Halliday and [[Eric Monte]]. ''Nine Lives'' was distributed by [[American International Pictures]], and was considered to be inferior to its predecessor.<ref name="Grant"/> Both films have been released on DVD in the United States, Canada and the UK.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.ca/Fritz-Cat-Widescreen-Skip-Hinnant/dp/B00003CWQI |title=ASIN: B00003CWQI |accessdate=March 2, 2007 |work= |publisher=[[Amazon.ca]] |pages= |language= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070104072421/http://www.amazon.ca/Fritz-Cat-Widescreen-Skip-Hinnant/dp/B00003CWQI |archivedate=January 4, 2007 |dead-url=yes |quote= |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Fritz-Cat-Nine-Lives/dp/B000EMTJP6/ |title=ASIN: B000EMTJP6 |accessdate=March 2, 2007 |work= |publisher=[[Amazon.com|Amazon.co.uk]] |pages= |language= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070315000056/http://www.amazon.co.uk/Fritz-Cat-Nine-Lives/dp/B000EMTJP6/ |archivedate=March 15, 2007 |dead-url=yes |quote= |df= }}</ref> Bakshi states that he felt constricted using anthropomorphic characters in ''Fritz'', and focused solely on non-anthropomorphic characters in ''[[Heavy Traffic]]'' and ''Hey Good Lookin<nowiki>'</nowiki>'', but later used anthropomorphic characters in ''[[Coonskin (film)|Coonskin]]''.<ref name="Miller"/>
While review aggregate [[Rotten Tomatoes]], which compiles contemporary reviews from a wide range of critics, gives the film a score of 56%,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/fritz_the_cat/ |title=Fritz the Cat |accessdate=March 2, 2007 |work= |publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |pages= |language= |quote= }}</ref> the film is widely noted in its innovation for featuring content that had not been portrayed in animation before, such as sexuality and violence, and was also, as John Grant writes in his book ''Masters of Animation'', "the breakthrough movie that opened brand new vistas to the commercial animator in the United States",<ref name="Grant">{{cite book |last=Grant |first=John |title=Masters of Animation |year=2001 |publisher=Watson-Guptill |isbn=0-8230-3041-5 |pages=19–20 |chapter=Ralph Bakshi }}</ref> presenting an "almost disturbingly accurate" portrayal "of a particular stratum of Western society during a particular era,  ... as such it has dated very well."<ref name="Grant"/> The film's subject matter and its satirical approach offered an alternative to the kinds of films that had previously been presented by major animation studios.<ref name="Grant"/> Michael Barrier described ''Fritz the Cat'' and ''[[Heavy Traffic]]'' as "not merely provocative, but highly ambitious". Barrier described the films as an effort "to push beyond what was done in the old cartoons, even while building on their strengths".<ref>{{cite book |last1=Barrier |first1=Michael |title=Hollywood Cartoons: American Animation in Its Golden Age |year=2003 |publisher=Oxford University Press US |isbn=0-19-516729-5 |page=572}}</ref>
As a result of these innovations, ''Fritz'' was selected by ''[[Time Out (company)|Time Out]]'' magazine as the 42nd greatest animated film,<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Adams, Derek |author2=Calhoun, Dave |author3=Davies, Adam Lee |author4=Fairclough, Paul |author5=Huddleston, Tom |author6=Jenkins, David |author7=Ward, Ossian |year=2009 |title=Time Out's 50 greatest animated films, with added commentary by Terry Gilliam |journal=[[Time Out (company)|Time Out]] |url=http://www.timeout.com/film/features/show-feature/8835/time-outs-50-greatest-animated-films-curated-by-terry-gilliam.html |accessdate=November 11, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091206232303/http://www.timeout.com/film/features/show-feature/8835/time-outs-50-greatest-animated-films-curated-by-terry-gilliam.html |archivedate=December 6, 2009 |df=mdy }}</ref> ranked at number 51 on the [[Online Film Critics Society]]'s list of the top 100 greatest animated films of all time,<ref name="OFCS">{{cite web|url=http://ofcs.rottentomatoes.com/pages/pr/top100animated |title=Top 100 Animated Features of All Time |accessdate=March 2, 2007 |work= |publisher=[[Online Film Critics Society]] |pages= |language= |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ADt9yaLh?url=http://ofcs.rottentomatoes.com/pages/pr/top100animated |archivedate=August 27, 2012 |quote= |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> and was placed at number 56 on [[Channel 4]]'s list of the ''100 Greatest Cartoons''.<ref name="Channel4">{{cite web |url=http://www.channel4.com/entertainment/tv/microsites/G/greatest/cartoons/results.html |title=Top 100 Cartoons |accessdate=January 28, 2008 |work= |publisher=Channel 4 |pages= |language= |quote= }}</ref> Footage from the film was edited into the music video for [[Guru (rapper)|Guru]]'s 2007 song "State of Clarity".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.contactmusic.com/new/home.nsf/webpages/gurux05x06x07 |title=Guru, feat Common, State of Clarity, Video |accessdate=October 6, 2007 |work= |publisher=Contact Music |pages= |language= |doi= |quote= }}</ref>

{{Cleanup rewrite|date=February 2010}} [[File:Chris Pirillo Tshirt.jpg|thumb|200px|alt=Chris Pirillo wearing the Gnomedex 2007 T-shirt.|Chris Pirillo wearing the Gnomedex 2007 T-shirt.]] '''Gnomedex'''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gnomedex.com/ |title=Gnomedex |publisher=Gnomedex |date= |accessdate=2011-09-17}}</ref> is a single-track technology conference hosted by [[Chris Pirillo]], the owner of [[Lockergnome]], LLC<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gnomedex.com/ |title=Gnomedex |publisher=Gnomedex |date= |accessdate=2011-09-17}}</ref> and is produced by Chris Pirillo and his staff at Lockergnome. Pirillo was the co-host of the show [[Call For Help]] on the former cable television channel [[TechTV]]. Gnomedex started as an outgrowth of Pirillo's technology newsletters, IRC channel and web site. The conference name is a satirical [[portmanteau]] of Pirillo's Lockergnome and the now-defunct [[Comdex]] technology trade show, which was a massive and influential annual event at the time of the first Gnomedex conference.
Gnomedex has grown into a conference exploring new and emerging [[technology|technologies]] with influencers, [[entrepreneurs]] and tech enthusiasts as the primary audience. It bills itself as the crossroads between producers and observers, between users and developers. The conference format is meant to serve the needs of the attendees, many of whom are prolific [[blog]]gers and [[podcaster]]s.
The first Gnomedex took place in October 2001 in [[Des Moines]], [[Iowa]], while the tenth Gnomedex took place in August 2010 in [[Seattle]], [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]]. Gnomedex organizer Chris Pirillo announced that due to the difficulites in operating such events, that the tenth was likely to be the last Gnomedex unless additional backing and resources were brought forward to help spread the administrative and organizational overhead.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://chris.pirillo.com/the-future-of-gnomedex/ |title=The Future of Gnomedex ~ Chris Pirillo |publisher=Chris.pirillo.com |date=2001-09-13 |accessdate=2011-09-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.techflash.com/seattle/2010/08/qa_chris_pirillo_on_social_media_geek_week_and_the_last_gnomedex.html |title=Q&A: Chris Pirillo on the possible end of Gnomedex as we know it |publisher=Techflash.com |date=2010-08-09 |accessdate=2011-09-17}}</ref> A Gnomedex stage was included in the first Seattle Interactive Conference in November 2011 after [[Jake Ludington]] reportedly convinced Chris Pirillo to continue the event.<ref>[http://www.geekwire.com/2011/gnomedex-returns-part-seattle-interactive-conference Gnomedex back from another near-death experience]</ref> In March 2015, Chris Pirillo announced that Gnomedex will be making a return sometime in 2015.<ref name="2015-03-25 Soper Geekwire.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.geekwire.com/2015/chris-pirillo-bringing-back-gnomedex-tech-festival-to-seattle/ |title=Chris Pirillo is bringing Gnomedex back in Seattle — but don't call it a conference |newspaper=Geekwire.com |date=2015-03-25 |first=Taylor |last=Soper |accessdate=2015-09-05}}</ref>
== History ==
=== 2001 === The first Gnomedex was held Friday, October 12, 2001 through Sunday October 14, 2001 in [[Des Moines]], [[Iowa]].<ref name="10.11.2001 GnomeREPORT">{{cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040618010230/http://channels.lockergnome.com/windows/backissues/20011011.phtml |archivedate=2004-06-18 |deadurl=yes |url=http://channels.lockergnome.com/windows/backissues/20011011.phtml |work=lockergnome.com |title=10.11.2001 GnomeREPORT |first=Chris |last=Pirillo}}</ref> Originally scheduled for the weekend<ref>{{cite web | url =http://www.vpwsys.net/download/grc_low.wma | title =Raw Sockets Debate: Steve Gibson with Tom C.Greene | last1 = | first1 = | date = | year =2001 | editor = | work =Online Tonight with [[David H. Lawrence XVII|David Lawrence]] | issn = | archive-url =https://archive.org/details/stevegibsoninterviewrawsocketsgrc | archive-date =May 7, 2014 | deadurl =no | accessdate =February 7, 2015 | quote =GnomeDex: September 14 and 15, Des Moines, Iowa (@ 0:18:43) }}</ref> after [[9/11]], it was postponed for a month to allow people to adjust their travel plans. Despite the uncertainty, nearly 200 people attended from all over the United States, Canada and Europe. The keynote was delivered by [[Steve Gibson (computer programmer)|Steve Gibson]], president of Gibson Research Corp. Presentations included:
* [[David Lawrence (radio host)|David Lawrence]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedavidlawrenceshow.com |title=the david lawrence show and online tonight – pop culture, technology, current events and more |publisher=Thedavidlawrenceshow.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-17}}</ref> on the future of the music industry * Userland Software employee [[Robert Scoble]] discussing [[OPML]] and [[RSS]] technologies. * Derek Brown from Microsoft's Mobility Team demonstrating a Pocket PC-powered phone (technology which had just launched). * Mark Thompson, [[freeware]] developer for AnalogX * [[Mike Elgan]], technology writer and editorial consultant * Steve Kiene of [[eSellerate]]
David Lawrence also made a live broadcast of his radio show [[Online Tonight]] from Gnomedex.
Sponsorship was by several companies, including [[SnapStream]] and [[Microsoft]].
=== 2002 === Gnomedex 2.0 occurred on August 23 through August 24, 2002 in Des Moines, Iowa at the Downtown Marriott. The keynote was delivered by [[Leo Laporte]], formerly with [[TechTV]]. The speaker list included:
* Evan Willams from Blogger.com * [[Philip J. Kaplan|Phil "Pud" Kaplan]], creator of [[Fucked Company|FuckedCompany.com]] * Ed Ross, founder of PC Talent * Doc Searls * Beth Goza * Steve Gibson * Mark Thompson of Analog X * David Lawrence
[[Microsoft]] was the banner sponsor.
=== 2003 === Gnomedex 3.0<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gnomedex3.blogspot.com/ |title=Gnomedex 3 |publisher=Gnomedex3.blogspot.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-17}}</ref> was held in Des Moines, Iowa on July 25 and 26 2003.
Jennifer Staack was crowned Ms. Gnomedex 2003.<ref>{{cite web|author=Jenn at August 11, 2003 02:38 AM |url=http://jen.pohl-family.net/archives/000042.html |title=Jenn's Place: I AM Ms. Gnomedex 2003 |publisher=Jen.pohl-family.net |date=2003-08-11 |accessdate=2011-09-17}}</ref>
Beth Goza and Kevin Unangst from Microsoft presented on Digital Media in Microsoft Windows.
Speakers included: *[[John C. Dvorak]], columnist with [[PC Magazine]] *[[Dan Gillmor]], then with the [[San Jose Mercury News]] *[[Rob Malda]], operator of the [[Slashdot]] technology news web site *Nelson Minar from [[Google]] * Jim Louderback of Ziff-Davis Media * Amir Majidimehr of Microsoft Digital Media *[[Tim O'Reilly]], founder of [[O'Reilly Media]] *[[Eric Sink]] from SourceGear * Kevin Unangst of Microsoft
[[Microsoft]] and [[Google]] were the banner sponsors.
=== 2004 === Gnomedex 4.0 (a.k.a. "Geeks Gone Wild") was held from September 30 to October 4, 2004 at [[Harrah's]] in [[Lake Tahoe, Nevada]]. Originally, Gnomedex 4.0 was going to be sponsored by [[Comedy Central]] and have an open bar. The theme (and sponsor) changed several times after it was announced. The keynote was by [[Steve Wozniak]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4tENeGiaLXA&feature=youtube_gdata |title=Woz Keynote – Steve Wozniak at Gnomedex IV |publisher=YouTube |date=2010-08-19 |accessdate=2011-09-17}}</ref> Notable speakers and events included Nick Bradbury, Henry Copeland, Dan Gillmor, Ross Rader, Robert Scoble, [[Jason Shellen]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nick.typepad.com/blog/2007/08/index.html |title=Nick Bradbury: |publisher=Nick.typepad.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-17}}</ref> [[Wil Wheaton]]<ref>[http://www.pmcmovies.com/tech_conferences/just_a_geek_wil_wheaton_at_gnomedex_2004.html ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080913135513/http://www.pmcmovies.com/tech_conferences/just_a_geek_wil_wheaton_at_gnomedex_2004.html |date=September 13, 2008 }}</ref> and a live broadcast of the [[Gillmor Gang]] syndicated technology radio show. Sponsors included [[Microsoft]], [[PayPal]], [[Google]], [[AMD]], [[Yahoo!]] Search, DecisionCast, and [[ZDNet]].
[[Conversations Network|IT Conversations]] produced podcasts of the sessions, which are still available online.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://itc.conversationsnetwork.org/series/gnomedex.html |title=Gnomedex 4.0 |publisher=Itc.conversationsnetwork.org |date= |accessdate=2011-09-17}}</ref> The podcast of Steve Wozniak's keynote address is one of the all-time most popular audio programs in IT Conversations history.
The published schedule was as follows: * ''The Future of Security (panel)'': Chris DiBona (moderator), Neil Wyler, Fred Felman, CJ Holthaus, Nico Sell, Dan Appleman * ''Maximizing Your Blogging Strategies'': Adam Kalsey (moderator), Robert Scoble, Nick Bradbury, Ross Rader, [[Jason Shellen]], Dave Taylor * ''Keynote Speaker'': Steve Wozniak * ''Maximizing Your Digital Lifestyle'': Eric Rice (moderator), Jim Louderback, Patrick Norton, Ken Layne, Anil Dash, Paul Kent, Tim Handley * ''The Future of Online Content'': Scott Johnson, Greg Reinacker, Steve Gillmor, Dan Gillmor, Peter Kaminski, Jason Calacanis * Wil Wheaton * ''The Future of Online Advertising'': Dave McClure (moderator), Jeff Barr, Henry Copeland, Bill Flitter, Gokul Rajaram
=== 2005 === [[File:Chris Pirillo.jpg|thumb|alt=Chris Pirillo at Gnomedex 2005|Chris Pirillo at Gnomedex 2005]] Gnomedex 5.0 was the first of the series to be held in [[Seattle]], Washington at the Bell Harbor Convention Center. The conference took place from June 23–25, 2005. Notable presentations and activities included:
* [[Microsoft]] announced that RSS feeds would be supported in the next version of Microsoft Windows. They also gave the first public demonstration of Internet Explorer 7, focusing on its RSS features. Attendees received a track jacket from Microsoft with "Browse, Search, Subscribe" and "(Longhorn icon) (heart icon) RSS" patches. * [[Adam Curry]] delivered the closing keynote, while simultaneously recording an episode of his podcast, Daily Source Code. * Kathy Gill from University of Washington presented on blogging in the classroom<ref>{{cite web|url=http://faculty.washington.edu/kegill/pub/gnomedex05/ |title=Gnomedex 2005 - Blogs in the Classroom |publisher=Faculty.washington.edu |date=2005-06-24 |accessdate=2011-09-17}}</ref> * Julie Leung gave a presentation on personal and public media * Phillip Torrone of Make Magazine presented on the craft of making * David Winer sang The Beatles' Yellow Submarine. * An episode of the [[Gillmor Gang]] podcast was recorded live.
Scheduled speakers and panels were: * Dave Winer * [[Dean Hachamovitch]] of Microsoft * Steve Gillmor, Dave Sifry, Scott Gatz on Tomorrow's Syndication * Kathy Gill, Paul Vogelzang on the Tomorrow's Education * David Geller, John Battelle, Dan Gillmor on Today's Citizen Media * Matt Westervelt, Asa Dotzler, Scott Collins, Matt Mullenweg on Tomorrow's Open Source * Hobie Swan on MindManager * Julie Leung on Blogging as Social Tool * Mark Fletcher, Scott Rafer, Bob Wyman on Tomorrow's RSS * JD Lasica, Terry Heaton, Cory Bergman on Tomorrow's Media * Steve Rubel, Chris Sloop on Tomorrow's Public Relations * Denise Howell, Buzz Bruggeman, Jason Calacanis on Today's Digital Legalities * Adam Curry
A sold-out crowd of over 400 people attended.
=== 2006 === [[File:A Gillmor Gang photo from Gnomedex 6.0.jpg|thumb|alt=A Gillmor Gang photo from Gnomedex 6.0|A [[Gillmor Gang]] photo from Gnomedex 6.0]] Gnomedex 6.0 was held in [[Seattle]], Washington at the Bell Harbor Convention Center from June 29 - July 1, 2006. Notable presentations were:
* keynote by Senator John Edwards<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.podtech.net/home/866/gnomedex-2006-marc-canters-hilarious-exchange-with-senator-john-edwards |title=Gnomedex 2006: Marc Canter’s Hilarious Exchange With Senator John Edwards |publisher=PodTech.net |date=2006-07-18 |accessdate=2011-09-17}}</ref> * a discussion and demonstration of Pixsy by [[Chase Norlin]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6Aqqb9ZJEjs |title=Gnomedex 2006: Chase Norlin on Pixsy |publisher=YouTube |date=2007-04-13 |accessdate=2011-09-17}}</ref> * a demonstration of Melodeo by Bill Valenti and Rob Greenlee<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_Kw8GHs5Tog |title=Gnomedex 2006: Bill Valenti and Rob Greenly on Melodeo |publisher=YouTube |date=2007-04-13 |accessdate=2011-09-17}}</ref>
The published roster of discussion leaders was: * [[Michael Arrington]] * [[Om Malik]] * Dave Dederer * [[John Edwards]] * Werner Vogels * Steve Rubel * [[Marc Canter]] * Susan Mernit * Jim Lanzone * Steve Gilmor * [[Dave Winer]] * Philip "Pud" Kaplan * [[Chris Messina]] * [[Ethan Kaplan]] * [[Kaliya Hamlin]] (audience pick for Gnomedex MVP) * [[Halley Suitt]] * Blake Ross * [[Jeremy Zawondny]] * [[Phil Torrone]]
A sold-out crowd of over 400 people attended.
=== 2007 === Gnomedex 7.0 was held in [[Seattle]], Washington at the Bell Harbor Convention Center on August 9–11, 2007.
Roster of speakers: * Robert Steele * Darren Barefoot * [[Guy Kawasaki]] * Bad Sinatra Live * Justin Kan * Ronni Bennett * [[Vanessa Fox]] * [[Jason Calacanis]] * Cali Lewis and Neal Campbell * Michael Linton * Gregg Spiridellis * Derek K. Miller (via video link - [http://chris.pirillo.com/derek-millers-cancer-story/ archived video stream]) * Kathy Gill * Sterling Allan
Also, a selection of Ignite Seattle! [http://igniteseattle.com/] participants gave a series of 5-minute [[Pecha Kucha]]-style presentations.
A sold-out crowd of over 400 people attended.

=== 2009 === Gnomedex 9.0 was held from Friday, August 21, 2009 to Saturday, August 22, 2009. === 2010 === [[File:Violet Blue - Gnomedex 10 closeup.jpg|thumb|alt=Violet Blue - Gnomedex 10|[[Violet Blue]] - Gnomedex 10<br/>(CC) Randy Stewart, blog.stewtopia.com]] Gnomedex 10 was held August 19 through August 21, 2010, in [[Seattle]], Washington at the Bell Harbor Conference Center and shared registration with [[pii2010]] as a part of the larger [[Seattle Geek Week]] event.
Commercial sponsors included [[American Public Media]], Atlas Networks, Banyan Branch, the Bellevue Business Journal, BlogWorld, Deploy Day, EventBrite, GirlsInTech, [[GoDaddy]], Griffin Technologies, Hotel Max, [[Hover (domain registrar)|Hover]], IAmEastSide, the [[Issaquah Press]], [[Jones Soda Company]], [[Mashable]], [[Microsoft]], the Modern Media Man Summit, Parallels Holdings, [[PCC Natural Markets]], Pipeline Deals, Pooper Trooper, PopChips, Privacy Identity Innovation, the Public Insight Network, RaceVision, [[RealNetworks]], [[ReveNews]], [[Seagate Technology|Seagate]], Seattle Net Tuesday, SeattleWineGal, SmartCup, Social Media Club Seattle, [[Superantispyware|SuperAntiSpyware]], [[Swedish Medical Center]], [[Ustream.tv|UStream.TV]], Washington Technology Industry Association, [[WeatherBug]], [[Yelp, Inc.|Yelp]] and Zing Bars.
The tenth Gnomedex conference had a similar schedule to previous Gnomedexes held at the Bell Harbor Conference Center, starting with registration and then a social mixer for attendees to meet.
Speakers:
* [[Brian Solis]] presenting the opening keynote on community<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0BnqZSigYhQ |title=Brian Solis on Community at Gnomedex |publisher=YouTube |date=2010-08-27 |accessdate=2011-09-17}}</ref> * Trish Millines Dziko from the Technology Access Foundation on providing computer literacy skills to minorities * Charles Brennick of [[InterConnection.org|InterConnection]] on reusing and recycling computers * Austin Heap, creator of the [[Haystack (software)|Haystack]] software<ref>{{cite web|author=lockergnome |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V6b5ND2js_8 |title=Austin Heap – Gnomedex 2010 |publisher=YouTube |date=2010-08-24 |accessdate=2011-09-17}}</ref> * Tom Nugent * Todd Welch * Willow Brugh<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ustream.tv/recorded/9047234 |title=Willow Brugh (Bl00), Gnomedex 10, Willow Brugh is a transhumanist, a traceuse, and an organic chat client. She believes all systems are malleable, and shou |publisher=Ustream.tv |date= |accessdate=2011-09-17}}</ref> * Johnny Diggz * Rob Knop * Bill Schrier * Amy Karlson * Shauna Causey and Melody Biringer * Larry Wu * [[Scott Draves|Scott "Spot" Draves]] of Digital Sheep<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=05JwkO4SOo4 |title=Electric Sheep Frolic With Spot Draves at Gnomedex |publisher=YouTube |date=2010-08-25 |accessdate=2011-09-17}}</ref> * Scott and Alex Mueller of Moosicorn Ranch<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moosicorn.com |title=Moosicorn, an experiment in sustainable living |publisher=Moosicorn.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-17}}</ref> * [[Melissa Pierce]] * [[Violet Blue]] on sexuality<ref>{{cite web|author=lockergnome |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yir60vz4Z7U |title=Violet Blue Turns Sexuality Social at Gnomedex |publisher=YouTube |date=2010-08-26 |accessdate=2011-09-17}}</ref> * Jason Barger * Steven Fisher and Michael Dougherty * [[Tim Hwang]] * [[Matt Inman]] of [[The Oatmeal]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://chris.pirillo.com/the-ultimate-oatmeal-recipe |title=The [Ultimate] Oatmeal Recipe ~ Chris Pirillo |publisher=Chris.pirillo.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-17}}</ref> * Seattle Wine Gal on Wine Tasting How-To's * OmniTechNews * Joe Pirillo and Judy Pirillo on 10 Years of Gnomedex
Organizers indicate that the 2010 Gnomedex will likely be the last.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/gnomedex/status/20530202794 |title=Twitter / Gnomedex Conference: Very sad to hear @penmachi |publisher=Twitter.com |date=2010-08-06 |accessdate=2011-09-17}}</ref>
=== 2011 === Gnomedex 2011 was held on November 2, 2011 in [[Seattle]], Washington at the Washington State Convention Center and held in conjunction with [http://www.seattleinteractive.com Seattle Interactive Conference] 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.seattleinteractive.com/2011/gnomedex |title=sic2011/Gnomedex 2011|accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref>
Speakers:
* Marcus Barnes-Cannon from the University of Washington discussed the [[PROTECT IP Act]]. * Libby Tucker discussed how technology could be used to reduce the size of the [[Great Pacific Garbage Patch]] (a/k/a "Plastic Island") * Shawn Ahmed of the Uncultured Project discussed global poverty and shared his own experiences providing aid in [[Bangladesh]] in the aftermath of Hurricane Sidr. * Michael Haley, Ph.D spoke on designing systems to function as desired. * Chris Burgess of Atigeo discussed cyberbullying in a talk title Unintended Consequences <ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=STm9vTqR1Ps Unintended Consequences]</ref> * Pascal Schuback of [[CrisisCommons]] discussed how technology and open data could be used in crisis management and humanitarian aid to provide realtime data. * Kent Nichols of AskANinja explained how to find an audience for online video series * Microsoft's Robotics division gave a demo of Roborazzi, a camera-toting robot for taking pictures at social events.
Chris Pirillo said he was thinking about holding another Gnomedex in 2012 as a standalone event.
