revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=February 2018}}{{redirect|Seol|the surname|Seol (surname)}} {{For|other traditions of celebrating lunar new year|Lunar New Year}} {{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = Korean New Year |type = Asian |image = Korea 2013 Seollal 11.jpg |imagesize = 250px |caption = People wearing ''[[hanbok]]'' and playing ''[[yut]]''. |nickname = ''Seollal'' |observedby = [[Korean people]] around the world |date=Typically the second [[new moon]] after the [[winter solstice]] |date2017= January 28 |date2018= February 16 |date2019 = February 5 |date2020 = January 25 |frequency=Annual |longtype = [[Korean culture|Cultural]] |significance = First day of the [[Korean calendar]] |relatedto = [[Chinese New Year]], [[Japanese New Year]], [[Tsagaan Sar|Mongolian New Year]], [[Losar|Tibetan New Year]], [[Tết|Vietnamese New Year]] }}
'''Korean New Year''' ({{ko-hhrm|hangul=설날|rr=Seollal|mr=Sŏllal}}) is the first day of the [[Korean calendar|Korean lunar calendar]]. It is one of the most important traditional Korean holidays.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xsR3BgAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Encyclopedia of Korean Seasonal Customs|last=|first=|publisher=The National Folk Museum of Korea (South Korea)|year=2014|isbn=8992128924|location=|pages=30-46}}</ref><ref name="EncyKorea" /> The celebration usually lasts three days: the day before Korean New Year, Korean New Year itself, and the day after Korean New Year. During this time, many Koreans visit family, perform [[Jesa|ancestral rites]], wear ''[[hanbok]]'' ([[Hangul]]: 한복; [[Hanja]]: 韓服), eat traditional food, and play folk games. Additionally, children often receive money from their elders after performing a formal [[Bowing|bow]].<ref name="visitkorea.or.kr" />
Korean New Year generally occurs in January or February on the second [[new moon]] after the [[winter solstice]], unless there is a [[Intercalation (timekeeping)|intercalary]] eleventh or twelfth month in the lead-up to the New Year. In such a case, the New Year falls on the third new moon after the solstice.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ujTfCwAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Encyclopedia of New Year’s Holidays Worldwide|last=Crump|first=William D.|publisher=McFarland|year=2014|isbn=1476607486|location=|pages=134-135}}</ref> Korean New Year typically falls on the same day as [[Chinese New Year]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YtvMDQAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The Statesman's Yearbook 2015: The Politics, Cultures and Economies of the World|last=|first=|publisher=Springer|year=2016|isbn=1349672785|editor-last=Turner|editor-first=Barry|location=|pages=756}}</ref>
== Names == While Korean New Year is generally referred to as ''Seollal'', it has been called by many other names.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://terms.naver.com/entry.nhn?docId=3573736&cid=58840&categoryId=58856|title=설날|last=|first=|date=2012-01-20|work=Korea Cultural Heritage Foundation|access-date=2018-03-30|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=ko|trans-title=Korean New Year}}</ref> They are listed in the table below.<ref name=":0" /> {| class="wikitable" style="width:50%;" !Literal translation ![[Hangul]] ![[Hanja]] ![[Revised Romanization of Korean|RR]] ![[McCune–Reischauer|MR]] |- |The first day |원일 |元日 |''Wonil'' |''Wŏnil'' |- | rowspan="2" |The first morning |원단 |元旦 |''Wondan'' |''Wŏndan'' |- |원조 |元朝 |''Wonjo'' |''Wŏnjo'' |- |The first month |원정 |元正 |''Wonjeong'' |''Wŏnjŏng'' |- |The first new |원신 |元新 |''Wonsin'' |''Wŏnshin'' |- |The morning of the first month |정조 |正朝 |''Jeongjo'' |''Chŏngjo'' |- | rowspan="3" |The head of the year |세수 |歲首 |''Sesu'' |''Sesu'' |- |연두 |年頭 |''Yeondu'' |''Yŏndu'' |- |연수 |年首 |''Yeonsu'' |''Yŏnsu'' |- | rowspan="2" |The beginning of the year |세초 |歲初 |''Secho'' |''Sech'o'' |- |연시 |年始 |''Yeonsi'' |''Yŏnshi'' |}
== Origins == The earliest references to Korean New Year are believed to be found in the 3rd century Chinese historical work, ''[[Records of the Three Kingdoms]], Book of Wei, Volume 30.''<ref name="EncyKorea" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://zh.wikisource.org/wiki/%E4%B8%89%E5%9C%8B%E5%BF%97/%E5%8D%B730|title=三國志/卷30|last=|first=|date=|website=Wikisource|language=zh|trans-title=Book of Wei, Volume 30|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-30}}</ref> Records of 7th century Korean New Year celebrations are included in the Chinese historical works, the ''[[Book of Sui]]'' and the ''[[Old Book of Tang]]''.<ref name="EncyKorea">{{cite web|url=http://encykorea.aks.ac.kr/Contents/Index?contents_id=E0028997|title=|last=Kim|first=Myeong-ja|date=2010|work=Encyclopedia of Korean Culture|publisher=Academy of Korean Studies|language=Korean|script-title=ko:설|trans-title=Lunar New Year|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=2018-03-30}}</ref> By the 13th century, Korean New Year was one of the nine major Korean festivals that included ancestral rites, according to the Korean historical work, the ''[[Goryeosa]]''.<ref name=":0" />
== Customs == [[File:Hanbok (한복) (4261102177).jpg|thumb|246x246px|'''Hanbok''']] Korean New Year is typically a family holiday.<ref name="visitkorea.or.kr">{{cite web|url=http://english.visitkorea.or.kr/enu/ATR/SI_EN_3_6.jsp?cid=941952|title=Celebrating Seollal in Korea: Glimpse of Local New Year’s Customs|last=|first=|date=2018-02-02|website=Visit Korea|publisher=Korea Tourism Organization|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-30}}</ref> The three-day holiday is used by many to return to their hometowns to visit their parents and other relatives, where they perform an ancestral ritual called ''[[charye]]''. The three days are the day of, the day before, and the after.<ref name="visitkorea.or.kr"/> In 2016, 36 million South Koreans reportedly would be traveling to visit their families during the Korean New Year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bi.galegroup.com/essentials/article/GALE%7CA442021001/d10a7c8299881284e692c10fe613c675|title=Redirect Page|publisher=}}</ref> Koreans not only travel within the country, but around the world, as well. Many Koreans travel from overseas to visit their families for this annual holiday. Since it is one of the few times families may be able to get together and catch up on one another's lives, it is considered respectful and important to attend the holiday. Often, the family members first visit the elders, and this includes the grandparents and the parents. It is also considered respectful for people to visit their mothers- and fathers-in-law during the Korean New Year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/culture/2013/08/135_130229.html|title=Daughters-in-law vs. mothers-in-law|date=8 February 2013|publisher=}}</ref>
Including travel expense, preparation for this holiday is very costly. Gifts are usually given to family members and new clothes are worn during the holiday. Traditional food is prepared for many family members coming to visit for the holiday. Fruits are especially expensive. Due to the increased demand, food prices are inflated during the month of Seollal. As a result, some people have chosen to forgo some traditions because they have become too expensive. These families prepare a modest ancestral rite only with necessary foods for Seollal. The government has started taking certain measures to help stabilize and support ordinary people's livelihood for Seollal holiday period. They have raised the supply of agricultural, fishery, and livestock products. The government used the rice reserves and pork imports to lower inflation. The government is also putting money into small and medium-sized companies to help with cash flow.
Many preparations go into celebrating the Korean New Year. During the first morning, Koreans pay their respect towards their ancestors. Traditional foods are placed on a table as an offering to the ancestors, and a rite begins with deep bows from all family members. This is a sign of respect and a very important practice on the first day of the New Year in Korea. It is also where they pray for the well-being of all the family members.<ref name="visitkorea.or.kr"/> Many Koreans dress up in colorful traditional Korean clothing called ''[[hanbok]]''. Hanbok are usually worn for special occasions such as weddings, Korean New Year, child's first birthday, etc.<ref name="visitkorea.or.kr"/> However, with modernization and evolving mores in the culture, more people tend to prefer westernized, modern clothing to the hanbok. After the rite, the members have a big feast.
Additionally, Koreans follow a zodiac similar to the Chinese zodiac. Twelve (12) animals represent the 12 years in sequential order with the rat/mouse representing the first year. Buddha is believed to have invited animals from all over the world to visit, to which only 12 visited. In return, he honored them by naming the years in the order that they arrived.<ref name="theseoultimes.com">{{cite web|url=http://theseoultimes.com/ST/?url=/ST/db/read.php?idx=12639&PHPSESSID=57bceeea8a5a2fafc46566ff1f589a56|title=The Seoul Times|publisher=}}</ref> Koreans believe that specific zodiac animals bring specific resources and qualities. For example, the year 2014 was the year of the horse, and it was considered a good year in the money and career aspect of life. It is said that a person born in a specific zodiacal year will carry that zodiac animal's characteristics. As a result, Koreans plan their year and activities around it to have a good, prosperous year. Parents may have even planned the birth year of their child, so the child may have a specific characteristic. It is fair to say that the Korean zodiac is an important part of Korea's culture.<ref name="theseoultimes.com"/>
Another custom observed is the lighting of a "moon house" built from burnable firewood and branches. This symbolizes the warding off of bad/evil spirits for the new year. Many also choose to add wishes they want come true in the next year to the moon house.
== Sebae == [[File:Korean Tradition Bow.jpg|thumb|Korean traditional bow]] Sebae (세배, 歲拜, ''worship elders'') is a ritual of filial piety that is traditionally observed on Seollal. Dressed in [[Hanbok|traditional clothing]], children wish their elders (grandparents, parents and aunts and uncles) a happy new year by performing a deep traditional bow (rites with more than one bow involved are usually for the deceased) and the words ''saehae bok mani badeuseyo'' ([[Hangul]]: 새해 복 많이 받으세요), or "Please receive a lot of good fortune for the New Year". Elders typically reward this gesture by giving children new year's money, or "pocket money" (usually in the form of crisp paper money) in silk bags made with beautiful traditional designs, as well as offering words of wisdom (dŏkdam). Historically, parents gave out rice cakes ''([[ddeok]])'' and fruit to their children.
== New Year food ==
=== Tteokguk === {{main article|Tteokguk}} ''Tteokguk'' (soup with sliced rice cakes) is a traditional Korean food that is customarily eaten for the New Year. According to [[Korean age reckoning]], the Korean New Year is similar to a birthday for Koreans, and eating ''tteokguk'' is part of the birthday celebration. Once you finish eating your ''tteokguk'', you are one year older.
On Korean New Year day, people prepare a lot of food and spend much of the day with family.
=== Jeon === {{Main article|Jeon (food)}} ''Jeon'', sometimes called ''buchimgae'', is a traditional Korean dish especially eaten on the Korean New Year's Day. A savory pancake, one would expect it to be sliced with a knife. However, the ''jeon'' is ripped apart with chopsticks in the belief of making it taste better.
== Folk games == {{see also|Traditional games of Korea}} Many traditional games are associated with the Korean New Year. The traditional family board game ''[[yut|yutnori]]'' remains a popular game, especially during Korean New Year. It is played using a set of specially designed sticks and is considered appropriate for all ages and genders. Men and boys traditionally would also fly rectangle [[kite]]s called ''Yeon'' ([[Hangul]]: 연, see ''[[yeonnalligi]]''), and also play ''[[jegichagi]]'', a game in which a light object is wrapped in paper or cloth, and then kicked in a [[footbag]] like manner. Korean women and girls would have traditionally played ''[[neolttwigi]]'', a game of jumping on a seesaw ([[Hangul]]: 시소), and ''[[gongginori]]'', a game played with five little ''[[gonggi]]'' (originally a little stone, but today many buy manufactured ''gongi'' in toy shops>). Top (''paengi'' (([[Hangul]]: 팽이) in Korean) spinning is also a traditional game played by children. Recently, a few adults play [[Go-Stop]] instead of traditional [[hwatu]].
==See also== *[[Korean calendar|Korean Calendar]] *Celebrations of Lunar New Year in other parts of Asia: ** [[Chinese New Year]] ''(Spring Festival)'' ** [[Japanese New Year]] ''(Shōgatsu)'' ** [[Tsagaan Sar|Mongolian New Year]] ''(Tsagaan Sar)'' ** [[Losar|Tibetan New Year]] ''(Losar)'' ** [[Tết|Vietnamese New Year]] ''(Tết)'' *Similar Asian Lunisolar New Year celebrations that occur in April: **[[Thingyan|Burmese New Year]] ''(Thingyan)'' **[[Cambodian New Year]] ''(Chaul Chnam Thmey)'' **[[Songkran (Lao)|Lao New Year]] ''(Pii Mai)'' **[[Sinhalese New Year|Sri Lankan New Year]] ''(Aluth Avuruddu)'' **[[Songkran (Thailand)|Thai New Year]] ''(Songkran)''
== References == {{Reflist}}

revision.comment: Robot - Moving category Freighters to [[:Category:Cargo ships]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories_for_discussion/Log/2017_December_24]].
revision.text:
The '''Kısmetim-1 incident''' occurred on December 15, 1992 when members of the [[Turkish Police|Turkish Narcotic Police]] on [[Turkish Navy]] vessels supported by US officials intercepted the MV ''Kısmetim-1'', a Turkish ocean freighter in [[Mediterranean]] international waters. The ship was suspected of being involved in smuggling about {{convert|3100|kg|lb|abbr=on}} [[morphine|morphine base]] into [[Turkey]]. The crew scuttled the ship during the operation.<ref name="tg1">{{cite web |url=http://www.tumgazeteler.com/?a=1345912 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717113237/http://www.tumgazeteler.com/?a=1345912 |title=''Kısmetim 1'' Davasında Yeni Karar |archivedate=July 17, 2011 |accessdate=January 18, 2009 |language=Turkish }}</ref>
MV ''Kısmetim-1'' was owned by [[Osman Ayanoğlu]]. The morphine base on the ship, worth millions of dollars, belonged to a consortium of himself and his partners including [[Şeyhmus Daş]] and [[Hüseyin Baybaşin]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/2425825.stm |publisher=BBC News |title=Keeping tabs on the Turkish connection |date=November 14, 2002 |accessdate=January 24, 2009 }}</ref> all Turkish [[drug lord]]s.<ref name="aks">{{cite journal|url=http://www.aksiyon.com.tr/detay.php?id=10021 |publisher=Aksiyon |title=Nejat Daş Olayının Perde Arkası |author=Akyol, Fuat |date=January 5, 2004 |accessdate=January 18, 2009 |language=Turkish |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070223171051/http://www.aksiyon.com.tr/detay.php?id=10021 |archivedate=February 23, 2007 }}</ref>
== Voyage ==
MV ''Kısmetim-1'' departed on October 7, 1991 from the Port of Yarımca in [[İzmit]], [[Turkey]], carrying dyestuff to [[Karachi]], [[Pakistan]]. As the ship docked at the destination port, Celal Kambur, the ship's purser started a conversation with the port policeman Yousuf Chacha. The Pakistani policeman asked the Turkish crew member to deliver a package to [[Ajman]], a port in the [[United Arab Emirates]] (UAE). The package contained {{convert|10|kg|lb|abbr=on}} [[heroin]] at a price of US$1.00 per gram.<ref name="sab">{{cite news |url=http://arsiv.sabah.com.tr/2001/01/13/g07.html |publisher=Sabah |title=Yükümüzü Atom Sanıyordum |author=Fıratlı, Nurhan |date=January 13, 2001 |language=Turkish |accessdate=January 18, 2009 }}</ref>
Soon after leaving the [[Port of Karachi]], the captain received a radio message saying that the ship's owner Osman Ayanoğlu was ambushed and murdered. On the way to [[United Arab Emirates#Ports and harbours|Port of Ajman]] before dawn, the captain ordered to pickup goods from a motorboat on high sea, which docked the ship. More than 100 sacks were pulled up into the ship in the darkness. The captain told the crew that the sacks contained [[nuclear material]] for the [[Mechanical and Chemical Industry Corporation (Turkey)|MKE]]<ref name="sab" />
The ship arrived in Ajman to unload fertilizer. Celal Kambur met the Pakistani drug dealer and received the money in a restaurant. The delivery of the drug package took place at 23:00 local time the same day by throwing to a boat, which pulled alongside the ship.<ref name="sab" />
The next morning, police raid the ship and found the money of US$10,000 from the drug trade on Celal Kambur. He was tried and found guilty for the drug crime. The ship moored at the port for six months during the trial and was only allowed to leave as the trial ended, and Celal Kambur was put into prison.<ref name="sab" />
Celal Kambur served his heavy prison sentence and was pardoned after nine years by the emir of Ajman, one of the seven emirates of the UAE federation.<ref name="sab" />
== Operation ==
Since its departure from Karachi, the ship was under close surveillance by the United States [[Drug Enforcement Administration|DEA]], which was forwarding all the relevant information to the Turkish Police. The incident in Ajman was very disappointing for the US and Turkish law enforcement services since they feared the main smuggle would have been revealed.
Finally, the ship passed through the [[Suez Canal]] and sailed into the Mediterranean Sea. Three Turkish Navy warships, the frigate [[List of major surface ships of the Turkish Navy#Yavuz class|TCG ''Yıldırım'' (F 243)]], the destroyer [[TCG Savaştepe (D 348)|TCG ''Savaştepe'' (D 348)]], the submarine rescue ship [[TCG Akın (A 585)|TCG ''Akın'' (A 585)]] and the US destroyer [[USS Briscoe (DD-977)|USS ''Briscoe'' (DD-977)]] carrying Turkish and US narcotic policemen as well as maritime patrol aircraft of type [[P-3 Orion]] deployed from [[Sicily]] intercepted the ship<ref name="esh">{{cite news|url=http://www.ensonhaber.com/comment_view.php?id=178261&type=1 |publisher=EnSonHaber |title=ETÖ'nün uluslararası eroin işi.. |author=Nayır, Cemil Nabi |date=January 9, 2009 |accessdate=February 1, 2009 |language=Turkish |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090117031059/http://www.ensonhaber.com/comment_view.php?id=178261&type=1 |archivedate=January 17, 2009 }}</ref> in high sea before she tried to escape to [[Cyprus]], a country, which Turkey has no good international relations with. Following the four days lasting joint operation, the ship went down with all its load, the nine crew were rescued.<ref name="mil" />
The US and Turkish officials claimed that the crew deliberately sank the ship in order to prevent the capture of the drug load. The ship's crew denied this allegation before the court declaring that the ship sank due to rough sea.<ref name="mil" />
The operation was led on site by [[Necdet Menzir]], director of Istanbul Police Department and [[Mestan Şener]], head of the narcotics bureau. [[Mehmet Ağar]], director general of the Turkish Police and [[Ismet Sezgin]], minister of interior, were in command of the operation.<ref name="esh"/>
== Aftermath ==
Şeyhmus Daş was shot to death on December 25, 1992 in Istanbul in his car when he was on the way to a wedding ceremony along with his wife and two daughters. The killing occurred ten days after the Kısmetim-1 incident and two weeks before the [[Lucky-S incident]], another drug smuggling operation on the sea.<ref name="mil">{{cite web |url=http://www.milliyet.com.tr/2002/06/20/guncel/agun.html |archiveurl=http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:nDDLnZ7tLVcJ:www.milliyet.com.tr/2002/06/20/guncel/agun.html+lucky+s&hl=tr&ct=clnk&cd=1&gl=tr |title=''Lucky-S''’in Sırları Daş’la Mezara Girdi |archivedate=December 9, 2008 |accessdate=January 18, 2009 |language=Turkish }}</ref>
[[Nejat Daş]], son of Şeyhmus Daş, who had carried out the drug trade negotiations in Karachi on behalf of his father, was tried at the 2nd State Security Court (DGM) in [[Istanbul]] and found guilty of [[drug trafficking]]. He was charged with 5 years and 10 months of heavy prison sentence. He escaped the prison on November 8, 1994, as he was brought from [[Sinop Fortress Prison]] to the 1st DGM in Istanbul for trial due to his involvement in the [[Lucky-S incident]].<ref name="tg1" />
== In popular culture== Turkish TV series [[Valley of the Wolves]] use this incident.
== See also ==
* [[Lucky-S incident]]
== References == {{reflist|2}}

page.title: List of Olympic medalists in art competitions

revision.text:
[[File:Baron Pierre de Coubertin.jpg|thumb|alt=Photograph of Pierre de Coubertin|Under the pseudonyms Georges Hohrod and Martin Eschbach, [[International Olympic Committee|IOC]] founder [[Pierre de Coubertin]] won a gold medal in the literature category at the [[Art competitions at the 1912 Summer Olympics|1912 Summer Olympics]].]] There were '''146 medalists''' in [[Art competitions at the Summer Olympics|the art competitions]] that were part of the [[Olympic Games]] from [[1912 Summer Olympics|1912]] until [[1948 Summer Olympics|1948]]. These art competitions were considered an integral part of the movement by [[International Olympic Committee]] (IOC) founder [[Pierre de Coubertin]] and necessary to recapture the complete essence of the [[Ancient Olympic Games]]. Their absence before the [[1912 Summer Olympics]], according to journalism professor Richard Stanton, stems from Coubertin "not wanting to fragment the focus of his new and fragile movement".{{cite book|last = Stanton|first = Richard|title = The Forgotten Olympic Art Competitions|publisher = [[Trafford Publishing]]|edition = 1st|date = 2000|location = [[Victoria, British Columbia|Victoria]]|page = 3|isbn = 1552126064}} Art competitions were originally planned for inclusion in the [[1908 Summer Olympics]] but were delayed after that edition's change in venue from Rome to London following the 1906 eruption of [[Mount Vesuvius]].Stanton, p. 18. By the [[1924 Summer Olympics]] they had grown to be considered internationally relevant and potentially "a milestone in advancing public awareness of art as a whole".Stanton, p. 69. During their first three appearances, the art competitions were grouped into five broad categories: architecture, literature, music, painting, and sculpture. The Dutch Organizing Committee for the [[1928 Summer Olympics]] split these into subcategories in the hopes of increasing participation.Stanton, p. 95. Although it was a successful strategy, the [[1932 Summer Olympics]] eliminated several of these subcategories, which led to fewer entries in the broader categories.Stanton, p. 146. For the [[1936 Summer Olympics]], the German government proposed the addition of a film contest to the program, which was rejected.Stanton, p. 158. Following a final appearance at the [[1948 Summer Olympics]], art competitions were removed from the Olympic program. Planners of the [[1952 Summer Olympics]] opposed their inclusion on logistical grounds, claiming that the lack of an international association for the event meant that the entire onus of facilitation was placed on the local organizing committee.Stanton, p. 210. Concerns were also raised about the professionalism of the event, since only amateurs were allowed to participate in the sporting tournaments,Stanton, p. 211. and the growing commercialization of the competitions, as artists had been permitted to sell their submissions during the course of the Games since 1928. In 1952 an art festival and exhibition was held concurrent with the Games, a tradition that has been maintained in all subsequent Summer [[Olympic games|Olympics]].Stanton, p. 213. The IOC does not track medalists in Olympic art competitions in its database and thus the prize winners are only officially recorded in the original Olympic reports. Judges were not required to distribute first, second, and third place awards for every category, and thus certain events lack medalists in these placements. Since participants were allowed multiple submissions, it was also possible for artists to win more than one in a single event, as [[Alex Diggelmann]] of Switzerland did in the graphic arts category of the 1948 edition.{{cite journal|title = The Official Report of the Organising Committee for the XIV Olympiad London 1948|page = 536|publisher = The Organising Committee for the XIV Olympiad|location = [[London]]|date = 1951|url = http://library.la84.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1948/OR1948part2.pdf|format = PDF|accessdate = 2012-03-06}} Diggelmann is tied with Denmark's [[Josef Petersen]], who won second prize three times in literature, for the amount of medals captured in the art competitions. Luxembourg's [[Jean Jacoby]] is the only individual to win two gold medals, doing so in painting in 1924 and 1928. Of the 146 medalists, 11 were women and only Finnish author [[Aale Tynni]] was awarded gold. Germany was the most successful nation, with eight gold, seven silver, and nine bronze medals,{{cite web|last = Gjerde|first = Arild|author2 = Jeroen Heijmans|author3 = Bill Mallon|author4 = Hilary Evans|title = Art Competitions|work = Olympics|publisher = Sports Reference.com|year = 2011|url = https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/sports/ART/|accessdate = 2012-03-07|archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/66VSjSXMP?url=http://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/sports/ART/|archivedate = 2012-03-28|deadurl = no|df = }} although one was won by Coubertin himself, a Frenchman. He submitted his poem ''Ode to Sport'' under the pseudonyms Georges Hohrod and Martin Eschbach, as if it were a joint-entry, and won first prize in the 1912 literature category. The original report credits this medal to Germany.{{cite web|last = Gjerde|first = Arild|author2 = Jeroen Heijmans|author3 = Bill Mallon|author4 = Hilary Evans|title = Pierre, Baron de Coubertin Biography and Olympic Results|work = Olympics|publisher = Sports Reference.com|year = 2011|url = https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/de/pierre-baron-de-coubertin-1.html|accessdate = 2012-03-07|archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/66VT2aWgB?url=http://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/de/pierre-baron-de-coubertin-1.html|archivedate = 2012-03-28|deadurl = no|df = }} Two individuals, [[Walter W. Winans]]{{cite web|last = Gjerde|first = Arild|author2 = Jeroen Heijmans|author3 = Bill Mallon|author4 = Hilary Evans|title = Walter Winans Biography and Olympic Results|work = Olympics|publisher = Sports Reference.com|year = 2011|url = https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/wi/walter-winans-1.html|accessdate = 2012-03-08|archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/66VT5TLLP?url=http://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/wi/walter-winans-1.html|archivedate = 2012-03-28|deadurl = no|df = }} and [[Alfréd Hajós]], won medals in both athletic and art competitions.{{cite web|last = Gjerde|first = Arild|author2 = Jeroen Heijmans|author3 = Bill Mallon|author4 = Hilary Evans|title = Alfréd Hajós Biography and Olympic Results|work = Olympics|publisher = Sports Reference.com|year = 2011|url = https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/ha/alfred-hajos-1.html|accessdate = 2012-03-08|archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/66VTAaxrD?url=http://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/ha/alfred-hajos-1.html|archivedate = 2012-03-28|deadurl = no|df = }} == Architecture == === Mixed architecture === [[File:Hajos.jpg|thumb|175px|alt=Photograph of Alfréd Hajós|[[Alfréd Hajós]] was one of two individuals to win medals in sport and art competitions.]] {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |+Olympic medalists in mixed architecture ! scope="col" style="width:105px;" |Games ! scope="col" style="background-color:gold; width:180px;" |Gold ! scope="col" style="background-color:silver; width:180px;" |Silver ! scope="col" style="background-color:#cc9966; width:180px;" |Bronze |- ! scope="row" |[[1912 Summer Olympics|1912 Stockholm]] |{{flagIOCathlete|{{Hs|Monod}}[[Eugène-Edouard Monod]] & [[Alphonse Laverrière]]|SUI|1912 Summer}}

page.title: List of armed groups in the Libyan Civil War

revision.text:
A number of armed groups have involved themselves in the ongoing [[Libyan Civil War (2014–present)|Libyan Civil War]]. ==Second Libyan Civil War (2014–present)== {|class="wikitable" |- !{{flagdeco|Libya}} [[House of Representatives (Libya)|House of Representatives]] and allies
{{flagdeco|Libya|1977}} [[Gaddafi loyalism after the 2011 Libyan Civil War|Gaddafi loyalists]]!!{{flagdeco|Libya}} [[Presidential Council (Libya)|Presidential Council]] and allies!!{{flagdeco |Libya}} [[General National Congress]] and allies!!{{flag|Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant}}
{{flagicon image|Flag of Jihad.svg}} [[Al-Qaeda]], other [[Salafi jihadism|Salafist jihadists]], and allies |- |valign=top|{{flagdeco|Libya}} '''[[Second Al-Thani Cabinet|Libyan Interim Government]]''' (Tobruk-based){{cite news|title=Rival Libyan factions sign UN-backed peace deal|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/12/libya-rival-parliaments-sign-backed-deal-151217131709056.html|accessdate=17 December 2015|work=Al Jazeera|date=17 December 2015}}{{cite news|title=Libya's rival factions sign UN peace deal, despite resistance|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20151217/world/libyan-factions-meet-to-sign-un-peace-deal.596042|accessdate=17 РІА Новини, 16.02.2015 *{{flagdeco|Egypt|Air Force}} [[Egyptian Air Force]] {{flag|United Arab Emirates}} (limited involvement) *{{flagicon image|UAE Armed Forces Coat of Arms.svg}} [[Armed Forces of the UAE|Union Defence Force]] '''Supported by''': *{{flag|Algeria}}{{cite web|url=http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/libyas-haftar-pledges-take-imminent-control-benghazi-and-tripoli-1615448321|title=Libya's Haftar pledges to take imminent control of Benghazi and Tripoli|publisher=}} *{{flag|France}} (until 2016){{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-36843186|title=Libya attack: French soldiers die in helicopter crash - [https://www.nytimes.com/2016/02/22/world/africa/us-scrambles-to-contain-growing-isis-threat-in-libya.html?_r=1 "US Scrambles To Contain Growing ISIS Threat in Libya"]. New York Times. 21 February 2016. "The American airstrikes in northwestern Libya on Friday, which demolished an Islamic State training camp and were aimed at a top Tunisian operative, underscore the problem, Western officials said. The more than three dozen suspected Islamic State fighters killed in the bombing were recruited from Tunisia and other African countries".{{cite web|url=http://www.libyanexpress.com/us-abandons-long-time-cia-asset-khalifa-haftar-brands-him-as-spoiler/|title=US abandons long-time CIA asset Khalifa Haftar, brands him as spoiler|publisher=Libyan Express|date=18 August 2016}} *{{flag|United Kingdom}} (until 2016){{cite news|title=British Deployment to Libya|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3383459/SAS-spearhead-operation-involving-1-000-British-troops-wrest-control-dozen-oil-fields-seized-ISIS-Libya.html|accessdate=5 January 2016}} *{{flag|Jordan}} (until 2016){{cite web|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2015/04/13/Jordan-pledges-support-for-Libya-in-talks-with-General-Haftar.html|title=Jordan pledges support {{legend|#ebc0b3|Under the control of the [[House of Representatives (Libya)|Tobruk-led Government]] and [[Libyan National Army]]}}{{legend|#cae7c4|Under the control of the [[Government of National Accord]] and [[Libya Shield Force|Allies]]}}{{legend|#86c286|Under the control of the [[General National Congress (2014)#National Salvation Government|National Salvation Government]]}}{{legend|#e4e4e4|Controlled by the Mujahedeen Councils of [[Shura Council of Mujahideen in Derna|Derna]], [[Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries|Benghazi]] and Adjabiya}}{{legend|#afc6e9|Controlled by local forces}}{{legend|#e3d975|Controlled by [[Tuareg militias of Ghat|Tuareg]] forces}}]] ===Notes=== *The [[Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries]] are fighting on the part of the GNA at the [[Gulf of Sidra Offensive (2017)]]. *Parts of the [[Gaddafi loyalism after the 2011 Libyan Civil War|Gaddafi loyalists]] are allied with the [[Libyan National Army]].{{cite web|url=http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/libya-why-gadhafi-loyalists-are-back-2138316983|title=Libya: Why the Gaddafi loyalists are back|publisher=}} *The [[Libya Shield 1]] is a part of the [[Libya Shield Force]]. ==See also== *[[List of armed groups in the Syrian Civil War]] *[[List of armed groups in the Iraqi Civil War]] *[[List of armed groups in the Yemeni Civil War]] *[[List of armed groups in the Syrian Civil War spillover in Lebanon]] *[[Combatants of the Iraq War]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Armed groups in the Libyan Civil War}} [[Category:Aftermath of the Libyan Civil War (2011)]] [[Category:Libya-related lists]] [[Category:Libyan Civil War (2014–present)]] [[Category:Military history of Libya]]

The '''London Victory Parade of 1815''' was a British [[victory parade]] held after the defeat of [[Napoleon]] in the [[Napoleonic Wars]] and his [[exile]] to [[Elba]]. The parade took place on 20 June {{dubious|date=January 2013}} 1815 at [[Hyde Park, London|Hyde Park]] in [[London]].
Over 15,000 troops attended the parade, most of them British. Other groups in attendance included [[Cossacks]], [[Highlanders (Seaforth, Gordons and Camerons)|Highlanders]] (who were an independent regiment at the time), and other small continental contingents.<ref>{{cite book |last=Ure |first= John |title= The Cossacks: An Illustrated History |year= 2002 |publisher= The Overlook Press, Peter Mayer Publishers, Inc |location= Woodstock, NY |isbn=1-58567-138-X}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Napoleonic Wars]]
==References== <references/>

Added a citation needed tag to help backup the claims about the ceremonies
revision.text:
[[Image:Malanggan-Masken Berlin-Dahlem.jpg|thumb|Malagan masks from the [[Ethnological Museum of Berlin]]]]
'''Malagan''' (also spelled '''malangan''' or '''malanggan''') ceremonies are large, intricate traditional cultural events that take place in parts of [[New Ireland Province|New Ireland]] province in [[Papua New Guinea]]. The word '''malagan''' refers to wooden carvings prepared for ceremonies and to an entire system of traditional culture. ==Malagan ceremonies==
''Malagan'' [[ceremonies]] are the most large-scale and famous of the many events that take place within the ''malagan'' culture. They take place irregularly, and are typically large and complex events, taking several days, and requiring months or years of preparation. {{Citation needed|reason=Needs sources to back up claims|date=December 2018}}
While a ''malagan'' ceremony is always held in the name of one or more people who have died in recent years, it is not at all merely a mortuary rite. Many other interactions take place within the overall event, including announcements, repayment of debts, recognition of obligations, resolution of disputes, and many other customary activities.
==Malagan carvings and carvers== [[Image:Malagan carvings.jpg|thumb|Malagan carvings]]
''Malagan'' [[Wood carving|carvings]], now world-famous, are the wooden carvings which are created for use in ''malagan'' ceremonies. Traditionally these were burnt or placed in a cave to rot at the conclusion of the event; in modern times most are now retained, as the carving tradition is now only known by a few. Contemporary masters of ''malagan'' form include Michael Homerang of Madina Village, Ben Sisia of Libba Village (northern New Ireland) and Edward and Mathew Salle of Lava Village (Tatau, Tabar Islands, New Ireland). Many ''malagan'' carvings are held in European and other [[museum]]s.
==Malagan culture==
''Malagan'' culture is the general term for the traditional culture in the area where ''malagan'' ceremonies take place, covering much of Northern New Ireland province. There are many other ceremonies and customary practices within this large and complex cultural system.
The word ''malagan'' comes from the [[Nalik language]] of northern [[New Ireland (island)|New Ireland]]. Alternative spellings include ''malangan'' and ''malanggan''.
==See also== *[[List of festivals in Papua New Guinea]] *[[List of folk festivals]] ==References== {{No footnotes|date=April 2009}} *{{cite book | last = Lincoln | first = Louise |author2=Tibor Bodrogi |author3=Dieter Heintze |author4=Michael Gunn | title = Assemblage of Spirits | publisher = George Braziller | date = 1987 | location = New York | pages = 13–55, 63–83 | isbn = 0-8076-1188-3 }} *{{cite book | last = Gunn | first = Michael | title = Ritual Arts of Oceania: New Ireland | publisher = Skira editore | date = 1997 | location = Milan | pages = 37–63 | isbn = 88-8118-207-6 }} *{{cite book | last = Gunn | first = Michael |author2=Phillipe Peltier | title = New Ireland: Art of the South Pacific | publisher = Continents Editions | date = 2006 | location = Milan | pages = | isbn = 88-7439-369-5 }}
==External links== {{commons category|Malanggan}} *[http://www.alcheringa-gallery.com Alcheringa Gallery] - Canadian gallery representing some malagan carvers
{{Culture of Oceania|state=autocollapse}}
[[Category:Death customs]] [[Category:Festivals in Papua New Guinea]] [[Category:Folk festivals]] [[Category:Masquerade ceremonies]] [[Category:Masks in Oceania]]
{{tradition-stub}}

{{About|meetings in general|meetings in organizations that use parliamentary procedure|Meeting (parliamentary procedure)}} {{for|multi-event athletic competitions|Track and field#Meetings}} [[Image:Conference table.jpg|thumb|upright=1.25|Meetings are sometimes held around [[conference room|conference]] [[Furniture#Table|table]]s.]]
A '''meeting''' is when two or more [[Homo sapiens|people]] come together to discuss one or more topics, often in a formal or business setting, but meetings also occur in a variety of other environments. Many various types of meetings exist.
== Definition == [[File:2screensystem.jpg|thumb|A modern [[videoconferencing]] system]]
A meeting is a gathering of two or more people that has been convened for the purpose of achieving a common goal through verbal interaction, such as sharing information or reaching agreement.<ref name="pi"/> Meetings may occur face-to-face or virtually, as mediated by communications technology, such as a [[conference call|telephone conference call]], a [[Skype|skyped conference call]] or a [[videoconferencing|videoconference]]. One Merriam-Webster dictionary defines a meeting as "an act or process of coming together" - for example "as [...] an assembly for a common purpose [...]".<ref name="pu">[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/meeting Meeting – Definition and More from the Free Merriam-Webster Dictionary]. (n.d.). Dictionary and Thesaurus – Merriam-Webster Online. Retrieved 2016-02-04.</ref>
[[Meeting planner]]s and other meeting [[professional]]s may use the term "meeting" to denote an event booked at a hotel, [[convention center]] or any other venue dedicated to such gatherings.<ref name="pi">[http://www.bls.gov/oco/ocos298.htm Meeting and Convention Planners]. (2009, December 17). [[U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics]]. Retrieved April 21, 2010.</ref><ref> {{cite book | last1 = Montgomery | first1 = Rhonda J. | last2 = Strick | first2 = Sandra K. | title = Meetings, Conventions, and Expositions: An Introduction to the Industry | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=bgWRbYjTLVsC | location = New York | publisher = [[John Wiley & Sons|Wiley]] | publication-date = 1994 | isbn = 9780471284390 | accessdate = 2016-02-04 }} </ref>
== Types of meetings == [[Image:Conferenceroom2.JPG|thumb|Meetings sometimes take place in [[conference room]]s]] [[File:President Reagan holds a oval office staff meeting 1981.jpg|thumb|First staff meeting of a new executive]] [[File:Training meeting in a ecodesign stainless steel company in brazil.JPG|thumb|Training meeting about [[sustainable design]]. The photo shows a training meeting with factory workers in a [[stainless-steel]] [[ecodesign]] company in [[Rio de Janeiro]], [[Brazil]].]]
The term "meeting" may refer to a [[lecture]] (one presentation), [[seminar]] (typically several presentations, small audience, one day), [[conference]] (mid-size, one or more days), [[congress]] (large, several days), [[trade fair|exhibition or trade show]] (with manned stands being visited by passers-by), [[Academic conference|workshop]] (smaller, with active participants), training [[course (education)|course]], [[team-building session]] and [[Kickoff meeting|kick-off event]].
Common types of meeting include: * [[Committee#Procedures|Committee meeting]], a coming-together of a defined subset of an organization * Investigative meeting, generally when conducting a pre-interview, exit interview or a meeting among the investigator and representative * [[Kickoff meeting]], the first meeting with a [[project]] team and the client of the project to discuss the role of each team-member<ref>{{cite book | last=Sullivant | first=J. | title=Strategies for Protecting National Critical Infrastructure Assets: A Focus on Problem-Solving | publisher=Wiley | year=2007 | isbn=978-0-470-22836-4 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0_6t1nRPDi4C&pg=PA89 | access-date=October 1, 2018 | page=89}}</ref> * [[Town hall meeting]], an informal public gathering. * Work meeting, which produces a product or intangible result such as a decision{{citation needed|date= July 2016}}; compare [[working group]]. :* [[Board of directors|Board]] meeting, a meeting of the [[board of directors]] of an organization :* Management meeting, a meeting among [[manager]]s :* Staff meeting, typically a meeting between a manager and those that report to that manager :* [[Team meeting]], in project contexts - a meeting among colleagues working on various aspects of a [[team]] project.
Other varieties include breakfast meetings<ref>{{cite book | last=Chaney | first=L.H. | last2=Martin | first2=J.S. | title=The Essential Guide to Business Etiquette | publisher=[[Praeger Publishing|Praeger]] | year=2007 | isbn=978-0-275-99714-4 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3xIFsS1IVGUC&pg=PA114 | access-date=October 1, 2018 | page=114}}</ref> off-site meetings (or [[Awayday]] meetings in the UK), and "stand-up meetings" where participants stand up to encourage brevity.
Since a meeting can be held once or often, the meeting organizer has to determine the repetition and frequency of occurrence of the meeting: one-time， recurring meeting， or a series meeting such as a monthly "lunch and learn" event at a company, church, club or organization in which the placeholder is the same, but the agenda and topics to be covered vary.{{cn|date=November 2018}} In Russian, a "flying meeting" ({{lang-ru | летучий митинг | translit = letuchij miting }}) is a hastily-called brief meeting.<ref> {{cite book | last1 = Mokiyenko | first1 = Valeri | last2 = Nikitina | first2 = Tatjana | chapter = митинг | title = Толковый словарь языка Совдепии | trans-title = Explanatory dictionary of the language of the Sovdepia | url = https://sovdep.academic.ru/1972/%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B3 | language = ru | location = Saint Petersburg | publisher = Фолио-Пресс | publication-date = 1998 | isbn = 5-7627-0103-4 | access-date = 2018-09-21 | quote = Летучий митинг[:] Экстренно собранный непродолжительный митинг. }} </ref>
==See also== {{portal|Business|Social science}} {{columns-list|colwidth=22em| * [[Action item]] * [[Agenda (meeting)|Agenda]] ** [[Online diary planner]] * [[BarCamp]] * [[Conference room]] * [[Event management]] * [[Facilitation (business)]] * [[International Congress Calendar]] * [[Meeting point]] * [[Meeting scheduling tool]] * [[Minutes]] * [[Official trip]] * [[Organizational development]] * [[Parliamentary procedure]] * [[Quaker]] [[meeting for worship]] * [[Robert's Rules of Order]] * [[Scientific meeting]] * [[Town meeting]] * [[Task list]] * [[Unconference]] }}
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== {{Wiktionary}} {{Commons category|Meetings}} * {{cite journal | last=Olson | first=Gary M. | last2=Olson | first2=Judith S. | last3=Carter | first3=Mark R. | title=Small group design meetings: an analysis of collaboration | journal=Human-Computer Interaction | volume=7 | issue=4 | issn=0737-0024 | doi=10.1207/s15327051hci0704_1 | pages=347–374 | url=https://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=1461843 | access-date=October 1, 2018}} * {{cite web | last=Johansen | first=Robert | last2=Vallee | first2=Jacques | last3=Spangler | first3=Kathleen | title=Electronic Meetings: Technical Alternatives | website=ACM Digital Library | url=https://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=578546 | access-date=October 1, 2018}} * {{cite book | title=Effective Meetings at Work | publisher=[[Taylor & Francis]] | year=2007 | isbn=978-1-136-40844-1 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jasrBgAAQBAJ | access-date=October 1, 2018}} 112 pages.
{{Authority control}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2018}} {{infobox event | title = | image =Cathy Cesnik.jpg | image_name = | date = approx. November 7, 1969; body discovered January 3, 1970 | coordinates = | also known as = Sister Cathy murder | cause = [[Intracerebral hemorrhage]] caused by [[skull fracture]] | outcome =Under investigation by Baltimore City and County police | reported injuries = | reported death(s) = | burial = Saint Mary's Cemetery, [[Sharpsburg, Pennsylvania]] | inquest = | coroner = | suspects = | charges = | verdict = | convictions = | publication bans = | litigation = }}
'''Catherine Anne "Cathy" Cesnik''' {{post-nominals|post-noms=[[School Sisters of Notre Dame|SSND]]}} (born November 17, 1942; disappeared November 7, 1969) was a [[Roman Catholic Church|Catholic]] [[religious sister]] who taught English and drama at the formerly all-girls [[Archbishop Keough High School]] in [[Baltimore]], Maryland. On November 7, 1969, Cesnik disappeared.<ref name="huffingtonpost">{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/05/14/cesnik-nun-murder-maskell_n_7267532.html|title=Buried in Baltimore: The Mysterious Murder of a Nun Who Knew Too Much|last=Bassett|first=Laura|date=May 14, 2015|work=The Huffington Post|access-date=April 20, 2017|language=en-US}}</ref> Her body was discovered on January 3, 1970, near a garbage dump in the Baltimore suburb of [[Lansdowne, Maryland|Lansdowne]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Nawrozki |first1=Joe |last2=Erlandson |first2=Robert A. |date=June 19, 1994 |title=With New Lead, Police Reopen Old Murder Case |url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1994-06-19/news/1994170025_1_sister-catherine-catherine-ann-priest |newspaper=The Baltimore Sun |access-date=April 20, 2017}}</ref> Her murder remains unsolved. Cesnik's murder is the basis for the [[Netflix]] documentary web series ''[[The Keepers]]'' in 2017.
== Biography == Catherine Anne Cesnik was born on November 17, 1942, in the [[Pittsburgh]], Pennsylvania neighborhood of [[Lawrenceville (Pittsburgh)|Lawrenceville]], located in the city's east end. She was the eldest child of Joseph and Anna Omulac Cesnik (died 2015).<ref>{{cite news|last=O'Neill |first=Brian |date=May 13, 2017 |title=Justice for Sister Cathy is Long Overdue |url=http://www.post-gazette.com/opinion/brian-oneill/2017/05/14/Sister-Cathy-Catherine-Cesnik-murder-Baltimore-1969/stories/201705140086 |newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette |location=Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania |publisher=PG Publishing Co. |access-date=June 14, 2017}}</ref> Her paternal grandparents, John (Jan) and Johanna Tomec Česnik, were Slovenians who emigrated from [[Yugoslavia]] to Pittsburgh,<ref>Joseph Cesnik in 1930 Census; Census Place: Pittsburgh, Allegheny, Pennsylvania; 1930 United States Federal Census; National Archives and Records Administration.</ref> while her maternal grandfather, Joseph Omulac, came from Yugoslavia and maternal grandmother, Martha Hudok, was born in [[Austria]].<ref>Pennsylvania, Marriages, 1852–1968</ref> Cesnick had three siblings.
Cesnik attended St. Mary's School on 57th Street and St. Augustine High School, both in Lawrenceville. She was [[valedictorian]] of her [[Catholic school|Catholic high school]] class in 1960, where she had also been the [[May Queen]] and the president of the senior class and [[student council]].
== Disappearance and death == At the time she disappeared, Cesnik was teaching at [[Western High School (Baltimore)|Western High School]] in [[Baltimore]], Maryland.<ref name="baltimoresun2"/> On November 7, 1969, she left the apartment she shared with Sister Helen Russell Phillips at the Carriage House Apartments, at 131 North Bend Road in [[Catonsville, Maryland|Catonsville]], en route to the [[Edmondson, Baltimore|Edmondson Village Shopping Center]] to purchase a gift at [[Hecht's]] for her sister's engagement.<ref name="baltimoresun1">{{cite news |date=January 8, 1970 |title=Sister Catherine Cesnik Case: Missing Nun's Body Found in Lansdowne |url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/features/retro-baltimore/catherine-cesnik/bal-missing-nun-s-body-found-in-lansdowne-20170516-story.html |newspaper=The Baltimore Sun |access-date=June 14, 2017}}</ref> Records indicate Cesnik cashed a paycheck at [[FNB Corporation|First National Bank]] in Catonsville that night and possibly made a purchase at Muhly's Bakery in Edmondson Village, since a box of bakery buns was found in the front seat of Cesnik's car.<ref name="baltimoresun2">{{cite news |date=May 19, 2017 |title=Timeline: The Sister Catherine Cesnik Case|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/features/retro-baltimore/catherine-cesnik/bal-timeline-the-sister-catherine-cesnik-case-20170518-story.html |newspaper=The Baltimore Sun |accessdate=June 14, 2017}}</ref> The car, in muddy condition, was found illegally parked across from her apartment complex at 4:40 the next morning by Russell's friends, the priests Peter McKeon and Gerard J. Koob.<ref name="baltimoresun2"/> Residents of Carriage House Apartments spotted Cesnik in her car at approximately 8:30 that night, and others spotted her car at the illegally parked location across the street around two hours later.<ref name="baltimoresun2"/>
Police searched the area immediately following Cesnik's disappearance but did not find her. On January 3, 1970, her body was found by a hunter and his son, in an informal landfill located on the 2100 block of Monumental Road, in a remote area of [[Lansdowne, Maryland|Lansdowne]].<ref name="baltimoresun1"/> An [[autopsy]] performed by Deputy Medical Examiner [[Werner Spitz]] revealed that Cesnik died from an [[intracerebral hemorrhage]] following a fracture to her skull from a blow to her left temple by a blunt instrument.{{citation needed|date=July 2017}} The case remains unsolved .
==Background== During Cesnik's tenure at [[Seton Keough High School|Archbishop Keough High School]], it is alleged that two of the priests, Fathers [[Joseph Maskell]] and E. Neil Magnus, were [[Catholic sex abuse cases in the United States|sexually abusing the girls at the school]] in addition to [[sex trafficking|trafficking]] them to others.<ref>{{cite news |last=Koch |first=Denise |date=February 27, 2017 |title=Baltimore Priest Victim: Police Were in on Sexual Abuse |url=http://baltimore.cbslocal.com/2017/02/27/victim-of-notorious-baltimore-priest-says-police-were-in-on-sexual-abuse/ |work=CBS Baltimore |access-date=June 14, 2017}}</ref> In 1995, Teresa Lancaster and Jean Wehner (née Hargadon), former students at Keough who claim to have been sexually abused by Maskell, filed a lawsuit against the school which was dismissed under the [[statute of limitations]] (''Jane Doe et al. v. A. Joseph Maskell et al.''). Wehner said that Cesnik once came to her and said gently, "Are the priests hurting you?" Both women have said that she is the only one who helped them and other girls abused by Maskell, ''et al.'', and have said that she was murdered prior to discussing the matter with the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Baltimore|Archdiocese of Baltimore]], although there is no evidence for this assertion.<ref>{{cite news |last=Smith |first=Jennifer |date=April 20, 2017 |title=The Next Making a Murderer: Netflix Releases Trailer for True Crime Docu-series about Baltimore Nun's Unsolved 1969 Killing and How the Church 'Covered It Up' |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-4430080/Netflix-releases-trailer-new-crime-series-Killers.html |work=Mail Online |access-date=April 20, 2017}}{{Failed verification|date=February 2018}}</ref><ref name="huffingtonpost" />
There is currently no physical evidence linking Maskell to the crime. It was revealed in late 2016 that the Archdiocese had paid off numerous settlements to Maskell's alleged victims since 2011.<ref>{{cite news |last=Knezevich |first=Alison |date=November 15, 2016 |title=Baltimore Archdiocese Pays Settlements to a Dozen People Alleging Abuse by Late Priest |url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/maryland/baltimore-city/bs-md-maskell-settlements-20161115-story.html |newspaper=The Baltimore Sun |access-date=June 14, 2017}}</ref>
Wehner alleges that, two months before Cesnik's body was discovered, and only a day or two after Cesnik disappeared on November 7, Maskell drove her to a wooded site near [[Fort Meade, Maryland|Fort Meade]] and showed her the body. Wehner claims to remember trying repeatedly to brush off the [[maggot]]s crawling on Cesnik's face while frantically repeating the words, "Help me, help me." Wehner's account was brought into question by scientific evidence showing that it would have been impossible for maggots to be alive at the relevant time of year. However, pathologist [[Werner Spitz]], who worked on the case, later confirmed that there had been maggots in both the victim's mouth and trachea when found. Meteorological records also disclose that the temperature the week in question was high enough for maggots to hatch.{{citation needed|date=November 2018}} It is alleged that Maskell reportedly told Wehner, "You see what happens when you say bad things about people?"<ref name="huffingtonpost" />
Several days later, on November 13, the body of [[Murder of Joyce Malecki|Joyce Malecki]], a 20-year-old woman who looked like Wehner, was discovered by "two hunters" in the same wooded location where Maskell had driven Wehner to see Cesnik's body. Cesnik's body was not found until January 3, 1970, and its discovery by "two hunters" was not in the wooded location near Fort Meade but on the open hill trash dump of a small business property in Lansdowne.{{citation needed|date=February 2018}}
In 2016, the [[Baltimore County Police Department]] (BCPD) reassigned the case due to retiring officers, prompting new interviews and further investigation into the alleged sexual abuse at Keough.<ref>{{cite press release |year=2017 |title=About the BCoPD Cold Case Unit and the Sister Catherine Ann Cesnik Homicide |url=http://www.archbalt.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/sistercesnikreleasetimeline.pdf |format=PDF |publisher=Baltimore County Police Department |access-date=June 14, 2017 |via=Archdiocese of Baltimore}}</ref> After attaining permission from the [[State's attorney]]'s office, the BCPD exhumed the body of Maskell, who died of a major stroke in 2001, but did not find a DNA match to evidence from the crime scene.<ref name="baltimoresun3">{{cite news |last=Knezevich |first=Alison |date=May 17, 2017 |title=Police: Exhumed Priest's DNA Does Not Match Evidence from Crime Scene Killing of Sister Cathy |url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/maryland/bs-md-co-dna-maskell-20170517-story.html |newspaper=The Baltimore Sun |access-date=April 20, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Knezevich |first=Alison |date=May 4, 2017 |title=Priest's Body Exhumed from Randallstown Cemetery in Investigation of Baltimore Nun's Decades-Old Killing |url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/maryland/baltimore-county/bs-md-co-priest-exhumed-20170504-story.html |newspaper=The Baltimore Sun |access-date=June 14, 2017}}</ref> Police spokeswoman Elise Armacost announced that this discovery does not exclude Maskell from being a suspect in the case.<ref name="baltimoresun3" />
==In popular culture== [[Netflix]] produced a seven-part documentary series about the case called ''[[The Keepers]]'', which debuted on May 19, 2017.<ref>{{cite news |last=Liebman |first=Lisa |date=May 19, 2017 |title=The Dead Nun, the School Sex Scandal, and the Amateur Detectives Fighting for Justice |url=https://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2017/05/the-keepers-netflix-who-killed-sister-cathy-true-crime |work=Vanity Fair |access-date=December 24, 2017}}</ref> The series features interviews with women who were Cesnik's students, and with some of those who were sexually abused by Maskell and others.<ref>{{cite news |last=McDonell-Parry |first=Amelia |date=May 19, 2017 |title='The Keepers': Inside Netflix's Compelling New True-Crime Docuseries |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/tv/features/the-keepers-inside-compelling-new-true-crime-docuseries-w483230 |work=Rolling Stone |access-date=December 24, 2017}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Crime in Baltimore]] *[[Deaths in 1970]] *[[List of unsolved deaths]]

revision.text:
[[File:MIM-104 Patriot during the National Victory Celebration parade honoring the coalition forces of Desert Storm.JPEG|thumb|A MIM-104 Patriot tactical air defense missile system is towed by a heavy expanded mobility tactical truck in the National Victory Celebration.]] [[File:President Bush greets General H. Norman Schwarzkopf who leads the Desert Storm Homecoming Parade in Washington, D.C - NARA - 186434.jpg|thumb|President [[George H. W. Bush]] greeting [[Norman Schwarzkopf Jr.]] on the parade route.]] The '''National Victory Celebration''' was held in [[Washington, D.C.]], United States, on June 8, 1991, to celebrate the conclusion of [[Gulf War]]. It was the biggest [[military parade]] since [[World War II]]. 8,000 Desert Storm troops marched in the national parade. A small group of Vietnam veterans also took part in the parade. General [[Norman Schwarzkopf Jr.]], the commander of the Desert Storm forces, led the parade.{{sfn|Cohen|Gatti|1991|pp=312–313}} The parade, took place on [[Constitution Avenue]], [[Pennsylvania Avenue]] and across the [[Arlington Memorial Bridge|Memorial Bridge]]. The elaborate parade, which cost $12 million, was criticized by opponents because they claimed it to be militaristic.<ref>https://www.cbsnews.com/amp/news/how-cbs-news-reported-the-last-national-military-parade-in-1991/</ref><ref>https://www.upi.com/Archives/1991/06/09/Desert-Storm-Victory-Celebration/9997676440000/</ref><ref>http://articles.latimes.com/1991-06-09/news/mn-986_1_victory-celebration</ref><ref>https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1991/06/10/on-the-mall-the-celebration-lingers/89f330fe-462e-457f-b8c4-c8162d82c6d5/</ref>
The celebration helped to set a single day Metrorail record of 786,358 trips, breaking the record of 604,089 trips set during the [[Inauguration of George H. W. Bush]] set in 1989. The record would last until the [[First inauguration of Bill Clinton]] in 1993. It also set the weekend record which would last 17 years until it was broken by the [[Rally to Restore Sanity and/or Fear]].
==See also== * [[New York at War]], 1942 mobilization parade * [[New York City Victory Parade of 1946]] * [[Grand Review of the Armies]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|National Victory Celebration}} * [https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=7L1PVpet-XM Full Footage of the Parade]

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox motor race | Race title = Paris-Bordeaux-Paris | Logo = Monument à Levassor 1907.jpg | Track map = | Series long = | Series short = | Venue = Road from Paris to [[Bordeaux]]
(and return) | Location = France | Coordinates = | Sponsor = | First race = 11 June 1895 (unique race)
30 entrants
21 qualified
12 Stopped | First series race = | Last race = | Distance = {{convert|1178|km}} | Laps = | Duration = | Previous names = | Most wins driver = | Most wins rider = | Most wins team = | Most wins manufacturer = | Surface = | Length km = | Turns = | Record time = | Record driver = | Record car = | Record year = | Record class = }} The '''Paris–Bordeaux–Paris Trail''' of June 1895 is sometimes called the "first motor race" although it did not conform to modern convention whereby the fastest finisher is the winner. It was a triumph for [[Émile Levassor]] who arrived first after completing the 1,178 km race in 48 hours, nearly six hours ahead of the runner-up. However, the official winner was [[Koechlin family#Paul Koechlin|Paul Koechlin]], who arrived third in his Peugeot, exactly 11 hours slower than Levassor, but officially the race had been for four-seater cars, whereas Levassor and the runner-up drove two-seater cars. {{cite book | title = Car facts & feats | edition = 2nd | author = Anthony Harding | publisher = Sterling Pub. Co. | year = 1977 | isbn = 978-0-8069-0108-4 | page = 48 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=mBDymREIK5MC&q=%22Paris%E2%80%93Bordeaux%E2%80%93Paris+race%22+first&dq=%22Paris%E2%80%93Bordeaux%E2%80%93Paris+race%22+first&hl=en&ei=tMewTtPCO6j9iQL2g70R&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CEEQ6AEwAg }}{{cite news|title=Ces merveilleux fous roulants sur leurs drôles de machines|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/reportage/20070709.FIG000000143_ces_merveilleux_fous_roulants_sur_leurs_droles_de_machines.html|accessdate=30 September 2011|newspaper=Le Figaro|date=9 July 2007|language=French}}[http://www.teamdan.com/archive/gen/upto1903/1895.html TeamDan Early results database – 1895] ==First race== Paris–Bordeaux–Paris is sometimes called the first [[automobile]] race in history or the "first motor race". The 1894 [[Paris–Rouen (motor race)|Paris–Rouen]] had been run over public roads as a contest (''concours'') not a race, and the fastest finisher, a steam powered vehicle, was judged ineligible for the main prize. [[Émile Levassor]] finished first in the 1,178 km Paris–Bordeaux–Paris race, taking 48 hours and 48 minutes, nearly six hours before the runner-up [[Louis Rigoulot]], and eleven hours before the official winner, [[Koechlin family#Paul Koechlin|Paul Koechlin]] in his Peugeot. Officially, the race was for four-seater cars, and Levassor and Rigoulot drove two-seater cars. The ensuing outcry caused the ''A.C.F.'' to organise their next event, the [[1896 Paris–Marseille–Paris]], so that the fastest finisher was the winner. ==Name== The race is sometimes referred to as the ''I Grand Prix de l'A.C.F''. This results from a retrospective political move that began in the early 1920s when French media represented many races held in France before the 1906 French Grand Prix as being Grands Prix de l'Automobile Club de France, despite their running pre-dating the formation of the Club. Hence, the 1906 race was said to have been the 9th edition of the Grand Prix de l'Automobile Club de France. The ACF itself adopted this reasoning in 1933, although some members of the Club dismissed it, "concerned the name of the Club was lent to the fiction simply out of a childish desire to establish their Grand Prix as the oldest race in the world."Hodges (1967), pp. 2–3[http://www.teamdan.com/archive/gen/upto1903/1895.html 1895 Grand Prix and Paris Races]. Retrieved on 12 September 2009. ==Levassor's progress== Levassor, who drove one of his cars, a 1205 cc (74 ci) [[Panhard|Panhard & Levassor]], started carefully, observing his opponents; he overtook the then leading [[Marquis]] [[Albert de Dion|de Dion]] who stopped to take on water for his [[steam car]]. Levassor led the race since then, stopping regularly to check his car's components. He came to [[Bordeaux]] several hours before any driver was expected to come which resulted in the fact that he had to drive back to Paris as well (the driver who was his change was still asleep in a hotel, and no-one knew which one). Levassor accepted the situation calmly, waking the organisers up to prove his coming and his time, had some sandwiches and champagne, took a brief walk and set off for Paris at 2:30 am. When [[Baron]] [[René de Knyff]] met him en route, he was so surprised by Levassor's time that he nearly crashed. Levassor, after spending two days and nights behind the wheel, came triumphantly to Paris, reaching an average speed of 24.5 km/h. He said after the race: "Some 50 km before Paris I had a rather luxurious snack in a restaurant which helped me. But I feel a little tired."{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}} ==Legacy== The race proved that both the riders and the cars were capable of driving such distances and it generated public enthusiasm which indicated that such events were commercially viable.{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}} ==Results== ===Overall=== The overall results were: {| class="wikitable" |- ! Pos !! No !! Driver !! Car !! Time !! Notes |- | 1 || 5 || [[Émile Levassor]] || [[Panhard & Levassor]] || 48:48:00 || 24.54 km/h
