{{EngvarB|date=March 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} {{Infobox song | name = Rain | cover = Rain-Paperback Writer US aa sleeve.jpg | alt = | caption = US picture sleeve | type = single | artist = [[the Beatles]] | album = | A-side = [[Paperback Writer]] | released = 30 May 1966 | format = [[Gramophone record|7"]] | recorded = 14 and 16 April 1966
[[Abbey Road Studios|EMI Studios]], London | studio = | venue = | genre = [[Psychedelic rock]]http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/08/05/the-beatles-revolver-turns-50-a-psychedelic-masterpiece-that-rewrote-the-rules-of-rock | length = 2:59 | label = {{plainlist| * [[Parlophone]] * [[Capitol Records|Capitol]] }} | writer = [[Lennon–McCartney]] | producer = [[George Martin]] | chronology = [[The Beatles]] UK | prev_title = [[Day Tripper]] | prev_title2 = [[We Can Work It Out]] | prev_year = 1965 | title = [[Paperback Writer]] | title2 = Rain | next_title = [[Eleanor Rigby]] | next_title2 = [[Yellow Submarine (song)|Yellow Submarine]] | next_year = 1966 | misc = {{Extra chronology | artist = [[The Beatles]] US | type = single | prev_title = [[Nowhere Man (song)|Nowhere Man]] | prev_year = 1966 | title = "[[Paperback Writer]]" /
"Rain" | year = 1966 | next_title = [[Eleanor Rigby]]" / "[[Yellow Submarine (song)|Yellow Submarine]] | next_year = 1966 }} {{External music video|{{YouTube|cK5G8fPmWeA|"Rain"}}}} {{Extra music sample|Type=single|filename=Rain - The Beatles.ogg|title="Rain"}} }} "'''Rain'''" is a song by the English [[Rock music|rock]] band [[the Beatles]] that was first released in May 1966 as the [[A-side and B-side|B-side]] of their "[[Paperback Writer]]" single. Both songs were recorded during the sessions for the album ''[[Revolver (Beatles album)|Revolver]]'' although neither appears on that album. The song was written by [[John Lennon]] and credited to [[Lennon–McCartney]]. It is noted for its slowed-down rhythm track, an example of the tape-manipulation techniques the band embraced at this time, and backwards vocals over the song's coda. The single's release marked the first time that reversed sounds had appeared in a pop song, although the Beatles used the same technique on the ''Revolver'' track "[[Tomorrow Never Knows]]", released in August 1966.{{sfn|Reising|LeBlanc|2009|pp=94, 95}} Three promotional films were made for the song "Rain".{{sfn|Neaverson|2009}} ==Music and lyrics== The inspiration for "Rain" is agreed on by [[Neil Aspinall]], the Beatles' [[Road crew|roadie]], and John Lennon. They both described the band's arrival in [[Sydney]], Australia, marked by rain and poor weather.{{sfn|The Beatles|2000|p=140}} Lennon said, "I've never seen rain as hard as that, except in [[Tahiti]]", and later explained that "Rain" was "about people moaning about the weather all the time".{{sfn|The Beatles|2000|p=212}} Another interpretation is that the song's "rain" and "sun" are phenomena experienced during a benign LSD trip.{{sfn|Revolution in the Head - MacDonald 2005|p=196-7}} "Rain" has a simple musical structure. Set in the key of G major (the final mix pitches it about a quarter of a semitone below this, while the backing track was taped in G sharp), it begins with what [[Alan W. Pollack]] calls, "a ra-ta-tat half-measure's fanfare of solo [[snare drum]]s", followed by a guitar intro of the first chord. The verses are nine measures long, and the song is in {{music|time|4|4}} time. Each verse is based on the G, C, and D chords [[Chord progression#Three-chord progressions|(I, IV, and V)]]. The refrain contains only I and IV chords, and is twelve measures long (the repetition of a six-measure pattern). The first two measures are the G chord. The third and fourth measures are the C chord. The third measure has the C chord in the so-called [[Second inversion|{{su|p=6|b=4}} (second) inversion]]. The fifth and sixth measures return to the G chord. Pollack says the [[refrain]] seems slower than the verse, though it is at the same tempo, an illusion achieved by "the change of beat for the first four measures from its erstwhile bounce to something more plodding and regular". After four verses and two refrains, a short solo for guitar and drums is played, with complete silence for one beat. Following this, the music returns accompanied by what Pollack terms "historically significant" reverse lyrics.{{sfn|Pollack|1993}} Musicologist [[Walter Everett (musicologist)|Walter Everett]] cites this closing section as an example of how the Beatles pioneered the "fade-out–fade-in [[Coda (music)|coda]]", a device used again by them on "[[Strawberry Fields Forever]]" and "[[Helter Skelter (song)|Helter Skelter]]", and by Led Zeppelin on "[[Thank You (Led Zeppelin song)|Thank You]]".{{sfn|Everett|2009|p=154}} [[Allan Kozinn]] describes McCartney's [[Bass guitar|bass]] as "an ingenious counterpoint that takes him all over the fretboard ... while Lennon and McCartney harmonize in [[Perfect fourth|fourths]] on a melody with a slightly [[Middle East|Middle Eastern]] tinge, McCartney first points up the song's droning character by hammering on a high G (approached with a quick slide from the F natural just below it), playing it steadily on the beat for twenty successive beats."{{cite book |author=[[Allan Kozinn]] |title=The Beatles |year=1995 |location=London |publisher=Phaidon |pages=143}} ==Recording== Recording began on 14 April 1966, in the same session as "Paperback Writer", and concluded on 16 April, with a series of [[Overdubbing|overdubs]] before mixing on the same day.{{sfn|Lewisohn|1988|p=74}}{{sfn|Fontenot|2008}} At that time, the Beatles were enthusiastic about experimenting in the studio to achieve new sounds and effects.{{sfn|Lewisohn|1988|p=70}} These experiments were showcased in their seventh album, [[Revolver (Beatles album)|''Revolver'']]. [[Geoff Emerick]], who was the engineer for both sessions, described one technique he used to alter the sonic texture of the track by recording the backing track "faster than normal". When played back, slightly slower than the usual speed, "the music had a radically different tonal quality."{{sfn|Emerick|2006|p=117}} The opposite technique was used to alter the tone of Lennon's lead vocal: it was recorded with the tape machine slowed down, making Lennon's voice sound higher when played back.{{sfn|Lewisohn|1988|p=83}} The last verse of "Rain" includes backwards vocals, the first use of this technique on a record.{{sfn|Playboy Magazine|April, 1981|p=194}} (the hit [[novelty song]] "[[They're Coming to Take Me Away, Ha-Haaa!]] ", where side B is side A played backwards, was released later that year of 1966). The backwards vocals are Lennon singing the lyrics of the song: "When the sun shines", "Rain", and "If the rain comes, they run and hide their heads."{{sfn|YouTube: Rain Finale backwards|1995}} Both Lennon and producer [[George Martin]] claimed credit for the idea. Lennon said:
After we'd done the session on that particular song – it ended at about four or five in the morning – I went home with a tape to see what else you could do with it. And I was sort of very stoned and tired, you know, not knowing what I was doing, and I just happened to put it on my own tape recorder and it came out backwards. And I liked it better. So that's how it happened.{{sfn|The Beatles Interview Database|2007}}{{sfn|Gilliland|1969|loc=show 37, track 4}}
Emerick confirmed Lennon's creative accident, but Martin remembered it differently:
I was always playing around with tapes and I thought it might be fun to do something extra with John's voice. So I lifted a bit of his main vocal off the four-track, put it on another spool, turned it around and then slid it back and forth until it fitted. John was out at the time but when he came back he was amazed.{{sfn|Lewisohn|1988|p=74}}{{sfn|Emerick|2006|p=117}}
Later, in 1980, Lennon claimed:
I got home from the studio and I was stoned out of my mind on [[cannabis (drug)|marijuana]] and, as I usually do, I listened to what I'd recorded that day. Somehow I got it on backwards and I sat there, transfixed, with the earphones on, with a big hash joint. I ran in the next day and said, 'I know what to do with it, I know ... Listen to this!' So I made them all play it backwards. The fade is me actually singing backwards with the guitars going backwards. [Singing backwards] Sharethsmnowthsmeaness ... [Laughter] That one was the gift of God, of [[Jah]], actually, the god of marijuana, right? So Jah gave me that one.http://www.beatlesbible.com/songs/rain/
Regardless of who is credited for the technique, "from that point on," Emerick wrote, "almost every overdub we did on ''[[Revolver (Beatles album)|Revolver]]'' had to be tried backwards as well as forwards."{{cite web|title=88 – 'Rain'|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/100-greatest-beatles-songs-20110919/rain-19691231|work=100 Greatest Beatles Songs|publisher=Rolling Stone}} The "Paperback Writer" / "Rain" single was the first release to use a new device invented by the maintenance department at [[Abbey Road Studios|Abbey Road]] called "ATOC" for "Automatic Transient Overload Control". The new device allowed the record to be cut at a louder volume, louder than any other single up to that time.{{sfn|Emerick|2006|p=117}} On the final mix of the single, Lennon played a 1965 [[Gretsch|Gretsch Nashville]], [[Paul McCartney]] a 1964 [[Rickenbacker 4001S]] bass, Harrison a 1964 [[Gibson SG]], and [[Ringo Starr]] used [[Ludwig-Musser|Ludwig]] drums.{{sfn|MacDonald|2005|p=196}}{{sfn|Fontenot|2008}} ==Release and reception== First released as a B-side to "Paperback Writer" in the United States (Capitol 5651) on 30 May 1966 and in the UK on 10 June, the single was later released part of a [[Record Store Day]] reissue in 2010.[http://www.discogs.com/Beatles-Paperback-Writer-Rain/release/2335266 Beatles, The – Paperback Writer / Rain (Vinyl) at Discogs] It later appeared on the [[compilation album|compilations]] ''[[Hey Jude (album)|Hey Jude]]'' in the US and ''[[Rarities (1978 The Beatles album)|Rarities]]'' in the UK. It also appeared on the ''[[Past Masters]]'' CD.{{sfn|Fontenot|2008}} In the United States, the song peaked at number 23 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] on 9 July 1966,{{cite web|title=The Hot 100: July 9th 1966|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/hot-100/1966-07-09|publisher=[[Billboard (magazine)|billboard.com]]|accessdate=2 August 2017}} and remained in that position the following week.{{cite book|last1=Castleman|first1=Harry|last2=Podrazik|first2=Walter J.|title=All Together Now: The First Complete Beatles Discography 1961–1975|publisher=Ballantine Books|location=New York, NY|year=1976|isbn=0-345-25680-8|p=349}} The "Paperback Writer" single reached number 1 in the UK (for two weeks starting on 23 June).{{sfn|Fontenot|2008}} ''Rolling Stone'' magazine ranks "Rain" 463rd in its list of "[[Rolling Stone's 500 Greatest Songs of All Time|The 500 Greatest Songs of All Time]]".{{sfn|Rolling Stone|2004b}} On a similar list compiled by the New York radio station [[Q104.3]], the song appeared at number 382.{{cite web |url=http://www.q1043.com/common/top_songs/2012.html?page=2 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-02-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131214135622/http://www.q1043.com/common/top_songs/2012.html?page=2 |archivedate=14 December 2013 |df=dmy-all }} "Rain" is notable for [[Ringo Starr]]'s drumming, which Starr rates as his best recorded performance.{{sfn|Miles|1997|p=280}} Both [[Ian MacDonald]] and ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' described his drumming on the track as "superb",{{sfn|MacDonald|2005|p=198}}{{sfn|Rolling Stone|2004a}} while [[Richie Unterberger]] of [[AllMusic]] praised his "creative drum breaks".{{sfn|Unterberger|2007}} In 1984, Starr said: "I think it's the best out of all the records I've ever made. 'Rain' blows me away … I know me and I know my playing … and then there's 'Rain'."{{sfn|www.beatleswiki.com/wiki/index.php/Rain}} Music critic [[Jim DeRogatis]] describes it as "the Beatles' first great psychedelic rock song".{{sfn|DeRogatis|2003|p=43}} It has been noted for its slowed-down rhythm track and backwards vocals, anticipating the studio experimentation of "Tomorrow Never Knows" and other songs on ''Revolver'', which was released two months later.{{sfn|Lewisohn|1988|p=74}}{{sfn|MacDonald|2005|p=196}} ==Promotional films== The Beatles created three promotional films for "Rain"{{sfn|Neaverson|2009}} which are considered among the early precursors of music videos.{{sfn|BBC|2008}} These videos, along with other Beatles videos at the time, sparked [[George Harrison]] to say during the ''[[The Beatles Anthology (film)|Beatles Anthology]]'', "So I suppose, in a way, we invented [[MTV]]."{{sfn|The Beatles|2000|p=214}} The films were directed by [[Michael Lindsay-Hogg]] who worked with them earlier on the pop 1960 television programme ''[[Ready Steady Go!]]''{{sfn|Miles|1998}} One features the Beatles walking and singing in a garden and a [[greenhouse]] (filmed 20 May 1966 at [[Chiswick House]] in London).{{sfn|Neaverson|2009}}{{sfn|Ritchie|2008}} The other two feature the band performing on a [[sound stage]] (filmed 19 May 1966, one in colour for Ed Sullivan and the other in black and white for the UK).{{sfn|Neaverson|2009}}{{sfn|Anthology DVD|2003|loc=Episode 3, "Rain"}} McCartney was injured in a [[moped]] accident on 26 December 1965, six months prior to the filming of "Rain" and closeups in the film reveal a scarred lip and a chipped tooth.{{sfn|Miles|1998}}{{sfn|Anthology DVD|2003|loc=Episode 3, "Rain"}} McCartney's appearance in the film played a role in the "[[Paul is dead]]" rumours from 1969.{{sfn|Fontenot|2008}} ''The Beatles' Anthology'' documentary video includes a re-edit of two of these three clips, full of rhythmic fast cuts and several shots that went unused in the original videos.{{sfn|Unterberger|2006|p=320}} This creates an impression that the videos were more technically complex, fast-paced, and innovative than was the case. For example, the backwards film effects shown here are 1990s creations. Such effects were actually first deployed in the "Strawberry Fields Forever" promotional film of January 1967.{{sfn|Unterberger|2006|p=322}} ==Covers, samples, and media references== [[U2]] has played the song in whole or in part throughout many of their tours, usually during outdoor concerts when it has started to rain.{{sfn|U2gigs.com|2010}} [[Pearl Jam]] improvised the song into their song "[[Jeremy (song)|Jeremy]]" during their 1992 [[Pinkpop Festival]] show and played it in full at the [[Isle of Wight Festival]] in 2012.http://www.setlist.fm/setlist/pearl-jam/2012/seaclose-park-newport-england-53df1709.html [[Kula Shaker]] covered the song live at [[Reading Festival]] in 1996 as did [[Fairport Convention]], featuring [[Dan Ar Braz]], at the [[The Cropredy Box|Cropredy Festival]] in 1997. [[Todd Rundgren]] has also covered the song,{{sfn|Fontenot|2008}} as has the late [[Dan Fogelberg]], who reprised it as part of his own cover of "[[Rhythm of the Rain]]". The Grateful Dead played it twenty times throughout the early 1990s. The Beatles [[tribute act]] [[Rain: A Tribute to the Beatles|Rain]] derives its name from the song.Isherwood, Charles. [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/27/theater/reviews/27rain.html?_r=0 "Another Long and Winding Detour,"] ''New York Times'' (OCT. 26, 2010). In 2016 [[Aloe Blacc]] sings it as Boris the Frog in the eponymous [[Beat Bugs]] episode 3b. ==Personnel== *[[John Lennon]] – lead and backing vocals, rhythm guitar *[[Paul McCartney]] – backing vocals, bass *[[George Harrison]] – backing vocals, lead guitar *[[Ringo Starr]] – drums, [[tambourine]] :Personnel per [[Ian MacDonald]]{{sfn|MacDonald|2005|p=196}} ==Notes== {{Multiple issues|{{Orphan|date=September 2018}}{{notability|date=October 2018}}}} {{Infobox recurring event | name = Scottish International Airshow | status = Active | genre = [[Air show]] | dates = September | frequency = Yearly | venue = [[Ayr|Ayr Low Green]] | location = [[Ayr|Ayr, Scotland]] | country = {{SCO}} | established = 2014 | attendance = ~ 90,000 Public Visitors <ref>[https://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/in-your-area/airshow-aviation-ayrshire-red-arrows-13190618cx ]{{dead link|date=October 2018}}</ref> | activity = Trade Exhibition {{-}} Aerobatic Displays {{-}} Static Displays | organised = Scottish International Airshow | website = [https://www.tsia.scot/about-us/ Scottish International Airshow] }}
The '''Scottish International Airshow''' is an annual [[Air Show]] taking place at [[Ayr|Ayr, Scotland]]. Founded in 2014, the air show features a variety of different aircraft such as [[Biplane]]s, [[Fighter Jet]]s, [[Aerobatic aircraft]], [[Seaplane]]s, and much more.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tsia.scot/whats-on/|title=What's On - The Scottish International Airshow|publisher=}}</ref>
==Venue== TSIA (The Scottish International Airshow) is held at [[Ayr|Ayr Low Green]]. At the airshow, there are food stands, stalls, [[Funfair|Various Funfair Rides]], exhibitions from the [[British Armed Forces]] and [[British police]] such as [[British Army|The British Army]], [[Royal Air Force]] and the [[Royal Navy]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/special-features/arrows-target-ayr-show-what-13081138|title=Arrows target Ayr show in what promises to be biggest and best year yet|first=Lisa|last=Gray|date=14 August 2018|publisher=}}</ref>
==Operation== TSIA is created and hosted by the Scottish International Airshow. Inside of the air show area, it is patrolled by police and security guards. Typically, the order of the aircraft's are the [[RAF Typhoon|Typhoon]], older planes such as the [[Douglas DC3]] and [[Beech 18|The Beech 18's]]. Followed by the [[Seaplane]]s and then the [[F/A-18C|F18]] and the red arrows. In between these aircraft there are some smaller and older planes that fly in formation.<ref name="military-airshows.co.uk">{{cite web|url=http://www.military-airshows.co.uk/ven29.htm|title=Scottish Airshow 2018 Ayr Flying Display Schedule, Timetable, Weather Forecast, Tickets, Hotel Accommodation, East Fortune - Military Airshows in the UK|website=www.military-airshows.co.uk}}</ref>
==Aircraft== 2018 Airshow Aircraft
*Swiss Airforce [[F/A-18C]] supersonic jet display *Royal Navy [[Hawker Sea Fury]] *RAF Tutor Aircraft [[Grob G 115]] *[[Consolidated PBY Catalina]] Flying Boat *[[RAF Typhoon]] supersonic jet *The [[Red Arrows]] *[[RAF Lancaster bomber]], [[Spitfire]] and [[Hawker Hurricane]] *[[Cessna 172]] sea plane (does a water landing) *Formation of a [[Douglas DC3]] and three [[Beech 18|Beech 18's]] *[[AutoGyro Calidus]] *The Global Stars aerobatic team (4 [[Extra 300|Extra 300's]]) *[[Pitts S1]] aerobatic display *[[Scottish Aviation Bulldog]] & [[De Havilland Canada DHC-1 Chipmunk]] *[[Boeing-Stearman]] *[[De Havilland Dragonfly]] <ref name="military-airshows.co.uk"/>

[[UTV Motion Pictures#UTV Spotboy|UTV Spotboy]] | distributor = [[UTV Motion Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|df=yes|2012|09|06|Toronto|2013|10|18|India}} | runtime = 123 minutes | country = India | language = [[Hindi]] | budget = {{INRConvert|65|l}}{{cite news|url=https://www.news18.com/news/movies/i-cant-keep-messaging-people-id-rather-act-rajkummar-rao-1839309.html|title=Was Told Not to Wear Perfume at Night: Rajkummar Rao on Eerie Experience During Stree Shooting|last=Bengani|first=Sneha|publisher=CNN-News18|date=9 August 2018|accessdate=11 August 2018|archiveurl=https://www.news18.com/news/movies/i-cant-keep-messaging-people-id-rather-act-rajkummar-rao-1839309.html|archivedate=11 August 2018}} | gross = {{INRConvert|3.60|c}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/movie/shahid/box-office/|title=Shahid: Box office|publisher=Bollywood Hungama|accessdate=14 July 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180714085155/http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/movie/shahid/box-office/|archivedate=14 July 2018|df=dmy-all}} }} '''''Shahid''''' is a 2013 Indian Hindi language [[Biographical film|biographical]] [[Drama (film and television)|drama]] film directed by [[Hansal Mehta]]. Jointly produced by [[Anurag Kashyap]], [[UTV Motion Pictures#UTV Spotboy|UTV Spotboy]] and Sunil Bohra, it is based on the life of lawyer and human rights activist [[Shahid Azmi]] who was assassinated in 2010. The film stars [[Rajkummar Rao]] in the titular role; [[Mohammed Zeeshan Ayyub]], [[Prabhleen Sandhu]] and [[Baljinder Kaur]] appear in supporting roles. Mehta took a break after some of his films were box-office failures. When he heard about Azmi's murder, he felt the need to make a film about his life. He began his research for the film nearly three months after Azmi's murder. Mehta met writer Sameer Gautam Singh, who wrote the screenplay after researching Azmi's life and spending months interviewing Azmi's family. [[Apurva Asrani]] did additional work on the screenplay with Mehta. Asrani also served as the film's editor. Anuj Dhawan was the director of photography. ''Shahid'' had its world premiere at the [[2012 Toronto International Film Festival]]'s City to City programme in 2012. It was screened at several other film festivals including the 14th [[Mumbai Academy of the Moving Image#Film Festival|Mumbai Film Festival]], the [[New York Indian Film Festival]], the Indian Film Festival Stuttgart, the [[Dubai International Film Festival]] and the Chicago South Asian Film Festival. The film was awarded the Silver Gateway Trophy at the Mumbai film festival while Mehta won the Best Director award. Mehta also won the best director award at New York Indian Film Festival and at the Indian Film Festival of Stuttgart. The film was released theatrically in India on 18 October 2013 and met with critical acclaim. Rao received the [[National Film Award for Best Actor|Best Actor Award]] and Mehta the [[National Film Award for Best Director|Best Director Award]] at the [[61st National Film Awards]] ceremony. ==Plot== Shahid Azmi and his family are terrorised during the [[Bombay riots]], when hundreds of Muslims died. Later he goes to [[Kashmir]] and spends a brief period at a militant training camp but soon returns after witnessing an execution. He moves back to Mumbai where he is arrested under the [[Terrorist and Disruptive Activities (Prevention) Act]], for an alleged conspiracy to assassinate some politicians. His brother Arif Azmi tries to [[bail]] him out but fails. Shahid is tortured by police and forced to admit to the crime, after which he spends seven years at [[Tihar Jail]] in New Delhi. During his incarceration Omar Sheikh ([[Prabal Panjabi]]) tries to [[Mind control|brainwash]] him. Another inmate, Ghulam Navi Waar, inspires him to begin his college education, and once he is acquitted of the charges, he studies law in Mumbai. After receiving his law degree, Shahid works with lawyer Maqbool Memon for a few months, before starting his career as an independent lawyer with the financial support of his elder brother Arif. During this process he meets Mariam, a Muslim divorcee, and marries her. Shahid soon starts picking up cases of Muslims charged under the [[Prevention of Terrorism Act, 2002|Prevention of Terrorism Act]] (POTA). He fights many cases [[pro bono]] in consultation with [[non-governmental organization]]s. Shahid's first major success as a defence lawyer is winning an acquittal, due to lack of evidence, for Arif Paanwala who was arrested under POTA for the [[2002 Mumbai bus bombing]]. Shahid represents the accused in the [[2006 Mumbai train bombings]], the 2006 Aurangabad arms haul, and the [[2006 Malegaon bombings]] case. He is criticised for supporting terrorists and starts getting threatening calls that disturb his family life. On one occasion, Shahid's face is blackened by assailants outside the court room. While defending [[Faheem Ansari]] in the [[2008 Mumbai attacks]] case, he is shot by two gunmen in his office and dies on the spot. Later, Ansari is shown to be acquitted of all charges by the Supreme Court of India due to lack of evidence. ==Cast== * [[Rajkummar Rao]] as [[Shahid Azmi]] * [[Mohammed Zeeshan Ayyub]] as Arif Azmi * [[Tigmanshu Dhulia]] as Maqbool Memon * [[Kay Kay Menon]] as Ghulam Navi Waar * [[Prabal Panjabi]] as Omar Sheikh * [[Prabhleen Sandhu]] as Mariam * Vivek Ghamande as Faheem Khan * [[Baljinder Kaur]] as Ammi ==Production== {{quote box|width=30%|align=right|quote="I was very mesmerised by this young lad who had taken on the system on his own. He was killed at 32, but there was so much he had achieved before that. I knew there was a story to tell there."|source=Mehta on the film.}} ===Development=== Director [[Hansal Mehta]] said that he needed a break after some of his films proved to be a box-office failures, like ''[[Woodstock Villa]]'' (2007) and ''[[Raakh (2010 film)|Raakh]]'' (2010).{{cite news|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/indiarealtime/2013/10/06/qa-hansal-mehta-on-his-new-film-shahid/|title=Q&A: Hansal Mehta on His New Film ‘Shahid’|last=Pereira|first=Priyanka|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=6 October 2013|accessdate=14 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180614171404/https://blogs.wsj.com/indiarealtime/2013/10/06/qa-hansal-mehta-on-his-new-film-shahid/|archivedate=14 June 2018|df=dmy-all}} On 11 February 2010, lawyer [[Shahid Azmi]] was shot dead in his office in Mumbai at the age of 32.{{cite news |title=26/11 accused Fahim Ansari's lawyer Shahid Azmi shot dead|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2010-02-11/india/28127692_1_fahim-ansari-assailants-shahid-azmi|work=The Times of India|date=11 February 2010}} He had represented those accused of the 2006 Mumbai local train blasts, the 2006 Malegaon blasts case and while he was defending Faheem Ansari in the 26/11 attacks case that he was killed.{{cite news|title=The lawyer who courted death|url=http://www.livemint.com/Leisure/ryxborlNOcg3cP0Bh7GSDM/The-lawyer-who-courted-death.html?facet=print|work=Mint|date=13 September 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130925174602/http://www.livemint.com/Leisure/ryxborlNOcg3cP0Bh7GSDM/The-lawyer-who-courted-death.html?facet=print|archivedate=25 September 2013|df=dmy-all}} He was arrested during the communal riots of 1992-1993 in Mumbai and later studied law and began defending people arrested on false charges.{{cite news|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/bollywood/hansal-mehta-a-street-should-be-named-after-shahid/|title=Hansal Mehta: A street should be named after ‘Shahid’|work=The Indian Express|date=16 October 2013|accessdate=14 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180614172310/https://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/bollywood/hansal-mehta-a-street-should-be-named-after-shahid/|archivedate=14 June 2018|df=dmy-all}} The lawyer secured 17 acquittals in his seven-year career.{{cite news|title=Film remembers Indian lawyer Shahid Azmi as symbol of hope|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-19595663|accessdate=15 May 2013|publisher=BBC|date=28 September 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121126083611/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-19595663|archivedate=26 November 2012|df=dmy-all}} Mehta said that when he heard about Azmi's murder, he had a sense that the tale of his life could pull his "creativity out of the rut". He felt that Azmi lived an "ordinary life, with extraordinary conviction to do what he believed was right" and that his story "had to be told". Mehta began his research nearly three months after Azmi's murder.{{cite news|url=https://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/i-owe-everything-to-my-lack-of-success-hansal-mehta-113101500531_1.html|title=I owe everything to my lack of success: Hansal Mehta|work=Business Standard|date=15 October 2013|accessdate=14 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180614171454/https://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/i-owe-everything-to-my-lack-of-success-hansal-mehta-113101500531_1.html|archivedate=14 June 2018|df=dmy-all}} He later met writer Sameer Gautam Singh, who approached Mehta with a script. Mehta said he could not make a film with the script and asked him if he was would co-write another script with him. Singh agreed, and Mehta sent him along with his son Jai Mehta to Azmi's hometown to meet his family. To gather facts they interviewed his family members and friends for two months.{{cite news|url=https://www.livemint.com/Leisure/ryxborlNOcg3cP0Bh7GSDM/The-lawyer-who-courted-death.html|title=The lawyer who courted death|last=Janardhan|first=Arun|work=Mint|date=13 September 2012|accessdate=14 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180614144254/https://www.livemint.com/Leisure/ryxborlNOcg3cP0Bh7GSDM/The-lawyer-who-courted-death.html|archivedate=14 June 2018|df=dmy-all}} Mehta chose not to go with them as he feared that seeing a filmmaker family and friends would "alter the version of Shahid's life they narrated". Both Mehta and Singh read several of Azmi's cases for the story.{{cite news|url=https://www.indiatoday.in/movies/bollywood/story/interview-hansal-mehta-shahid-214032-2013-10-11|title=For me, Shahid is Gandhi: Hansal Mehta|last=Singh|first=Suhani|work=India Today|date=11 October 2013|accessdate=14 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180614144232/https://www.indiatoday.in/movies/bollywood/story/interview-hansal-mehta-shahid-214032-2013-10-11|archivedate=14 June 2018|df=dmy-all}} Mehta noticed that they were written in simple English that could be understood by anyone: "It told me he was a no-nonsense guy. He wanted to fight the battle and not beat around the bush." Mehta and Singh also met his colleagues, attended court sessions, petitions, litigations and learned how to get a client acquitted. Mehta went to seek permission to make the film; family members expressed their skepticism about the project. Later, they agreed and talked to him about Azmi. The film focused on Azmi's beginnings and two cases he handled: the [[2006 Mumbai train bombings]] and the [[2008 Mumbai attacks]]. Mehta combined several of Azmi's petitions into a single case for "clarity and dramatic impact". Mehta said the Azmi's family was supportive of the film. ===Casting and filming=== Mehta was looking for "big stars" for the film, but most were not interested because of his earlier failures. At the time, the film's co-producer [[Anurag Kashyap]] suggested he cast [[Rajkummar Rao]] thinking he was perfect for the role of Azmi. Later, casting director [[Mukesh Chhabra]] sent Rao to Mehta's office. Mehta cast him after a screen test. Mehta felt Rao "surrendered himself completely" to the film. In preparing for the role, Rao met Azmi's family and spent time with them to understand the man and his personality. He also studied the [[Quran]] and attended courtrooms to understand how lawyers behave. Rao said he was "emotionally drained" as the character was challenging and complex. In the scenes where he had to cry, Rao said he could not stop himself, thinking about what Azmi had to go through. [[Tigmanshu Dhulia]], [[Prabhleen Sandhu]], [[Kay Kay Menon]] and [[Mohammed Zeeshan Ayyub]] played supporting roles in the film.{{cite news|url=http://archive.indianexpress.com/news/raanjhanaa-actor-zeeshan-ayyub-looking-forward-to-the-release-of-shahid/1141642/|title=Raanjhanaa actor Zeeshan Ayyub looking forward to the release of Shahid|work=The Indian Express|date=14 July 2013|accessdate=14 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180714085155/http://archive.indianexpress.com/news/raanjhanaa-actor-zeeshan-ayyub-looking-forward-to-the-release-of-shahid/1141642/|archivedate=14 July 2018|df=dmy-all}} The scene where Azmi's face is blackened by assailants outside a courtroom was a re-enactment of an incident from Mehta's own life. In 2000, members of [[Shiv Sena]] who were protesting his film ''[[Dil Pe Mat Le Yaar!!]]'' attacked him and vandalised his office. ''Shahid'' was made on a production budget of {{INRConvert|86|l}} and filmed in complete secrecy.{{cite news|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/bollywood/superstars-do-not-guarantee-success-raj-kumar/|title=Superstars do not guarantee success: Raj Kumar|work=The Indian Express|date=26 October 2013|accessdate=14 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180614172345/https://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/bollywood/superstars-do-not-guarantee-success-raj-kumar/|archivedate=14 June 2018|df=dmy-all}} It was shot in several [[Mumbai]] neighbourhoods Azmi had frequented including [[Kurla]], [[Govandi]] and [[Pydhonie]]. Mehta chose to shoot in the apartment above Azmi’s ground floor residence in the Taximen's Colony as he wanted to "capture the sense of claustrophobia and unkemptness of his home".{{cite news|url=https://mumbaimirror.indiatimes.com/others/sunday-read/Keeping-it-real/articleshow/24405378.cms|title=Keeping it real|last=Holla|first=Anand|work=Mumbai Mirror|date=20 October 2013|accessdate=14 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180614145617/https://mumbaimirror.indiatimes.com/others/sunday-read/Keeping-it-real/articleshow/24405378.cms|archivedate=14 June 2018|df=dmy-all}} Some portions of the film were shot in Azmi's office and his colony.{{cite web|url=http://movies.ndtv.com/bollywood/shahid-makes-shahid-azmis-brother-emotional-635836|title=Shahid makes Shahid Azmi's brother emotional|publisher=NDTV|date=19 October 2013|accessdate=14 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180614171536/http://movies.ndtv.com/bollywood/shahid-makes-shahid-azmis-brother-emotional-635836|archivedate=14 June 2018|df=dmy-all}} ''Shahid'' was also shot in [[Nagpada]], where Faheem Ansari's wife Yasmin lives.{{cite news |title=The 'unlikely' lawyer as an unlikely hero |url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/the-unlikely-lawyer-as-an-unlikely-hero/985769/0 |work=The Indian Express |date=9 August 2012 |accessdate=9 August 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131010071725/http://www.indianexpress.com/news/the-unlikely-lawyer-as-an-unlikely-hero/985769/0 |archivedate=10 October 2013 |df=dmy-all }} The scenes in the terrorist training camp were shot in [[Himachal Pradesh]]. Mehta decided to depict realistic court scenes based on his team's observation of real courts. They visited the Andheri Court and the Esplanade Court among others, taking photographs to recreate the ambiance for the courtroom scenes.{{cite news|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/entertainment-others/screen-exclusive-in-conversation-with-shahid-director-and-on-screen-shahid-azmi/|title=Screen Exclusive: In conversation with ‘Shahid’ director and on screen Shahid Azmi|work=The Indian Express|date=18 October 2013|accessdate=14 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180614171843/https://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/entertainment-others/screen-exclusive-in-conversation-with-shahid-director-and-on-screen-shahid-azmi/|archivedate=14 June 2018|df=dmy-all}} Courtroom sets were built because filming in an actual court is not permitted. The film's unit consisted of about 17 people because of budget and time constraints; it was made on a budget of {{INRConvert|65|l}}. The film was shot linearly on a non-linear draft. Mehta said it was filmed guerilla style using all "available digital formats without really worrying about which lens was available". The filmmaker used only natural or minimal lighting. For an interrogation scene, Rao suggested Mehta show him naked as he wanted to "feel the embarrassment, the mental pain of the character."{{cite news|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/hindi/bollywood/news/Nude-scene-in-Shahid-was-my-idea-Rajkumar-Yadav/articleshow/24200732.cms|title=Nude scene in 'Shahid' was my idea: Rajkumar Yadav|work=The Times of India|date=15 October 2013|accessdate=14 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180625160550/https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/hindi/bollywood/news/Nude-scene-in-Shahid-was-my-idea-Rajkumar-Yadav/articleshow/24200732.cms|archivedate=25 June 2018|df=dmy-all}} The film's editor, [[Apurva Asrani]], edited the film in a linear order as he felt an earlier version was "not working". Mehta ultimately decided to give him a screenplay credit as he felt Asrani "shaped the narrative" of the film. ''Shahid'' was jointly produced by Kashyap, [[UTV Motion Pictures#UTV Spotboy|UTV Spotboy]] and Sunil Bohra.{{cite news|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/bollywood/shahid-director-i-had-no-apprehension-in-doing-a-biopic/|title=‘Shahid’ director: I had no apprehension in doing a biopic|work=The Indian Express|date=16 October 2013|accessdate=14 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180614200219/https://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/bollywood/shahid-director-i-had-no-apprehension-in-doing-a-biopic/|archivedate=14 June 2018|df=dmy-all}} Azmi had defended Kashyap's film ''[[Black Friday (2007 film)|Black Friday]]'' in the courts while it was debarred from release by the censor board. Anuj Dhawan served as the film's director of photography.{{cite news|url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/bollywood/ranbir-not-raj-kumar-was-top-choice-for-shahid-director/story-KeE1N0WNbmXPR8FU4JrQxI.html|title='Ranbir not Raj Kumar' was top choice for Shahid: director|last=Jha|first=Subhash K|work=Hindustan Times|date=19 October 2013|accessdate=14 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180614171401/https://www.hindustantimes.com/bollywood/ranbir-not-raj-kumar-was-top-choice-for-shahid-director/story-KeE1N0WNbmXPR8FU4JrQxI.html|archivedate=14 June 2018|df=dmy-all}} Mehta said that they had a lot of material they did not use as "not all of it could translate into a scene"; he wanted the film to be more accessible. Azmi's brother Khalid Azmi said of the film's authenticity that "it is 95 percent accurate." ==Release and reception== ''Shahid'' premiered at the [[2012 Toronto International Film Festival]] in its "City to City" programme in September 2012.{{cite news|title=Anurag Kashyap's film at Toronto Film Festival|url=http://www.mid-day.com/entertainment/2012/aug/020812-Anurag-Kashyaps-film-at-Toronto-Film-Festival.htm|work=Mid Day|date=2 August 2012|accessdate=26 August 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120820002212/http://www.mid-day.com/entertainment/2012/aug/020812-Anurag-Kashyaps-film-at-Toronto-Film-Festival.htm|archivedate=20 August 2012|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/bollywood/rajkumar-was-one-of-the-best-decisions-for-shahid-hansal-mehta/|title=Rajkumar was one of the best decisions for ‘Shahid’: Hansal Mehta|work=The Indian Express|date=16 October 2013|accessdate=14 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180614194531/https://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/bollywood/rajkumar-was-one-of-the-best-decisions-for-shahid-hansal-mehta/|archivedate=14 June 2018|df=dmy-all}} The film was screened at several film festivals including the 14th [[Mumbai Academy of the Moving Image#Film Festival|Mumbai Film Festival]], the [[New York Indian Film Festival]], the Indian Film Festival Stuttgart, the [[Dubai International Film Festival]] and the Chicago South Asian Film Festival.{{cite news|url=https://indianexpress.com/article/cities/delhi/my-films-dont-talk-down-to-the-audience-2/|title=‘My films don’t talk down to the audience’|work=The Indian Express|date=13 October 2013|accessdate=14 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180614171722/https://indianexpress.com/article/cities/delhi/my-films-dont-talk-down-to-the-audience-2/|archivedate=14 June 2018|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|url=https://www.indiatoday.in/movies/bollywood/story/shahid-trailer-211797-2013-09-21|title=Trailer: Shahid based on human rights activist and lawyer Shahid Azmi|work=India Today|date=21 September 2013|accessdate=14 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180614172217/https://www.indiatoday.in/movies/bollywood/story/shahid-trailer-211797-2013-09-21|archivedate=14 June 2018|df=dmy-all}} The film's album soundtrack consisted of one song titled "Beparwah", sung by [[Arjit Singh]].{{cite web|url=https://www.last.fm/music/Arijit+Singh+-+Www.SongsKing.iN/_/Beparwah+(Shahid)+-+Arijit+Singh+%5BSongsKing.iN%5D|title=Beparwah (Shahid) - Arijit Singh|publisher=Last.fm|accessdate=14 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180714085155/https://www.last.fm/music/Arijit+Singh+-+Www.SongsKing.iN/_/Beparwah+(Shahid)+-+Arijit+Singh+%5BSongsKing.iN%5D|archivedate=14 July 2018|df=dmy-all}} The film's poster, which showed Rao's blackened face, was also released.{{cite news|url=https://www.news18.com/news/india/hansal-mehtas-past-inspires-shahid-movie-poster-643637.html|title=Hansal Mehta's past inspires 'Shahid' movie poster|publisher=CNN-News18|date=7 October 2013|accessdate=14 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180614172014/https://www.news18.com/news/india/hansal-mehtas-past-inspires-shahid-movie-poster-643637.html|archivedate=14 June 2018|df=dmy-all}} The official trailer was unveiled on 20 September 2013. The film opened in India on 18 October 2013 around 400 screens.{{cite web|url=http://movies.ndtv.com/bollywood/boss-shahid-enjoy-good-run-at-the-box-office-435164|title=Boss, Shahid enjoy good run at the box office|publisher=NDTV|date=21 October 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140121083357/http://movies.ndtv.com/bollywood/boss-shahid-enjoy-good-run-at-the-box-office-435164|archivedate=21 January 2014|df=dmy-all}} A private screening of the film was held for the cast and crew before its release.{{cite news|url=https://www.indiatoday.in/movies/photo/stars-flock-at-special-screening-of-shahid-370806-2013-10-18|title=Stars flock at special screening of Shahid|work=India Today|accessdate=14 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180614173018/https://www.indiatoday.in/movies/photo/stars-flock-at-special-screening-of-shahid-370806-2013-10-18|archivedate=14 June 2018|df=dmy-all}} ===Critical response=== ''Shahid'' received mostly positive review from the critics with particular praise for Rao's performance.{{cite news|url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/bollywood/hansal-mehta-q-team-up-for-garbage/story-sqnJ4zqMXtVcX95idkRFwK.html|title=Hansal Mehta, Q team up for Garbage|work=Hindustan Times|date=4 July 2017|accessdate=15 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180615163253/https://www.hindustantimes.com/bollywood/hansal-mehta-q-team-up-for-garbage/story-sqnJ4zqMXtVcX95idkRFwK.html|archivedate=15 June 2018|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=https://www.ibtimes.co.in/039shahid-review-roundup-a-courageous-film-that-grips-you-till-the-end-514855|title='Shahid’ Review Roundup: A Courageous Film that Grips You Till the End|publisher=International Business Times|date=18 October 2013|accessdate=15 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180615190850/https://www.ibtimes.co.in/039shahid-review-roundup-a-courageous-film-that-grips-you-till-the-end-514855|archivedate=15 June 2018|df=dmy-all}} Saibal Chatterjee of [[NDTV]] called it a "gritty, gutsy, bold and brave" film that articulates "uncomfortable truths about contemporary India, its media, its judiciary and, of course, its people."{{cite web|url=http://movies.ndtv.com/movie-reviews/shahid-movie-review-887|title=Shahid movie review|last=Chatterjee|first=Saibal|publisher=NDTV|date=7 March 2014|accessdate=15 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180615135537/http://movies.ndtv.com/movie-reviews/shahid-movie-review-887|archivedate=15 June 2018|df=dmy-all}} [[Sify]]'s Sonia Chopra gave a positive review, writing that the film "salutes the man who walked a unique path" and does "full justice to the man and his extraordinary life."{{cite web|url=http://www.sify.com/movies/shahid-review-plucky-engaging-thought-provoking-review-bollywood-pcmbcIbdidhje.html|title=Shahid review: Plucky, engaging, thought-provoking!|last=Chopra|first=Sonia|publisher=Sify|date=18 October 2013|accessdate=15 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180615135220/http://www.sify.com/movies/shahid-review-plucky-engaging-thought-provoking-review-bollywood-pcmbcIbdidhje.html|archivedate=15 June 2018|df=dmy-all}} [[Rajeev Masand]] wrote in his review: "The film itself is brave and unflinching, and oozes the kind of sincerity that you long for in most Hindi films."{{cite web|url=http://www.rajeevmasand.com/reviews/our-films/cold-justice/|title=Cold justice|last=Masand|first=Rajeev|publisher=RajeevMasand.com|date=18 October 2013|accessdate=15 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180615163312/http://www.rajeevmasand.com/reviews/our-films/cold-justice/|archivedate=15 June 2018|df=dmy-all}} Madhureeta Mukherjee of ''[[The Times of India]]'' said the film is "brutally honest, brave and above all a fascinating humane story".{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/movie-reviews/hindi/shahidshahid-movie-review/movie-review/24296289.cms|title=Shahid Movie Review|work=The Times of India|date=1 February 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131020063058/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/movie-reviews/hindi/shahidshahid-movie-review/movie-review/24296289.cms|archivedate=20 October 2013|df=dmy-all}} Trisha of ''[[Firstpost]]'' felt Mehta's directorial style echoed "Azmi's own commitment to a truth in which thoughtless actions produce victims, rather than villainy producing heroes."{{cite web|url=https://www.firstpost.com/entertainment/movie-review-why-hansal-mehtas-shahid-is-worth-a-watch-1193883.html|title=Movie Review: Why Hansal Mehta's Shahid is worth a watch|author=Trisha|publisher=Firstpost|date=25 October 2013|accessdate=15 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180714085155/https://www.firstpost.com/entertainment/movie-review-why-hansal-mehtas-shahid-is-worth-a-watch-1193883.html|archivedate=14 July 2018|df=dmy-all}} Shubhra Gupta of ''[[The Indian Express]]'' mentioned in her review that the film "needed to have been made" and Mehta "tells it straight, without any false flourishes". She also praised Rao's performance, saying he "wears the character like skin, and becomes Shahid."{{cite news|url=http://archive.indianexpress.com/news/shahid-review-it-needed-to-have-been-made/1184193/1|title='Shahid' review: It needed to have been made|last=Gupta|first=Shubhra|work=The Indian Express|date=19 October 2013|accessdate=15 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180714085155/http://archive.indianexpress.com/news/shahid-review-it-needed-to-have-been-made/1184193/1|archivedate=14 July 2018|df=dmy-all}} ''[[India Today]]''{{'}}s Suhani Singh gave a positive review, writing the film "stops short of hero worship and is a fitting tribute to an inspiring figure."{{cite news|url=https://www.indiatoday.in/movies/reviews/story/movie-review-shahid-214684-2013-10-18|title=Movie Review: Shahid is a fitting tribute to an inspiring figure|last=Sigh|first=Suhani|work=India Today|date=18 October 2013|accessdate=15 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180615190631/https://www.indiatoday.in/movies/reviews/story/movie-review-shahid-214684-2013-10-18|archivedate=15 June 2018|df=dmy-all}} [[Anupama Chopra]] praised Rao's performance in the film and called it his "triumph, [..] his ''Shahid'' has strength, anguish and a controlled anger, but also real charm."{{cite news|url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/movie-reviews/movie-review-shahid-by-anupama-chopra/story-mWzgit5UoDRfc5YMJZmWDP.html|title=Movie Review: Shahid by Anupama Chopra|last=Chopra|first=Anupama|work=Hindustan Times|date=23 October 2013|accessdate=15 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180615190602/https://www.hindustantimes.com/movie-reviews/movie-review-shahid-by-anupama-chopra/story-mWzgit5UoDRfc5YMJZmWDP.html|archivedate=15 June 2018|df=dmy-all}} Vinayak Chakravorty of ''India Today'' called it a "career-defining role" for Rao and the "biggest reason you will love this unusual film."{{cite news|url=https://www.indiatoday.in/movies/reviews/story/shahid-review-214609-2013-10-17|title=Movie review: Shahid|last=Chakravorty|first=Vinayak|work=India Today|date=17 October 2013|accessdate=15 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180615190601/https://www.indiatoday.in/movies/reviews/story/shahid-review-214609-2013-10-17|archivedate=15 June 2018|df=dmy-all}} [[Baradwaj Rangan]] called the film a "deeply humanistic drama" and said the film "makes us think, but more often, it makes us feel."{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/cinema/cinema-reviews/shahid-law-and-disorder/article5251332.ece|title=Shahid: Law and disorder|last=Rangan|first=Baradwaj|work=The Hindu|date=19 October 2013|accessdate=15 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140623225835/http://www.thehindu.com/features/cinema/cinema-reviews/shahid-law-and-disorder/article5251332.ece|archivedate=23 June 2014|df=dmy-all}} ''[[Mid Day]]''{{'}}s Shubha Shetty Saha wrote: "Not often do we get the opportunity to watch a relevant movie that depicts the times we live in, with unblinking directness."{{cite news|url=https://archive.mid-day.com/entertainment/2013/oct/181013-bollywood-movie-review-shahid.htm|title=Movie Review: Shahid|last=Saha|first=Shubha Shetty|work=Mid Day|date=18 October 2013|accessdate=15 June 2018}} Prasanna D Zore of [[Rediff.com]] called it a "gutsy and thought-provoking film", she added that it is not an "in your face film": "It is a subtle, thought-provoking and gutsy story of a person who believed in the power of truth and justice yet knew that the path he had taken was strewn with risks, indifference and ignominy."{{cite web|url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/report/review-dont-miss-shahid/20131018.htm|title=Review: DON'T MISS Shahid!|last=Zore|first=Prasanna D|publisher=Rediff.com|date=18 October 2013|accessdate=15 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180615163306/http://www.rediff.com/movies/report/review-dont-miss-shahid/20131018.htm|archivedate=15 June 2018|df=dmy-all}} Saurav Datta of ''[[Daily News and Analysis]]'' felt the film was "incomplete" without showing Azmi's younger brother's role as he took over his job; he felt the film also concluded with an "abrupt, grinding halt".{{cite news|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/entertainment/review-hansal-mehta-s-shahid-an-incomplete-tale-of-shahaadat-1905699|title=Hansal Mehta's 'Shahid' - an incomplete tale of 'Shahaadat'|last=Datta|first=Saurav|work=Daily News and Analysis|date=19 October 2013|accessdate=15 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180615164748/http://www.dnaindia.com/entertainment/review-hansal-mehta-s-shahid-an-incomplete-tale-of-shahaadat-1905699|archivedate=15 June 2018|df=dmy-all}} ''[[Mint (newspaper)|Mint]]''{{'}}s Sanjukta Sharma called it an "admirable project" and praised Rao's performance but felt the film fell "short of a masterpiece" as a biopic.{{cite news|url=https://www.livemint.com/Leisure/JLIouNHNcmZsKdjatjQFCN/Film-Review--Shahid.html|title=Film Review: Shahid|last=Sharma|first=|work=Mint|date=19 October 2013|accessdate=15 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180615190656/https://www.livemint.com/Leisure/JLIouNHNcmZsKdjatjQFCN/Film-Review--Shahid.html|archivedate=15 June 2018|df=dmy-all}} Namrata Joshi of ''Outlook'' wrote that the film "portrays the psyche of the Indian Muslim in the changing, increasingly polarised India with warmth and simplicity."{{cite news|url=https://www.outlookindia.com/magazine/story/shahid/288188|title=Shahid|last=Joshi|first=Namrata|work=Outlook|date=28 October 2013|accessdate=15 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180615190747/https://www.outlookindia.com/magazine/story/shahid/288188|archivedate=15 June 2018|df=dmy-all}} ''Reuters''{{'}} Shilpa Jamkhandikar responded positively to the film and praised Rao's performance: "As Shahid, Raj Kumar injects the right amount of earnestness, anger and vulnerability into his role, to make this one of the best performances we have seen this year."{{cite news|url=http://blogs.reuters.com/india/2013/10/17/movie-review-shahid/|title=Movie Review: Shahid|last=Jamkhandikar|first=Shilpa|work=Reuter|date=17 October 2013|accessdate=15 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170309121851/http://blogs.reuters.com/india/2013/10/17/movie-review-shahid/|archivedate=9 March 2017|df=dmy-all}} Journalist and writer [[Rana Ayyub]] called the film a "brave and worthy tribute to [Azmi's] work and courage."{{cite news|url=https://india.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/10/21/biopic-on-life-of-lawyer-murdered-in-a-mumbai-court/|title=Biopic on Life of Lawyer Murdered in Mumbai|last=Ayyub|first=Rana|work=The New York Times|date=21 October 2013|accessdate=15 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180615191752/https://india.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/10/21/biopic-on-life-of-lawyer-murdered-in-a-mumbai-court/|archivedate=15 June 2018|df=dmy-all}} Among overseas reviewers, Omer M. Mozaffar of [[RogerEbert.com]] praised Mehta's direction and called his work a "pleasant surprise": "the lack of polish at first seems like a film school weakness, but grows into a well-crafted asset, especially in his deliberate fades to black."{{cite web|url=https://www.rogerebert.com/far-flung-correspondents/shahid-man-against-the-machines|title=SHAHID: Man Against the Machines|last=Mozaffar|first=Omar M.|publisher=RogerEbert.com|date=30 September 2014|accessdate=15 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180615191321/https://www.rogerebert.com/far-flung-correspondents/shahid-man-against-the-machines|archivedate=15 June 2018|df=dmy-all}} Rachel Saltz of ''[[The New York Times]]'' gave a positive review writing: "[Mehta] has made a film of conviction that’s neither plodding nor preachy." However, Saltz felt the second half of the film was "truncated and overstuffed".{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/21/movies/shahid-stars-raj-kumar-yadav-as-a-real-life-lawyer.html|title=Standing Up for Muslims in India’s Courts|last=Saltz|first=Rachel|work=The New York Times|date=20 October 2013|accessdate=15 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180615191222/https://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/21/movies/shahid-stars-raj-kumar-yadav-as-a-real-life-lawyer.html|archivedate=15 June 2018|df=dmy-all}} Mohammad Kamran Jawaid of ''[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]]'', gave the film a positive review writing that the two-hour time constraint "means there's little room for the traditional expansion we get from biopics, and if at times ''Shahid'' feels like an expanded best-of Mr. Azmi's life, it's because it is".{{cite news|last=Jawaid|first=Mohammad Kamran|title=Movie Review: Shahid|url=http://dawn.com/news/1054302/movie-review-shahid|work=Dawn|date=5 November 2013|accessdate=9 November 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131108220821/http://dawn.com/news/1054302/movie-review-shahid|archivedate=8 November 2013|df=dmy-all}} ''Shahid'' was mentioned in critic and author Shubhra Gupta's book, ''50 Films That Changed Bollywood, 1995-2015''.{{cite book|title=50 Films That Changed Bollywood, 1995-2015|last=Gupta|first=Shubhra|publisher=Harper Collins|year=2016|isbn=9789351778486}} ===Box office=== ''Shahid'' opened to small audiences in theatres and earned a total of {{INRConvert|45|l}}. It went on to take in {{INRConvert|2.05|c}} at the end of its first weekend. The film performed well with multiplex audiences compared to single screens.{{cite web|url=http://www.koimoi.com/box-office/shahid-1st-tuesday-box-office-collections/|title=Shahid : 1st Tuesday Box Office Collections|date=23 October 2013|publisher=koimoi|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131027203644/http://www.koimoi.com/box-office/shahid-1st-tuesday-box-office-collections/|archivedate=27 October 2013|df=dmy-all}} It collected {{INRConvert|32|l}} on the fifth day, {{INRConvert|30|l}} on the sixth, and {{INRConvert|26|l}} seventh day. The film's total box office collection at the end of its theatrical run was {{INRConvert|3.607|c}}. ===Awards=== For ''Shahid'', Rao received the [[National Film Award for Best Actor|Best Actor Award]] and Mehta the [[National Film Award for Best Director|Best Director Award]] at the [[61st National Film Awards]] ceremony.{{cite web |title=61st National Film Awards For 2013 |url=http://www.dff.nic.in/List%20of%20Awards.pdf# |publisher=Directorate of Film Festivals |date=16 April 2014 |accessdate=16 April 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140416181218/http://www.dff.nic.in/List%20of%20Awards.pdf |archivedate=16 April 2014 |df=dmy-all }} Rao also won the [[Filmfare Critics Award for Best Actor]] at the [[59th Filmfare Awards]].{{cite web|url=http://www.filmfare.com/news/winners-of-59th-idea-filmfare-awards-5220.html|title=Winners of 59th Idea Filmfare Awards|date=25 January 2014|publisher=Filmfare|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140127031218/http://www.filmfare.com/news/winners-of-59th-idea-filmfare-awards-5220.html|archivedate=27 January 2014|df=dmy-all}} At the 14th [[Mumbai International Film Festival]], the film won the Silver Gateway trophy and cash prize of {{INRConvert|5|l}} while Mehta won the Best Director award.{{cite news|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/Here-And-There-wins-Best-Film-at-14th-Mumbai-Film-Festival/articleshow/16965661.cms|title=Here And There wins Best Film at 14th Mumbai Film Festival|work=The Times of India|date=26 October 2012|accessdate=14 July 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180714085155/https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/Here-And-There-wins-Best-Film-at-14th-Mumbai-Film-Festival/articleshow/16965661.cms|archivedate=14 July 2018|df=dmy-all}} Mehta won the Best Director award at the [[New York Indian Film Festival]] and at the Indian Film Festival of Stuttgart.{{cite news|url=https://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/bollywood/disney-utv-to-release-hansal-mehtas-shahid-on-oct-18/|title=Disney UTV to release Hansal Mehta’s Shahid on Oct 18|work=The Indian Express|date=5 September 2013|accessdate=14 June 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180614171629/https://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/bollywood/disney-utv-to-release-hansal-mehtas-shahid-on-oct-18/|archivedate=14 June 2018|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/jim-luce/ny-indian-american-film-f_b_3337037.html|title=NY Indian American Film Festival Triumphant in 13th Year|last=Luce|first=Jim|work=HuffPost|date=25 May 2013|accessdate=14 July 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170907181929/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jim-luce/ny-indian-american-film-f_b_3337037.html|archivedate=7 September 2017|df=dmy-all}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|2181831|Shahid}} * {{Bollywoodhungama|563934|Shahid}} {{Hansal Mehta}} [[Category:2012 films]] [[Category:Indian biographical films]] performance]] [[Category:Films whose director won the Best Director National Film Award]] [[Category:Films shot in Mumbai]] [[Category:UTV Motion Pictures films]] [[Category:Indian courtroom films]] revision.comment: Removing link(s): [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/ICC Records]] closed as delete ([[WP:XFDC|XFDcloser]])
revision.text:
{{more citations needed|date=March 2018}} {{EngvarB|date=March 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox organization | name = Spring Harvest | logo = Spring Harvest.png | type = [[Charitable_organization#Charitable_organization_structure|Company limited by guarantee]] | founded_date = 1979 (first Spring Harvest festival) 2008 (company incorporated as eternalfx) 2009 (Memralife Group) 2017 (company rebranded as Essential Christian) | founder = [[Clive Calver]], Peter Meadows | key_people = Rt Rev [[Pete Broadbent]] (Chair)
Rev Dr Ian White (Vice Chair)
Peter Martin (CEO)
Gavin Calver (Chair of the event planning group) | location = [[Uckfield]], [[East Sussex]], UK (Registered office) | area_served = UK | focus = To serve and enable the Church and to equip and inspire individuals in the Christian faith to live as disciples of Jesus Christ | method = Conferences, events, resources, financial grants | revenue = {{increase}}£4,819,854 (2016)[https://apps.charitycommission.gov.uk/Accounts/Ends97/0001126997_AC_20161130_E_C.pdf Essential Christian Financial Statements y/e 2016-11-30] | num_employees = 41 (2016) | homepage = {{URL|springharvest.org}} }} '''Spring Harvest''' exists to 'equip the Church for action' through a range of events, conferences, books and resources.[http://www.springharvest.org Spring Harvest Web Site] The tone is generally [[Evangelicalism|evangelical]] with modern worship music, workshops and [[Bible]] study groups. The programme offers different streams for age groups such as children, young people, families, adults, etc. The organisation also runs a number of events, conferences and courses and produces a range of resources. First held in 1979 as a one-week one-site event at [[Prestatyn]], Spring Harvest rapidly evolved and is now held at Butlins resorts in [[Minehead]] and [[Skegness]] every year - with the addition of one week at Harrogate in 2018. The format for 2010 changed to five 'event-weeks' each consisting of six days (five nights) - three event-weeks at Minehead and two at Skegness - one week fewer than in 2009. This pattern remained for 2011, with approximately 28,000 people attending over these five event-weeks, including day visitors.{{cite journal|title=Memralife Group Financial Statements (to 30 November 2011)}} Then in 2012 and 2013 whilst the three Minehead weeks were retained there was only one Skegness week. In 2014 three of the four weeks available were reduced by one day. In 2017, the three weeks held in Minehead were reduced to just two, with one being shorter than the other by one day, and one week in Skegness remaining the same. The Spring Harvest programme will be held in Harrogate again in 2019, alongside both Butlin’s Minehead and Skegness Resorts. This new venue is expected to be continually used for the foreseeable future, and it is thought that the Essentail Christian Brand will be hosting the event in new sites as guest capacity demands increase. == History == {{Prose|section|date=March 2013}} === Location and attendance === * 1979: The first Spring Harvest event at Prestatyn, North Wales with 2,701 attending. * 1986: For the first time Spring Harvest took place at two locations in the UK: three weeks in Prestatyn, and two weeks in Butlins Minehead. * 1987: Spring Harvest met at Skegness for the first time. * 1988: At the 10th Spring Harvest, the attendance was over 50,000 mark. * 1989: Spring Harvest expanded to three locations, opening up a new Centre at Butlin's [[Ayr]], Scotland. * 1994: Over 70,000 Christians attended Spring Harvest at its four locations in Ayr, Minehead, [[Pwllheli]] and Skegness. * 2008: Spring Harvest Main Event take place over five weeks across the Skegness and Minehead sites, to accommodate the varied times of UK schools' Easter holidays. * 2018: The programme took place at the Harrogate Convention Centre for the first time. == Main event annual themes == Each year's main event has a teaching theme. * 2019 : Unlimited; When you pray... * 2018 : Only The Brave * 2017 : One For All * 2016 : Gamechangers * 2015 : Immeasurably More * 2014 : Unbelievable * 2013 : The Source - Encountering Jesus Today * 2012 : Church Actually - God's Brilliant Idea * 2011 : Route 66 - Biblical direction for the road we travel * 2010 : Different Eyes - Living distinctively in a time of uncertainty * 2009 : Apprentice = Walking the way of Christ * 2008 : One Hope * 2007 : One People * 2006 : One God : ''(The first event in a series of Three [THE BIG STORY])'' * 2005 : Sing the Lord's Song in a Strange Land * 2004 : Grace Academy : Losing to Win. * 2003 : Shepherd's Bush to King's Cross: Your connection to the mission of God. * 2002 : You've Got Mail : Jesus writes to His Church - Looking at the seven churches in the [[Book of Revelation]]. * 2001 : King of the Hill : looking at the [[Sermon on the Mount]]. * 2000 : A Royal Banquet : The inspiration for the Millennium - Looking at John's Gospel. * 1999 : Past Imperfect Future Tense * 1998 : Across the border line * 1997 : Solid Rock : The [[Ten Commandments]]. * 1996 : Beyond Belief * 1995 : Take off your shoes * 1994 : Dancing in the dark * 1993 : Living on the edge * 1992 : Meanwhile, back at the cross * 1991 : Shaken but not Stirred * 1990 : Uncage the Lion * 1989 : Deckchairs on the Titanic : What influences the church today. * 1988 : Who's pulling your strings : Looking at the forces and pressures which influence the world. == Media coverage == * In Week 2 at [[Minehead]] in 2003, Spring Harvest was featured on the BBC programme ''[[Songs of Praise]]''. The first 'week' (week 1), still in Minehead, Spring Harvest was featured on both local and national news as a sickness bug spread rapidly around the event.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/somerset/2954341.stm | publisher=BBC News | title=More hit by holiday camp virus | date=17 April 2003}} * In Week 3 at Minehead in 2006, the BBC returned to pre-record a Pentecost edition of ''Songs of Praise'', and also to transmit a live Easter morning service from the event. * Spring Harvest has also featured in other media, including BBC radio, and also regularly in Christian media. == Discography == * One for All: Spring Harvest Live Worship, 2017. * Game Changers: Spring Harvest Live Worship, 2016 * New Songs for the church, 2016 * Kids Praise Party Megamix, 2016 * Little Kids Praise Party Megamix, 2016 * Immeasurably More: Spring Harvest Live Worship, 2015 * New Songs for the Church, 2015 * Newsongs For Kids: 12 Fresh New Songs For Kids' Worship, 2015 * The Big Start Boxset, 2015 * Unbelievable: Spring Harvest Live Worship, 2014 * New Songs For Unbelievable Worship - Spring Harvest, 2014 * Spring Harvest Presents The Big Start 3, 2014 * Your Great Grace: 30 Worship Anthems Of Grace, Mercy & Justice, 2014 * Kids Praise Party 2, 2014 * Bottled At The Source: Live Worship From Spring Harvest, 2013 * The Source: 22 New Songs For The Church, 2013 * Spring Harvest Presents The Big Start 2, 2013 * Live Worship Actually: Spring Harvest Live Worship, 2012 * Acoustic Worship 2, 2012 * Favourite Worship Songs From The Big Start, 2012 * Fresh: New Songs For The Church, 2012 * Pre-School Praise Boxset 1-3, 2012 * Pre-School Praise Boxset 4-6, 2012 * Kids Praise Party, 2012 * Route 66: Spring Harvest Live Worship, 2011 * Route 66: New Songs, 2011 * 20 More New Songs For The Church, 2011 * Pre-School Praise 6, 2011 * Kids Praise Party 6: C'mon Everybody * Through Different Eyes - Spring Harvest Live Worship, 2010 * Glory - Spring Harvest New Songs, 2010 * Kids Praise Party: Celebrate God, 2010 * Moments Of Contemplation, 2010 * Pre-School Praise 5, 2010 * Through Different Eyes, 2010 * Acoustic Worship, 2010 * Moments Of Wonder, 2010 * He Is Risen! Indeed: Celebrating Jesus From The Big Top, 2010 * Kids Praise Party Box Set, 2010 * Journey: Walking The Way Of Christ - Spring Harvest Live Worship, 2009 * Perfect Sacrifice: 20 New Songs For The Church, 2009 * Pre-School Praise 4, 2009 * Kids Praise Party: We Wanna Be Like Jesus, 2009 * One Hope - Spring Harvest Live Worship, 2008 * Wonderful Saviour: 20 New Songs For Spring Harvest, 2008 * Moments Of Devotion: 12 Classic Instrumental Worship Songs, 2008 * He Is Risen: Easter Classics From The Big Top, 2008 * The Kids Colossal Jumbo Boxset, 2008 * Pre-School Praise 3, 2008 * Kids Praise Party 3, 2008 * One People Unified In Worship -Spring Harvest Live Worship, 2007 * Shine: 20 New Songs For Spring Harvest, 2007 * How Sweet The Sound, 2007 * Pre-School Praise 2, 2007 * Kids Praise Party 2, 2007 * One God - Spring Harvest Live Worship, 2006 * Our God Reigns - Spring Harvest New Songs, 2006 * iScape: No One Like You, 2006 * Pre-School Praise 1, 2006 * Kids Praise Party 1, 2006 * Essence Of Praise & Worship...live! Spring Harvest Live Worship, 2005 * Sing: New Songs, 2005 * Distinctive Sounds: Glory, 2005 * Little Kids Praise 2005/06, 2005 * Kids Praise 2005/06, 2005 * Spring Harvest Hymns 3: Blessed Assurance, 2005 * LIVE -Spring Harvest Live Worship, 2004 * New Songs, 2004 * Little Kids Praise 2004/05, 2004 * Kids Praise 2004/05, 2004 * Ultimate Kids Praise: 60 All Time Classic Kids Praise Songs, 2004 * Evolution, 2004 * Spring Harvest Hymns 2: To God Be The Glory, 2004 * Spring Harvest Live Worship, 2003 * New Songs, 2003 * Spring Harvest Hymns: Great Is Thy Faithfulness, 2003 * Spring Harvest Live Worship, 2002 * New Songs, 2002 * Kids Praise 2002 * Praise Mix 2002 * Spring Harvest Live Worship, 2001 * New Songs, 2001 * Kids Praise 2001 * Little Kids Praise 2001 * Spring Harvest Live Worship, 2000 * New Songs, 2000 * Kid's Praise 2000 * Best Of Spring Harvest Kids Praise And Little Kids Praise, 2000 * Little Kids Praise 2000 * Spring Harvest Live Worship '99 * New Songs '99 * Spring Harvest: The Ultimate Praise Mix, 1999 * Praise Mix 99 * Spring Harvest Live Worship '98 * New Songs '98 * Kid's Praise '98 * R:age 98 * Spring Harvest Live Worship '97 (Vol 1 and Vol 2) * New Songs for 1997 * Praise Mix: Quatamala, 1997 * Kids Praise '97 * Spring Harvest Live Worship '96 (Vol 1 and Vol 2) * New Songs '96 Beyond Belief * Spring Harvest Kids Praise '96 * Praise Mix: Shout It Out, 1996 * Take Off Your Shoes - Spring Harvest Live Worship '95 * Take off your shoes - New Songs '95 * Praise Mix 1995: It's A Small World * Kid's Praise '95 * Spring Harvest Live Worship '94 * Dancing in the Dark - New Songs '94 * Praise Mix 1994 * Kids Praise '94: Dancing In The Dark * Sping Harvest Live Worship '93 * New Songs for '93 * Kids Praise '93: Dancing In The Dark * Praise Mix '93: Living On The Edge * Spring Harvest Live Worship '92 * Meanwhile, Back At The Cross: 12 New Songs For Spring Harvest 1992 * Kids Praise: Meanwhile, Back At The Cross, 1992 * Spring Harvest Live Worship '91: shaken but not stirred * Kids Praise '91: Shaken But Not Stirred * Live Worship '90: Uncage The Lion, 1990 * Celebration '89 Vol 1 & Vol 2: Worship From Minehead, Skegness, Ayr * Spring Harvest '89: 12-19 Praise * Spring Harvest Live Worship '88 * Thank You: Celebrating 10 Years Of Worship At Spring Harvest, 1988 * Live Worship '87: Where Truth And Justice Meet * Live Worship '86: This Is Your God * Live Worship '85: Lights To The World * Live Worship '84: The Servant King * Praise Vol 2: Live Worship ' === Social campaigns and fund raising for causes === * 1982: At the outbreak of the [[Falklands War]], Spring Harvest sent a telegram to the [[Margaret Thatcher|Prime Minister]] expressing 'the love and concern felt by Christians for both governments and peoples involved.' £7,800 was collected and sent to the Church in Argentina. * 1988: A worship album was launched, with profits going to Christian projects involved in supporting those with [[HIV/AIDS]]. It went on to raise over £20,000. * 1991: £250,000 was given in voluntary offerings for a wide range of Christian work. £49,000 raised for a 'Greener Burkina' by the youth programme, was used to replant a forest and build a dam to alleviate drought conditions in Burkina Faso, West Africa. * 1994 Spring Harvest brought attention to the [[Yugoslav Wars]] by sending a film crew to [[Mostar]] - a UN designated War Zone. * 1999: Spring Harvest raises thousands of pounds to help the victims of brutality in the [[Kosovo War]]. * 2000: Spring Harvest launches Generation 2000+ at Minehead, the family week, in conjunction with Care for the Family and raises over £1 million for children worldwide through the 'remember me' project. === Linked initiatives === * 1993: Spring Harvest [[Word Alive]] was launched in-conjunction with the [[Keswick Convention]], [[Proclamation Trust]] and [[UCCF]]. * 1996: Spring Harvest launched an initiative with Focus, and [[Holy Trinity, Brompton]]. * 1998: Spring Harvest unveils plans to develop its activities, the first new initiative 'At Work Together' a conference for Leaders planned for September 1998. Alongside the developments a new Corporate Identity is also launched. * 2003: Spring Harvest Holidays is launched with the holiday site in the Vendée, western France, opening to its first visitors. The first 'Youthwork the conference' takes place in [[Southport]] in November 2003. * 2007: Spring Harvest Word Alive takes place for the final time following a communication to its partners by Spring Harvest that it was no longer possible to continue the format. Word Alive will be continuing without Spring Harvest under the name [[New Word Alive]]. === Governance === * 1993: Spring Harvest became a registered charity and a company limited by guarantee. * 2009: Spring Harvest and ICC Media Group complete merger to form Memralife Group.{{cite web |url=http://www.thegoodbookstall.org.uk/news.html |title=ICC Media Group and Spring Harvest merge |accessdate=2009-03-17 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090329044708/http://www.thegoodbookstall.org.uk/news.html |archivedate=29 March 2009 |df=dmy-all }} * 2009: Pilgrim Hall Christian Conference Centre in Sussex becomes latest member of the Memralife Group.{{cite web |url=http://www.springharvest.org/about-us/pilgrim-hall/ |title=Pilgrim Hall Christian Conference Centre |accessdate=2010-04-18 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100520160753/http://www.springharvest.org/about-us/pilgrim-hall/ |archivedate=20 May 2010 |df=dmy-all }} * 2010: After 20 years as CEO, Alan Johnson retires. Peter Martin appointed acting CEO of Memralife Group, this appointment being made permanent later in the year. * In 2017, the Memralife Group is rebranded to 'Essential Christian'. == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{official website|springharvest.org}} [[Category:Evangelical Christian conferences]] [[Category:Christian events]] [[Category:Christian festivals and holy days]]
