page.title: The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas

revision.text:
{{For|the 1982 feature film|The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas (film)}} {{Infobox Musical |name = The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas |subtitle = |image = BestWhorehouse.jpg |image_size = 200px |caption = Original cast album |music = [[Carol Hall]] |lyrics = Carol Hall |book = [[Larry L. King]]
[[Peter Masterson]] |basis = Story by Larry L. King |productions = 1978 [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]]
1980 U.S. Tour
1981 West End
1982 Broadway
1982 [[The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas (film)|Film]]
2001 U.S. Tour
2011 London Fringe Revival |awards = }} '''''The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas''''' is a [[Musical theatre|musical]] with a book by Texas author [[Larry L. King]] and [[Peter Masterson]] and music and lyrics by [[Carol Hall]]. It is based on a story by King that was inspired by the real-life [[Chicken Ranch (Texas)|Chicken Ranch]] in [[La Grange, Texas]]. ==Synopsis== It is the late 1970s, and a [[brothel]] has been operating outside of fictional Gilbert, [[Texas]] (subbing for real locale La Grange) for more than a century. It is under the proprietorship of Miss Mona Stangley, having been left to her by the original owner. While taking care of her girls, she is also on good terms with the local sheriff, Ed Earl Dodd. When crusading [[television]] [[reporter]] Melvin P. Thorpe (based on real-life [[Houston]] news personality [[Marvin Zindler]]) decides to make the illegal activity an issue, [[politics|political]] ramifications cause the place to be closed down. ==Production history== ''The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas'' opened on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] at the [[46th Street Theatre]] on June 19, 1978 and ran for 1,584 performances. The production was directed by [[Peter Masterson]] and [[Tommy Tune]] and [[choreographed]] by Tune and [[Thommie Walsh]]. The opening cast included [[Carlin Glynn]], [[Henderson Forsythe]], [[Jay Garner (actor)|Jay Garner]], Joan Ellis, [[Delores Hall]], and [[Pamela Blair]]. Glynn was replaced by [[Fannie Flagg]] and [[Anita Morris]] later in the run. [[Alexis Smith]] starred as Miss Mona in the [[National Company]], which toured major cities for more than a year, ending with a seven-month run in [[Los Angeles]]. In what was described as "a return engagement", the show opened on Broadway at the [[Eugene O'Neill Theatre]] on May 31, 1982 and closed on July 24, 1982 after nine previews and 63 performances. The cast featured Glynn and Hall.{{cite web |url=https://www.playbillvault.com/Show/Detail/4712/The-Best-Little-Whorehouse-in-Texas |title=The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas'' 1982 Listing |website=PlayBillVault.com |accessdate=July 25, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121202170123/http://www.playbillvault.com/Show/Detail/4712/The-Best-Little-Whorehouse-in-Texas |archive-date=2012-12-02 |dead-url=yes |df= }} The [[West End theatre|West End]] production opened at the [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane]] on February 26, 1981, again starring Glynn and Forsythe. It ran for 204 performances.{{cite web |url=http://www.overthefootlights.co.uk/London_Musicals.html |title=Introduction: A Hundred Years of London Musicals |accessdate=December 23, 2017}} A short-lived sequel entitled ''[[The Best Little Whorehouse Goes Public]]'' was staged on Broadway in 1994. "The Aggie Song" was performed on the [[Tony Awards]] broadcast, but was heavily censored because of the nature of the lyrics and choreography. A U.S. National Tour starring [[Ann-Margret]] opened on February 14, 2001.Jones, Kenneth. [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/58504-Nothin-Dirty-Ann-Margret-Opens-Whorehouse-Feb-13-in-CT "Nothin' Dirty: Ann-Margret Opens 'Whorehouse' Feb. 13 in CT"]. Playbill, February 13, 2001{{dead link|date=December 2017}} A benefit concert took place on October 16, 2006, to benefit the Actor's Fund. The concert was directed by Mark S. Hoebee and choreographed by [[Denis Jones]]. The cast included [[Terrence Mann]] (as Sheriff Ed Earl Dodd), [[Emily Skinner]], and [[Jennifer Hudson]].Gans, Andrew. [https://www.playbill.com/article/actors-funds-the-best-little-whorehouse-in-texas-benefit-concert-presented-oct-16-com-135569# "Actors' Fund's 'The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas' Benefit Concert Presented Oct. 16"] Playbill, October 16, 2006 A Revival production of the musical was staged on London's Fringe at The Union Theatre From October 2011- November 2011, starring Sarah Lark as Miss Mona, Nancy Sullivan as Shy and Leon Craig as Melvin P. Thorpe. Ensemble members included Jarred Page, Sasi Strallen, Katy Streader, Frankie Jenna, Patrick George, Dayle Hodge & Dan O'Brian. The production was directed by Paul Taylor-Mills. A Broadway revival, with direction and choreography from [[Rob Ashford]], was reportedly in the works in 2015.{{cite web|last1=Gans|first1=Andrew|title=Best Little Whorehouse in Texas Will Stomp Its Way Back to Broadway, Run by Rob Ashford|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/best-little-whorehouse-in-texas-will-stomp-its-way-back-to-broadway-run-by--326600|website=Playbill Club|accessdate=8 June 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Cox|first1=Gordon|title=‘Best Little Whorehouse in Texas’ Heads Back to Broadway|url=https://variety.com/2014/legit/news/best-little-whorehouse-in-texas-back-to-broadway-1201277945/|accessdate=June 8, 2015|work=Variety|date=August 7, 2014}} ==Song list== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} ; Act I * "Prologue" – The Rio Grande Band Leader and the Rio Grande Band * "20 Fans" – Company * "A Lil' Ole Bitty Pissant Country Place" – Mona Stangley and the Girls * "Girl, You're a Woman" – Mona Stangley, Shy, Jewel and the Girls * "Watch Dog Theme" – The Dogettes * "Texas Has a Whorehouse in It" – Melvin P. Thorpe, the Thorpe Singers and the Dogettes * "Twenty Four Hours of Lovin'" – Jewel and the Girls * "Watch Dog Theme" (Reprise) – The Dogettes * "Texas Has a Whorehouse in It" (Reprise) – Melvin P. Thorpe and the Dogettes * "Doatsy Mae" – Doatsy Mae * "Angelette March" – Angelette Imogene Charlene and the Angelettes * "The Aggie Song" – The Aggies * "The Bus from Amarillo" – Mona Stangley {{col-2}} ; Act II * "The Sidestep" – The Governor of Texas & Company * "No Lies" – Mona Stangley, Jewel and the Girls * "Good Old Girl" – Sheriff Ed Earl Dodd and the Aggies * "[[Hard Candy Christmas]]" – The Girls * "Finale" – Company {{col-end}} ==Awards and nominations== ===Original Broadway production=== {| class="wikitable" width="95%" |- ! width="5%"| Year ! width="20%"| Award ! width="45%"| Category ! width="20%"| Nominee ! width="10%"| Result |- | rowspan="16" align="center"| 1979 | rowspan="7"| [[Tony Award]] | colspan="2"| [[Tony Award for Best Musical|Best Musical]] | {{nom}} |- | [[Tony Award for Best Book of a Musical|Best Book of a Musical]] | Larry L. King and [[Peter Masterson]] | {{nom}} |- | [[Tony Award for Best Performance by a Featured Actor in a Musical|Best Performance by a Featured Actor in a Musical]] | [[Henderson Forsythe]] | {{won}} |- | rowspan="2"| [[Tony Award for Best Performance by a Featured Actress in a Musical|Best Performance by a Featured Actress in a Musical]] | [[Carlin Glynn]] | {{won}} |- | Joan Ellis | {{nom}} |- | [[Tony Award for Best Direction of a Musical|Best Direction of a Musical]] | [[Peter Masterson]] and [[Tommy Tune]] | {{nom}} |- | [[Tony Award for Best Choreography|Best Choreography]] | [[Tommy Tune]] and [[Thommie Walsh]] | {{nom}} |- | rowspan="8"| [[Drama Desk Award]] | colspan="2"| [[Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Musical|Outstanding Musical]] | {{nom}} |- | [[Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Actor in a Musical|Outstanding Actor in a Musical]] | [[Henderson Forsythe]] | {{nom}} |- | [[Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Actress in a Musical|Outstanding Actress in a Musical]] | [[Carlin Glynn]] | {{nom}} |- | [[Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Featured Actress in a Musical|Outstanding Featured Actress in a Musical]] | [[Pamela Blair]] | {{nom}} |- | [[Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Director of a Musical|Outstanding Director of a Musical]] | [[Peter Masterson]] and [[Tommy Tune]] | {{won}} |- | [[Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Choreography|Outstanding Choreography]] | [[Tommy Tune]] and [[Thommie Walsh]] | {{nom}} |- | [[Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Lyrics|Outstanding Lyrics]] | rowspan="2"| [[Carol Hall]] | {{won}} |- | [[Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Music|Outstanding Music]] | {{won}} |- | colspan="2"| [[Theatre World Award]] | [[Carlin Glynn]] | {{won}} |} ==Discography== * ''The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas'': original cast. Audio CD. MCA, 1997. MCAD-11683; MCA-3049. * ''Best Little Whorehouse in Texas'': New cast recording. Audio CD. Fynsworth Alley/Varèse Sarabande, 2001. 302 062 117 2. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Bibliography== * Hall, Carol. Vocal selections from ''The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas''. Melville, N.Y.: MCA Music, 1979. * King, Larry L., and Masterson, Peter. ''The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas''. Music and lyrics by Carol Hall. French's Musical Library. New York, N.Y.: S. French, 1978. {{ISBN|0-573-68111-2}}. * King, Larry L. ''The Whorehouse Papers''. New York: Viking Press, 1982. {{ISBN|0-670-15919-0}}. ==External links== * {{IBDB title|id=4066|title=Best Little Whorehouse in Texas}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120627064741/http://www.samuelfrench.com/store/product_info.php/products_id/2665 Licensing Information from Samuel French, Inc.] * [https://www.stageagent.com/Shows/View/838 Plot summary & character descriptions from StageAgent.com] * {{IMDb title|id=0083642|title=The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas}} {{The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Best Little Whorehouse in Texas, The}} [[Category:1978 musicals]] [[Category:Broadway musicals]] [[Category:Musicals inspired by real-life events]] [[Category:Texas in fiction]]

{{Infobox software | name = TidalCycles | logo = TidalCycles identity.svg | logo size = 250px | screenshot = Tidal Code Screenshot.png | developer = Alex McLean and others | released = 2009 | latest release version = 0.9.4 | latest release date = {{Start date and age|2017|05|07|df=yes}} | repo = http://github.com/tidalcycles/Tidal/ | programming language = [[Haskell (programming language)|Haskell]] | operating system = [[Linux]], [[macOS]], [[Windows]] | genre = [[Live coding]] environment | license = [[GNU General Public License|GPLv3]] | website = {{URL|tidalcycles.org}} }} '''TidalCycles''' (also known as "Tidal") is a [[live coding]] environment designed for musical improvisation. In particular, it is a [[domain-specific language]] embedded in [[Haskell (programming language)|Haskell]], focused on the generation and manipulation of audible or visual patterns.<ref>{{cite web|last1=McLean|first1=Alex|title=Tidal – Pattern Language for Live Coding of Music|url=http://smcnetwork.org/node/1371|website=Sound and Music Computing|accessdate=22 May 2015}}</ref> It was originally designed for heavily percussive, polyrhythmic grid-based music, but now uses a flexible, functional reactive representation for patterns, using rational time.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Making Programming Languages to Dance to: Live Coding with Tidal|url = http://doi.acm.org/10.1145/2633638.2633647|publisher = ACM|journal = Proceedings of the 2Nd ACM SIGPLAN International Workshop on Functional Art, Music, Modeling & Design|date = 2014|location = New York, NY, USA|isbn = 978-1-4503-3039-8|pages = 63–70|series = FARM '14|doi = 10.1145/2633638.2633647|first = Alex|last = McLean}}</ref> Tidal may therefore be applied to a wide range of musical styles, although its cyclic approach to time<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Temporal Semantics for a Live Coding Language|url = http://doi.acm.org/10.1145/2633638.2633648|publisher = ACM|journal = Proceedings of the 2Nd ACM SIGPLAN International Workshop on Functional Art, Music, Modeling & Design|date = 2014|location = New York, NY, USA|isbn = 978-1-4503-3039-8|pages = 37–47|series = FARM '14|doi = 10.1145/2633638.2633648|first = Samuel|last = Aaron|first2 = Dominic|last2 = Orchard|first3 = Alan F.|last3 = Blackwell}}</ref> means that it affords use in repetitive styles such as [[Algorave]].
Tidal does not produce sound itself, but via the [[SuperCollider]] sound environment through the SuperDirt framework, or via [[MIDI]] or [[Open Sound Control]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = SuperCollider Users New (Use this!!!!) - Tidal and supercollider|url = http://new-supercollider-mailing-lists-forums-use-these.2681727.n2.nabble.com/Tidal-and-supercollider-td7615895.html|website = new-supercollider-mailing-lists-forums-use-these.2681727.n2.nabble.com|accessdate = 2015-05-25}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Digital art]] [[Category:Computer programming]] [[Category:Live coding]] [[Category:Algorave]]

{{refimprove|date=September 2014}} {{Cite check|section called "United States sports victories"|date=July 2016}} [[File:American troops march down the Champs Elysees.jpg|thumb|right|250px|[[United States Army|American troops]] parade down the [[Avenue des Champs-Élysées]], after the [[Liberation of Paris]] in August 1944]] A '''victory parade''' is a [[parade]] held to celebrate a victory. Numerous [[military]] and [[sport]] victory parades have been held.
== Military victory parades== Among the most famous parades are the victory parades celebrating the end of the [[First World War]] and the [[Second World War]]. However, victory parades date back to ancient Rome, where [[Roman triumphs]] celebrated a leader who was militarily victorious. In the modern age, victory parades typically take the form of celebrating a national victory, rather than a personal one.
In the former [[USSR]] including the [[Russian Federation]] victory parades are held annually in every major city celebrating the victory of the Soviet Union in the [[Great Patriotic War (term)|Great Patriotic War]] (1941–1945).
=== Allies of World War II === *[[Berlin Victory Parade of 1945]] - USSR, USA, Great Britain and France *[[Berlin Victory Parade of 1946]] - USSR, USA, Great Britain and France
=== China === [[File:The military parade in honor of the 70-th anniversary of the end of the Second world war 01.jpg|thumb|Soldiers marching in the parade]] * [[2015 China Victory Day Parade]], September 3, 2015, a military parade to celebrate the 70th anniversary of Victory over Japan Day of the Second World War.
=== Germany === * [[Fall of France|1940 German Victory Parade in Paris]]. After the Fall of France, the German army marched down the Champs-Élysées in Triumph on 14 June 1940.
=== France === [[File:Le défilé de la Victoire, le 14 juillet 1919, François Flameng.jpg|thumb|''Le défilé de la Victoire, le 14 juillet 1919'', by [[François Flameng]]]] * [[1919 Paris Victory Parade]], celebrating the victory in the [[World War I|First World War]]. <!--need better sources--> * [[1944 Dieppe Victory Parade]], Victory Parade of the [[2nd Canadian Infantry Division]] in [[Dieppe, Seine-Maritime|Dieppe]] celebrated on 3 September 1944
=== Soviet Union / Post-Soviet Countries=== {{main|Victory Day Parades (9 May)}} Parades are traditionally held on 9 May to celebrate the victory in World War II over Nazi Germany.
=== Spain === * [[1939 Madrid Victory Parade]], held on 1 April 1939 to commemorate the Nationalist victory in the [[Spanish Civil War]] (1936-1939).
=== United Kingdom === * [[London Victory Parade of 1815|1815 London Victory Parade]], celebrating the victory in the [[Napoleonic Wars]]. * [[1919 London Victory Parade]], celebrating the victory in the [[World War I|First World War]]. * [[1945 Berlin British Victory Parade]] * [[1946 London Victory Parade]], celebrating the victory in the [[World War II|Second World War]]. * [[1982 London Victory Parade]], celebrating the victory in the [[Falklands War]].
=== United States === [[File:MIM-104 Patriot during the National Victory Celebration parade honoring the coalition forces of Desert Storm.JPEG|thumb|A MIM-104 Patriot tactical air defense missile system is towed by a heavy expanded mobility tactical truck in the National Victory Celebration.]] * [[Grand Review of the Armies]] * [[New York City Victory Parade of 1946]], January 12, designated by the [[United States Department of War]] to head the G.I. Victory Parade up [[Fifth Avenue]]. The 8,800 men of the [[82nd Airborne]] after docking in N.Y.C. harbour, aboard the [[RMS Queen Mary|Queen Mary]] the division was greeted by Mayor [[William O'Dwyer]]. This event was filmed by [[Pathe News]]. * [[National Victory Celebration]]
== Sports victory parades == {{split-section|date=November 2017}} ===United Kingdom sports victories === * [[Our Greatest Team Parade]] - celebrating Britain's successful 2012 Olympic and Paralympic teams * There is an annual victory parade to celebrate the winner of football's [[Premier League]], held in the winner's home city
===United States sports victories === Cities hosting the winning sports team in one of the [[U.S. cities with teams from four major league sports|four major league sports]] will host a victory parade in the city that the team represents. * [[Major League Baseball|MLB]] - [[List of World Series champions|World Series champions]] ** The most recent was the 2017 [[Houston Astros]] Victory Parade in [[Houston, Texas]] on November 3, 2017, attended by an estimated 750 000 to 1 million people.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sportsnet.ca/baseball/mlb/houston-honouring-world-series-champion-astros-parade/|title=Cheering fans greet World Series champion Houston Astros|publisher=Sportsnet|date=3 November 2017|access-date=4 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://abc13.com/community-events/city-1-million-attend-epic-astros-victory-parade-rally/2594302/|title=IT'S A CELEBRATION! Houston Astros victory parade and rally turned into epic party|publisher=ABC 13|date=3 November 2017|accessdate=4 December 2017}}</ref> * [[National Football League|NFL]] - [[List of Super Bowl champions|Super Bowl champions]] ** The most recent was the 2018 [[Philadelphia Eagles]] Victory Parade in [[Philadelphia]] on February 8, 2018, attended by an estimated 1 million.<ref>{{cite news |date=February 9, 2018 |title=LOOK: Eagle's Parade Attendance |url=http://www.philly.com/philly/super-bowl-lii/eagles-parade-attendance-crowd-estimate-philadelphia-super-bowl-20180208.html |agency=[[Philadelphia Inquirer]] |publisher=[[Philadelphia Inquirer]] |accessdate=February 9, 2018}}</ref> * [[National Hockey League|NHL]] - [[List of Stanley Cup champions|Stanley Cup champions]] ** The most recent was the 2017 [[Pittsburgh Penguins]] Victory Parade in [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania|Pittsburgh]] on June 14, 2017, which drew 650,000 people. <ref>{{cite news |date=June 16, 2016 |title=Penguins' victory parade largest parade in city history |url=http://www.wpxi.com/news/penguins-victory-parade-largest-parade-in-city-history/340074727 |agency=[[WPXI]] |accessdate=November 3, 2016}}</ref> * [[National Basketball Association|NBA]] - [[List of NBA champions|NBA champions]] ** The most recent was the 2017 [[Golden State Warriors]] Victory Parade in [[Oakland, California|Oakland]] on June 15, 2017, with an estimated turnout of 1 million people.
== See also == * [[Roman triumph]] * [[Victory Day]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * {{youtube|c2DqWGY1QHM|Victory Parade, USSR, 1945}}
[[Category:Aftermath of war]] [[Category:Military parades]] [[Category:Victory parades| ]]

{{Infobox music festival | name =World Popular Song Festival
(Yamaha Music Festival) | image =File:Nippon Budokan 2010.jpg | caption = | location =[[Tokyo]], [[Japan]] | years_active =1970 until 1989 | founders =[[Yamaha Music Foundation]] | dates = | genre = [[Rock music]], | attendance = | capacity = | website =[http://www.yamaha-mf.or.jp/history/e-history/wpsf/ Official Site by Yamaha Music Foundation] }} The {{nihongo|'''World Popular Song Festival'''|世界歌謡祭|Sekai Kayōsai}}, also known as '''Yamaha Music Festival''' and unofficially as the '''"Oriental Eurovision"''', was an international song contest held from 1970 until 1989. It was organised by the [[Yamaha Music Foundation]] in [[Tokyo]], [[Japan]] from 1970 until 1989. The first edition of the World Popular Song Festival (WPSF) took place on 20, 21 and 22 November 1970 with 37 participating countries from all continents. The concert was cancelled in 1988 due to the illness of the [[Shōwa Emperor]]; the final year was a charity concert for [[UNICEF]], after which the contest was formally ended.[http://www.yamaha-mf.or.jp/history/e-history/wpsf/ Official Site by Yamaha Music Foundation] ==History== [[Belgium]] was represented at the 1970 edition by [[Daliah Lavi]], famous for her role in ''[[Casino Royale (1967 film)|Casino Royale]]'' (1967), the [[James Bond]] parody featuring [[Woody Allen]] as well with Samantha Gilles in 1987 ending second with the song Hold Me. Lavi performed the [[chanson]] "Prends L'Amour" and ended up 13th in the Grand Final (the contest had two semi-finals and one final). The [[Netherlands]] delegated world-known jazz singer [[Rita Reys]] with the song "Just Be You", a composition by her husband Pim Jacobs. Czech singer [[Helena Vondráčková]] sang "Uncle Charlie" a novelty song inspired by [[Charlie Chaplin]]. Other famous 1970 participants were 1969 Eurovision winner [[Frida Boccara]] for [[France]], Jacques Michel for [[Canada]] and [[Ted Mulry]] for [[Australia]], who scored a national number 1 hit with his entry. Winner of the 1st WPSF was [[Israel]] with the duo Hedva & David. More than 2 million copies of their winning entry "Ani Holem Al Naomi" ("I Dream Of Naomi") were sold worldwide, giving a serious credibility boost to the new Festival. Well established names as well as new talents tried their fortune at the WPSF: a very young [[ABBA]] under the name [[Björn Ulvaeus|Björn]] & [[Benny Andersson|Benny]] with uncredited backing vocals by their partners [[Agnetha Fältskog|Agnetha]] and [[Anni-Frid Lyngstad|Anni-Frid]] performing the track "Santa Rosa" with little success (later relegated to the B-side of their second single "He Is Your Brother"), [[Celine Dion|Céline Dion]] (Best Song Award in 1982), [[Bryan Adams]] (Participating in 1982), [[Bucks Fizz]] (Best Song Award in 1981), [[Tina Charles (singer)|Tina Charles]], [[Eros Ramazzotti]], [[Daniela Romo]], [[Gianna Nannini]], [[Demis Roussos]], [[Bonnie Tyler]], [[B.J. Thomas]], [[La Toya Jackson]], [[Erasure]], [[Cissy Houston]], Italian singer-songwriter [[Alice (Italian singer)|Alice]] and many others. In the history of the WPSF, the [[United Kingdom]] has been the most successful, winning the "WPSF Grand Prix" 5 times in the seventies (even three times in row). The United Kingdom is followed by the [[United States]] with 4 Grand Prix victories. Smaller countries won as well: [[Jamaica]] in 1972 with [[Ernie Smith (singer)|Ernie Smith]], [[Norway]] in 1974 with [[Ellen Nikolaysen]], [[Cuba]] in 1981 with [[Osvaldo Rodríguez (Cuban)|Osvaldo Rodríguez]] and [[Hungary]] in 1983 with [[Neoton Família]].{{Citation needed|date=July 2017}} ==Grand Prix Winners== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#ccccff" !
